I originally started with FS17 on console and really didn't know about available mods for money cheats and didn't quite understand the use of mods so I did it the hard way and worked up from scratch by taking contracts and running those long jobs.   Buying land bit by bit.  I could make $50,000 on one harvest job.  I made like $40 million the hard way before moving on to FS19 Platinum edition.  The livestock in FS17 became lucrative as I was making $200,000 a day on milk and regularly selling thousands of pigs at a time for millions of dollars.  After playing FS19 on XBox One for awhile I discovered streamers on the channels who were using all these great mods that I didn't have access to.  Because they were only on PC.  So I bought the PC version.  Although I didn't do much with livestock with FS19 on Xbox.  I did that when I went to FS19 on PC.  And I found it disappointing because it's not that lucrative.  Cows don't produce enough manure, slurry, or milk to be worth the time having them.  They're not a money maker, they're a decoration.   The pigs are also anal-retentive.  If you want a lot of manure in FS19 you must construct a mod to buy it.  Also the volume of livestock is restricted by the pens available.   Many of the Cow Barns, pens, etc., that I experimented with had dump points that didn't work properly or were inside structures that prevented me from dumping my big truck trailers.  And the trucks would get stuck and need to be re-set.  A lot of the cow corral mods are broken.   The pigs were unsatisfying and so were the chickens.  You don't even need to water the chickens, they don't eat hardly anything, and their egg production is pathetic no matter how many of them you buy.  The sheep produce a pathetically small amount of wool.  The horses are for amusement, not production.   Although a horse breeding mod is available.  I was amazed at how low-maintenance are the livestock.  They're no work at all.  I kept checking back in, amazed, thinking, I still have no work to do here?  In FS17 they were a lot of work for a big reward.  In FS19 the livestock are very little work for very little reward.    The breeding rates of the livestock in FS19 is also slow.  In summary, the livestock in FS19 suck.   But I'm not trying to trash a great game.  And FS19 is a great game worth the money.  There are so many available maps and an incredible amount of mods available.  There are huge maps where you can take harvesting numbers to astronomical levels.  With Course Play this takes the entire game to a new level.   Socking away astronomical amounts of crops in a silo that will take 30 million liters.  One a couple maps the given silo was 100 million capacity.   Obtaining the mods can be ominous as some sites are full of adware and malware.  Right now I'm working on the Mining and Construction Economy map.  But I am disappointed by the limitations of the livestock on the other maps.  And it's very likely I will soon be buying Farming Simulator 17 Platinum on PC here on Steam and explore the available mods I never saw on console.  Because I might want to see what it is like to try to raise 2000 cows and 10,000 pigs.  And explore some of the larger maps I  never saw on console.  Hopefully in the next installment GIANT will get the livestock right.  Animals should be a productive element of the farm.  Not just a decoration.

I'm not a farmer, but I can imagine this is what being one is like. This game isn't perfect, but let me tell you what I do like about it. There are so many real-life and well-detailed pieces of equipment and vehicles in this game that it's basically farm equipment porn. They all handle (I suppose) how they would IRL, and that feels wonderful. The harvesters have weight, the trailers sway on bumps, etc. It's a little complicated figuring out what piece of equipment is used for, but most of them you don't really have to pay attention to unless you want to dive really deep with this game. The environments are gorgeous and scenic and you can almost smell the grass.

What I don't like about it is more than a few things, so my recommendation is kind of a 45-degree angle thumbs up. For some inexplicable reason the pickup truck physics are floaty as hell and they turn way too damn quick. Also for whatever reason Giants couldn't get licensed brands for the pickups and American big rigs, very weird. There's no crash damage in this game. I went head-on into another driver at 70 and stopped dead with no damage. You can fling your truck off a cliff, have it do 10 barrel rolls and pirouettes in mid-air, have it land right side up and drive away like nothing happened. What even is that?

The cities feel empty. People dot the streets but they're ghosts you can drive right through. Can't talk to anyone, can't even run anybody over. The other physics are sometimes wonky, like loading logs or picking up items. Your player character is some kind of superhuman who can leap on top of buildings and climb up almost vertical cliff faces. There's no third-person mode. In the default game there's only 2 maps, despite hundreds of pieces of equipment. Parts of the economy are kind of weird and nonsensical. And why can you drive the train? You can't load anything on it, you can't do anything with it.

Overall, a very fun game as long as you focus on the FARMING aspect of Farming Simulator and don't look too deep under the hood, because there ain't much there. 6.5/10

Everything in this game that involves driving a tractor across a field is great. Tractors look and feel pretty good, you get a large selection to choose from, and you get to carry all sorts of implements. Harvesters are also nice, although I wish there was more variety.

Everything that does not involve driving a tractor across a field is buggy or neglected. Farm building is bugged, but there's not much suitable space on provided maps, unless you want to destroy fields. Trees are bugged. Stacking pallets is bugged. Selling eggs and wool is bugged. Harvesting sugar beet and potatoes is bugged. Economy does not make sense. I really wish the developers would address all that, but they do not seem to care.

Farming Simulator 19 is another one of those games I sink multiple hours into, and is easily a good time waster. It is a a very realistic game and emulates the farming lifestyle pretty well. The base game is pretty much all you need and if you want more content you can just buy DLC or download mods. The only downside to FS19 is that it requires much patience when doing the usual plowing, cultivating, seeding, and harvesting especially when you are working on larger fields so if you don't have much patience this isn't really a game for you, otherwise I would rate the game 10/10.

I have been playing this game since 2011. I messed around on 2009 but 11 is when I got hooked. Overall I recommend this game to all who enjoy farming and simulators. But, I have two complaints. One is that there are still so many issues with the AI and at this point I don't know or understand why there is. You all have made great improvements although many were mods before you guys added them lol but the AI still isn't bug free. I like that we can create fields and such but there is no point when the AI get confused in certain areas and when the not so dynamic map doesn't update with the new fields created. For the second thing, I recently wanted to buy some of the DLC content you have offered. But noticed that the season pass is only offered to new comers... This is a bit frustrating and dare I say rude to myself and any other veteran players. Please, fix this issue and allow us all to enjoy a discount and new content. And please fix the dang AI! lmao it is getting old and quite sad at this point. P.S. I'll buy FS21 when it is available... maybe because I am a sucker? lol I own FS11, FS13, FS15, FS17, and FS19, so might as well own FS21. I will hold off on buying any of the DLCs out right now though until there is a discount or I can buy the Season Pass... Thanks for reading.

UPDATE AS OF September 2020!  -  I'm extremely disappointed that there will be no Farming Simulator 21 and the reason is this:  I have now exhausted the game and a few map mods that I'm totally 'over' these days. There are many amazing mods for the game and they have pushed me over the 1100 hours mark but a new FS is needed and now I feel that in 2021 I'll be left with an old game propped up my mods :/   |-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|   Original review: It took many updates to get to this quality, with some going backwards like my G920 steering wheel not working properly at launch, to fixed, then to randomly broken, the fps going up and down with each patch. There were many issues after launch which simply shouldn't have happened, but I'm happy to say that most have been fixed now. It's good to know that Giants are listening to the community and this has made me confident in the game again.I would still like to see the draw distance changed so that on max settings, the trees don't dumb down and objects disappear, I mean if I can see for miles and miles in every other sim game, why can't I in FS19? Perhaps it's because the consoles have won the day and the higher end PC's are now the minority :/The game play needs no information from me as it's all explained now on the store page sections, comments, previews and on Youtube.So to round up this review.Right now this game is at its best and well worth buying, plus those players that walked away due to the multitude of problems should jump back in and give it another go.

Is this the most realistic modern farming experience? Yes. Is it fun? Sometimes.

Most of the issues I'm going to talk about can be mitigated with mods, maps, etc. However, I want to provide a point of view for people who don't want to mod the game a bunch to get it to what I'd consider a fun state.

Graphics: They're good and more or less what I'd expect from the genre. They're nothing fancy, but they're hardly bad. Nothing more to say without getting nit-picky.

Sound: The sound is good. It is also nothing amazing or bad.

Gameplay: Oooh boy... This is good and bad. I'm going to split this up into sections below. I'll just say that I'm playing on keyboard and mouse, so bear that in mind. I don't really have the money to buy a setup for a specialized controller. I could also probably get good results from an xbox controller as well. 

Maps: I HATE the map design for the default maps. Ravenport isn't bad. I like the layout of the shops and roads, but I hate the fields. I also feel like you're required to back into way too many spots. 

General Gameplay: This game is REALLY slow. I knew this going in of course, but I didn't realize that it would be quite this slow. Yes, I realize you can adjust the time multiplier but this doesn't effect your farming machines speed. It only effects the grow speed of crops and the flux of prices. 

Modding: The best part is most of this can be fixed with mods. Mods are very easy to install and can make your game into pretty much what you want. For example, because I'm playing with keyboard and mouse, I opted to get a mod to load pallets and bags automatically as running a forklift with keyboard and mouse isn't really intuitive. All in all, I like this game, but think it definitely needs mods to be playable.

I know this has probably being spoken of a lot, but I simply cannot endorse this game because of its overpriced DLC. The gameplay is great for what it is and it has excellent mod support with a keen modding community. 

But you don't have to look too far to see the problem with Giants DLC policy every iteration of farming sim has been milked more and more, have a look at the platinum expansion for example as an add-on it is as much as the base game. Then there is the recent Kverneland and Vicon equipment pack I could go on and on.

When it was announced that there will not be a Farming simulator 21 I was looking forward to the continued support and updates to this, instead as I should have expected we are expecting a "premium edition" on top of the already platinum edition as well as an alpine farming expansion with hardly any content for exorbitant prices this was the last straw as far as I am concerned.

You can take this as just a rant and buy it anyway sure, but I for one will not be buying into this in the future and if enough others also avoid it Giants may just take a look and fix what is otherwise a great game.

I would never have considered myself to be someone who played a farming simulator but Giants have done really well with this one. The vehicles feel real and look good, there are a great many different types and it covers all aspects of farming I can think of. The modding community has my respect too as they produce a massive quantity of high quality mods, some of the maps are quite exceptional and must take a great deal of dedication to build, the vehicles and statics are generally great too. All said, this game has a large amount of replay value if you are into the type of play even slightly. You can just get stuck in to arcade like farming or if you are the sort of player who likes it you can go down the realism route too.

I don't know where to start.  FS19 is such a versatile game if you are wanting to run your own (imaginary) business.  The options provided at the start give the player a choice of their level of challenge which makes the game so much fun!  I enjoy the huge selection of mods available!  Gameplay is so diversified by the mods offered, that newer modes of playing can be created and carried out.  The folks at Giants Software have included a map editor for those who enjoy the meticulous creation of playable maps and also created a pseudo competition in the mod community as to who can create the best maps!  The game is huge and offers more and more each and everyday!  I can't begin to tell you just how much I love this game!

Just embrace the nerdery and get past the title-shaming.  If you like any game that involves base-building, logistics, management, or economy, this game has a satisfying blend of each -- and that's BEFORE incorporating mods, and some mods can absolutely extend beyond the "farm" scope.

In the base game, there's plant agriculture, animal husbandry, and an opportunity to focus on forestry and forest management (admittedly some maps emphasize this more heavily than others.)

Also: lifetime PC player, "keyboard and mouse" until I die, but I'm absolutely gonna buy a steering wheel for this game, and possibly a small joystick for the hydraulic / forklift aspects, too.

Since I have played this game a slight amount, let me give you the general run down. 

You start a farm, you gradually build up to bigger and faster equipment, adding more and more land as you expand. Then you get bored. Then you start a new map. Then you run out of stock maps and decide to give mods a try. At this point you are irredeemable. 

The next thing you know, you're like me. Sitting on 1,350 hours and 5 completed farms and you're lonely. So you think, ah I know. I'll involve my friends. 

So you throw together a mod pack, get everyone on the same page and generally enjoy your time. Everyone finds their own little niche and does well working together. Then one by one they fade away, because they're not addicted like you are, and they find doing the same thing over and over a bore and repetitive because they don't have a second monitor to watch videos on the side or listen to their perfectly crafted motivational farming music playlist like you. 

So now you have 6 or 7 farms that you're the sole caretaker of, and you're always browsing the mods and watching farming simulator videos on YouTube to see if there's any new maps that catch your eye. Oh, and of course, you'll pre-order the new one as soon as it's announced, because who knows what new lands you'll tame? 

I don't regret a single hour I spent playing and would gladly do it again.

FS19 is inherently a good game, in almost all aspects. For one thing, the graphics and optimization are both fantastic, meaning that playing on lower-end systems and even laptops is a breeze. Of course, it's also available on console, if that's your thing. There is a wide variety of equipment for you to choose from in the base game alone, with much more content available from mods. Gameplay is a mixed bag, and which many people enjoy it, is is admittedly somewhat mundane by nature. However, FS19 does not seem to have the same problems with redundancy that plagues some of the earlier titles in the series, with a wide variety of crops to grow, as well as several options for animal husbandry, and even forestry. Overall, I would recomend the game, but I would also say that you shouldn't buy it unless you are sure that it is the sort of thing that you would enjoy.

11 out of 10. this game is Fantastic!  the environment and details are so immersive, it started raining in game, i paused and ran around the house to make sure the dogs were inside! (of course it was sunny and 100 degrees outside) FS19 presents a perfect blend of simulation and real time strategy. The environment is very dynamic and natural, the vehicles are highly detailed, and different game play modes offer different levels of challenges... I would have enjoyed more selections of classic American Tractors that I saw growing up, but FS19 does have an active mod community, and after a few minutes browsing the content, modification should be straightforward. content is managed with .xml and uses common image formats... i have been too busy playing to look, but there is probably a blender plug in to manage the geometry.... for many years, everytime I saw Farming Simulator on a store shelf, I would look at the images and think, i dont have the disk space, my machine wont handle the graphics.... I wasted a lot of time.... The install was under 10gig, the graphics are fantastic and i have not yet dropped a frame... FS19 runs rock solid on my generic off the shelf laptop. I will absolutely recommend Farming Simulator to Everyone!

Decent game if you like grinding for things. Essentially that's what this comes down to. You work your fields to make money to buy more fields and bigger equipment to work the fields better. Repeat until you own all the fields and the biggest toys. 

The gameplay is pretty simple. There are basic rules and steps to follow for the different types of crops that you grow and the livestock you can keep. The vehicles themselves are all well modelled but I felt a bit more like I was playing with toy farm equipment than actually 'simulating' their driving. Don't expect this to be the 'iRacing' of tractor games, it's more arcade. There is no damage modelling. Collisions do nothing but bump you around and vehicle handling is more like GTA. Still that does allow you to focus more on the farm management and less on learning to drive a harvester. Also wheel support was pretty sparse. My G27 worked but the game offers very little configuration options. Had to do a lot of tweaking outside the game to get it feeling right.

All in all though Farming Simulator was a fun, relaxed experience. Definitely a change of pace from most other games. It does what it does well, that is farm management, and there are a ton of different vehicles to drive, equipment to try, crops to grow and animals to raise.

Not for everyone but definitely check it out if you're interested in farming or just want a relaxed, grindy, time management game to chill out to.

This is a great game in my opinion. I started this game and couldn't stop for a time, i just like when i can start from nothing and gradually build myself up through management and upgrades. I like how you have a variety of machines and tools to use. There are also mods if the stock stuff doesn't do what you want. You can expect to spend countless hours, growing and modifying and expanding. Choose the type of crop or animal etc, maintain the field etc its good. 

However what i find bad is the awful physics engine. When you decide to go logging, and you start to use machines to manipulate wood. Its like summoning a demon that haunts the game. Wood begins to do things you can't explain. You get frustrated because its so stupid to control. So logging is good money but awful without mods that imo is cheating.  Also i feel as though certain mod should be stock. The ai needs to be better. There needs to be more crops. Dev's should also look more into the processing side of things aswell. Anyway you can engage the player and give them more to do is good. 

The only reason i uninstalled was because i got bored, it got too consistent, only certain crops make significant money. If they add some new stuff i'd be happy to jump back in though.

The game is like real life.

If you want a game to just relax to without any set goals, this is the one. Just like real farming, you get back only what you put into the game. The options are about limitless with what you want to do-farm crops, raise animals, put up hay, harvest timber, or do a little of everything. You can even change terrain features with the in-game map editor. There are also countless mods with equipment and maps so the possibilities are endless.
If you're willing to invest in some controllers I highly recommend getting a steering wheel/pedal set along with a joystick because this makes the game that much more realistic and fun. Before you realize it you'll find you've wasted countless hours of your life playing a simulator with no end. Farm with a friend on co-op mode and try stacking hay bales after a few adult beverages for the real shannigans to begin.

I dont have a huge amount of hours under my belt for this game but enough to know two things. It's both brilliant and not so in equal measure.

What I like:
Do (almost) whatever you want - There's a pretty good choice of farming to specialize in.
The farm machinery is sensational, the selection and realism is very good and just shopping for new toys is fun by itself.
Relaxation - Really is a game that soothes your soul as you learn about things like PTO shafts and yields.
Mods - To be quite honest, the game is nothing without them.


What I dont like:
It's all very 1 dimensional - Grow/harvest/sell and repeat. I would love a more enriched commerce feature. Like, adding value to your crops in a factory and selling to the open market with other players (Mods exists for this kind of play but they can be clunky)
Multiplayer - tried a few times, found it messy and buggy and laggy...all the y's
BUGS - I mean the game is around since 2008 and your tractor still ends up on it's side like your Granny with a bad hip
AI - it's very limited,  you really should be able to hire workers to do the full harvest from start to finish


Overall:
The game is nice to play for a while but too reliant on mods and I fear the devs are happy to let the community do the hard work. I think it really needs to be taken to the next level in future releases with an enriched multiplayer, GPS, better AI plus more game mechanics that allow you to do more with your crops then just sell the raw product.

I give it a recommendation based on the fact I paid <€30 and the modding community.

I've been a fan of just about every driving, trucking, railroad, etc simulator that's out there. I think I enjoy this one the most. I could be biased because I drive trucks and buses for a living - and just find those boring now, and I originally didn't think Farming Simulator could be all that good. But there's so much to do in game! Plenty of equipment/tools/land/contracts in the base game with loads of mods to download. You can tweak the game settings so crops grow as quick or as slow as you prefer. Additionally, in basic career mode there are contracts you can take on which gives you a chance to explore all of the different machines the game has to offer. If you're on the fence about it - wait for a sale, check out the 'tube sites for gameplay video and decide for yourself - that's what I did - and I don't regret it! Happy Farming!

Will you like this game? Beats me. If you like relaxing, strategy/time management games and get inspired by a seemingly endless array of machinery and other things to strive for, then  you'll probably enjoy the game. But that's not why I'm bothering to write this review. I'm writing this review because the most remarkable thing about this game is how well it works. In a sea of games that struggle to provide what they promise, this game is amazing.

I have 68 mods activated, and the game takes less than 10 seconds to load and start. I have 6 fields, tons of equipment and placeables, co-op partners, half-a-dozen AI workers going at once, etc. and the game has never once dipped below the 60 FPS that I have it set at--and I'm playing on a laptop. I've had the game crash once and that was on a custom map-created by a modder-that conflicted with one of my mods.

Speaking of mods, the modding is incredible. You can install mods directly from the in-game menu, or you can go to their mod-hub website and download them to the mod folder. Super easy. There are so many great mods that it extends the playability by a considerable margin. Many mods are uploaded by the developers themselves, including bonus maps from previous versions of the game and many equipment packs. They could sell these as DLC, but they give them away for free.

I'm just very impressed. Big thumbs up.

As someone who has never played any of the Farming Simulator series, and this is my first time playing it, I would like to share my opinions about this game.

The game at first seems really difficult to understand, and frankly, it was kind of frustrating. But with tutorials, searching online for videos with tips or pages with useful information in them, and some playing, I really got the hang of it. Once you learn how Plowing, Cultivation, Sowing, etc. works, you pretty much go on your business with planting your favorite grains, or any of the other types the game has to offer. The graphical aspect of the game is amazing, no complaints there, although if you want, you can also download textures. The way the different machines work is just astonishing and really satisfying. The level of detail in each one of the machines is beautiful and I could not ask for better than that. To be honest, I really like big machines such as Harvesters, because they have that something about them which makes you want to use them. The game is superbly relaxing when you're just sowing or harvesting something on your field/s, or just when you drive around to deliver chaff, for example. 
The amount of machines you can work with and use is totally ENOUGH for me (and that might be true for you too), although you can buy the dlcs which would add more options in your machinery sections, depending on what you're working on. You can also download great mods depending on what you need (Certain cultivators for corn for example). I would say one thing though; If you're planning on growing sugarcanes, know that your options are almost NON-EXISTENT, that is because you have only one machine to work with and attaching a trailer to it is useless as the trailers that DO fit are small in their capacity, as harvesting sugarcanes gives huge amounts of it and you'll need a friend that will help you with the trailer part or, just use some mods.
Working on your field and growing grains and crops and getting the reward, in the end, is what makes me keep playing the game. 
You have 3 modes which you have to pick one of them, "New farmer" which is for newbies, "Farm manager" which is for amateur+ players who already have learned how to play, and "Start from scratch" which is for the expert players who truly feel they're up for a challenge.
The gameplay part is great, and its really easy to play with a keyboard once you memorize all the buttons for all the controls (The same goes for controller users too). You can buy many fields, and if two maps aren't enough for you, you can download user-made content which will make playing the game even more fun and it will last much, much longer. This game takes time to master and understand, so don't skip the tutorials as they are your starting point.
Before buying the game I was thinking if I would even play it, but I am glad that I purchased the game. 
I can write more about the game but for now, I'll let you decide if you want to buy the game or not. I would totally recommend the game to a friend. 10/10.

I'm in love with this game! Of course I'm on player-created maps, using lots of the mods, and really enjoying the process. The game is a fantastic platform! The UI is organized and easy to navigate. The gameplay is scale-able for a wide range of computers and consoles. Admittedly, its a totally nerdy game, but I'm a proud nerd, so this is right up my alley. I recommend the DLC because its just a small amount of paid content, when sooo much content is available for free. So it's sort of out of a feeling of obligation... or guilt... I most likely need therapy. But, real talk: some of the in game DLC is free, so you just do whatever you feel is right. New player-created mods regularly come out at a rate of more than 5 per week. That's more than 5 free downloads all accessible from within the game, each week. The Farming Simulator community is huge, with tons of video content-creators on popular online video-sharing social networks, wink. So I recommend the game with a thumbs up.

I own Farming Simulator 17 and it's fantastic and I thought this would be a great purchase but I was wrong. The Tutorial doesn't show you how to get started and any of the basics it jumps right into the more advanced farming of the game. So you will spend many hours just trying to get started and figure out simple things like how to purchase land or simply gassing up your vehicle and be frustrated long before you even get a chance to do anything. It really seems like a scaled down version of Farming Simulator 17 with little direction and the map is a fraction of the Farming Simulator 17.

My suggestion to the developers is to revisit the tutorial and add a basics tutorial that shows how to get started, I looked through the key bindings and found nothing stating how to fuel your vehicle and tried every pump while being in and out of the vehicle and found no possible way to get gas in my tractor. this seems like it was slapped together quickly with a smaller map and no direction and I don't suggest purchasing this, purchase Farming Simulator 17 it's much better from what i can see, very disappointed this should have been so much better then Farming Simulator 17, cheap imitation.

There are quite a few things you can do with a farming simulator game, and that's one of the most amazing things about the series. The only problem about this is that most of these things are recycled mechanics from previous games. if you have played any previous farming simulator game, Congratulations! you've completed roughly 80% of this game!

Aside from that, this newest installment is decidedly lacking in unique map content and vehicles, as well as being much more "grindey".
I don't know, maybe I've played too much of the franchise, but its just too repetitive for me.

I love this game. Especially with all the mods for it. 

My only complaint is the game is to euro. It kind of ruins the immersion of playing as a US farmer when I can't pronounce the names of half of my equipment. "Oh yeah.. I love driving rasabahabadubahdah!" Said the Farmer in total confusion.

Not slagging euro products but there is a lot of missing gear in this game. A lot more than I would expect from the 2019 version. Where is Kubota? Mahindir? Yes I know they aren't American but both are very common in the US. 

There are a lot of great mods that add in more gear in this game. But it's a real chore to download the 900 or so different mods needed to make the game feel authentic. I wish they came as a pack. On the plus side downloading and installing mods is probably easier in this game than in any other I have played. Even if you use the mods that don't install through the game client. Just drag a zip file into your documents/mygames/fs2019 folder and boom. All done! 

This is a great name and this franchise really needs to keep going. Hopefully somebody in the modding community will figyre  out how to pack 10-20 mods into one big download.

P.s. Whoever made the f350 powerstroke mod, THANK YOU!

Farming simulator 19 is a fantastic game by german developer GIANTS Software. I have the original pre-order dvd version of FS19 and now just recently the steam version. despite the issues in the early days of FS19, the game has expanded rapidly through its DLC's and daily uploaded mods to the ingame modhub to expand the gameplay. I must say that FS19 as a whole and where it is going right now is great. Giants have done a fantastic job on the game thus far and with farmcon just around the corner I'm looking forward to see where it is going to go next.

Would highly suggest this to anyone. with almost 800 hours in game I can honestly say I've not gotten bored. It's very relaxing if you just want something casual to relax with an build then this is the perfect game for you.

It's a realllly slow game. So, Take that in account when you buy it. 

Also, Devs really need to add a system so toppled/stuck vehicles can be brought back on their wheels easily. In the 30-40 minutes I spent playing this game, I had my 2 SUVs stuck vertically in trees, My tractor's trolley was stuck up in a mountain behind a tree. I took another two tractors to take the trolley out but I got both tractors stuck behind a rock on a mountain. I didn't knew how to use/buy the hand held tree cutter. Then, I took my harvestor and got that stuck as well. 

At the end of that game, I had no money and all my equipment was stuck. I tried to un-stuck some of it with a fork lift but the fork lift's arms are weak and can't lift any of the vehicles. I also tried bringing arms in the middle and then just driving into a vehicle but that didn't work either. 

I also couldn't just keep walking into a vehicle to move it a little bit. It's usually possible in some other games but not in this one. 

soo, be careful with your vehicles.

Thought this game would be boring, to be honest it is. if you are looking for excitement this is not the game for you. there is hardly any 'content' so i would suggest dozens of mods such as a maps and more vehicles, objects etc. 

BUT - it is also satisfying, you have a sense of achievement when you sell you product. You can be a humble farmer, grow crops, feed cows and drive your product to somewhere to sell. 

it is geared more towards a US farm than a UK or european farm.

I guess after 1,215 hours, I would recommend this game to other players.  It is fun and addictive.  Very customizable and offers good DLC addons of real industry equipment that don't break the bank. (Try that with FSX).  There are thousands of mods to extend your gameplay; whether it is deeper immersion (Season or MaizePlus mods) or more fantasy (1 million liter harvesters or Wilson trailers.  Maps large and small, with all the standard fruits, or 10 or more different fruits.  Manufacturing and forestry mods also abound for a completely different direction.

There are other types of Farming sims out there and I own them all.  They are each fun in their own way, but nothing comes close to a fun afternoon (or complete day and night) on the fantasy farm like Farm Simulator 19.  I've been called a fanboy for my views.  I guess I am a 53 year old fanboy with real farming experience, that really likes to get away and enjoy myself.  But it is realistic enough that it does allow me to sample equipment that I might otherwise not try in the area of business I am in.  That's just a small sweet plus.  It's a firm buy for me.  Happy farming!
its good
As a person with an agriculture background, this game is really entertaining

Coming from FS17 I was disappointed, shocked actually. The starter map was junky and cluttered looking. I can see myself explaining to my friends why they cant use the barn close to the house, and instead drive to the biogas facility to store/sell hay. If this is the face of FS19 then its a poor start. Next they redid the Menu Based System. It appears their focus was based on game compatibility  with Computer Tablets. I run a computer with decent graphic, the whole menuing system and associated iconography lacks graphic detail and is just cluncky looking on a PC. This being  July of 2020, I was disapointed with the in game MODs available. I like the in game Publicly available Down Load Content (PDLC) but it just wasn't enough for my tastes. It Seem like every time I start searching for 3rd Party PDLC for FS Games eventually my Antivirus software starts complaining about unsafe site behavior, so I prefer in game PDLC.

In short would i recommend FS19 - NO, I would recommend FS17 instead, or wait and see how FS21 looks.

Negatives:

I was trying to think of how I wanted to review this game myself in a way that would best reflect my views on this game. Despite the 45 hours I've put into this game on Steam, I have also previously put around 264 hours into this game on the Epic Games Launcher (yes, I know what others think of the launcher. I don't care, I just use it to get free game) which totals my hours of gameplay to over 309 hours across both launchers.

Anyway, down to the review.

I recall thinking and saying something to myself some years back, roughly when I think FS17 came out, but it might also be FS19, I'm not sure. That thing was this, "This game looks stupid, I'd never play this." Fast forward to this year when they released it for free on the EGS and I started playing it, now also owning it here on Steam.

I do genuinely like this game, with the models of different equipment types from vehicles to trailers being well modeled and accurately represented. The graphics are also pretty dang good even on my low end hardware, which I found to be pretty pleasing. I have also come to enjoy how the game works with mods without much issues, which is also great.

Pros:

- Graphics look great, can't complain about how the game looks.

- Equipment representation is well-done and accurate, down to very small details.

- I like the brand variety in the game, giving a lot of choice for most uses.

Cons:

- The land editor could use some improvement and work, as I don't find it to be very good.

- The traffic AI isn't great and could use some tweaking.

-  The game has some mods that I have used that I think could be actual features in the game. Mods like Additional Field Information, Passenger Mod, God Hand, and more quality of life improvements.

- Being on a server is miserable, because the game freezes for a moment whenever someone joins, which makes being in any public server not worth it.

(This review might be updated if need be)

8.5/10

This game is so wide open and there are so many things to do.  I'm 20 hours in and I feel like I've been playing for maybe 30 min.  I want to try other maps, other equipment, other ... everything.  The visuals are so amazing and so much of the interactions are so realistic.  Love the physics and the detail put into everything.  The Mod community is strong as well.  I have barely jumped into the mods but have found something useful anytime I wanted to save time or make something more efficient.

I've never felt so much responsibility to wake up before the sun rises, because there's only so much time before  harvest, and it's the first day of Spring. As my tractor rolls at 15mph through the still asleep town, I've timed my arrival to the field perfectly, just as the first rays of sunlight cast a soft glow on the ground. time to begin preparing the ground for what will sustain my family until a year from now. By the time the sun is high overhead I'm chugging along to the sound of the radio, time for a lunch break and fill up the tractor. As the day turns golden it's the hint that today has been a productive one, but wait! It's going to rain tomorrow, looks like we'll be out here under the halogens tonight. Get this game if you want to appreciate all the finer details of what it ACTUALLY takes to be a farmer!

I had mixed emotions when the game first came out. There was a lot of things about the game that I really liked, but at the same time, some I didnt like. I have a list of some of those things.
Likes.
1) The graphics.
The graphics in this game were a huge step up from FS 17. And while having great graphics, the game is also fairly optimized. My Ryzen 5 and RTX 2070 ran this game beautifully, and I didnt think my other pc with an i3 4150 and gtx 1050 ti could match that. But to my surprise, the game ran perfectly at the same settings! So lets move onto the next thing.
2) In game brands.
There are many tractor, harvester, equipment, etc brands in the game. They have alot of really good brands when it comes to just about everything. From John Deer, to Massey Ferguson, you can choose what you want and how you want it. Though, it would be nice to have some vehicle brands aswell, like Ford or Chevy but those are just very small details.
3)  Crops and their physics.
The physics for the crops are pretty good. If you accidentally drive over your crops the bend, but dont always fall. With small vehicles they pop back up, but if you are using a Semi or heavy tractor, you better be careful!

Dislikes.
1) Animal physics.
It was disappointing seeing the animal physics once the game actually released. In the game commercial they made having a dog, or riding a horse seem like something fun to add to the game. In the end, it was not. Riding a horse is clunky, and not very enjoyable. As for the dog, it just kinda snaps in the direction it needs to go and you cant do anything asides from give it food and throw the ball. No getting it in the truck like in the commercial. Livestock could also use some new physics. In the end, I believe they could hire someone else to deal with those physics.
2) AI.
The AI can be annoying depending on how you drive or what you are doing. It is very annoying when something falls off a trailer in the road and the AI keep getting as close as they can so you cannot move it or load it back on, or when you have a wide load that gets sideswiped and knocked off by an AI. Small detail, but depending on what you are doing they can be a real heartache. 
I could write a lot more about the game, but it would take to long for me to write, and you to read. In the end I recommend the game as it can be quite addicting.

Been playing with this version for a few hours now. I had played 17 for some time and read reviews of this new one. I didn't get it at first because of the bad reviews it had. That was a mistake. This version 19 is so much better than the last. Still lots of great machinery to play with and of course lots to grow, animals to keep etc. The biggest improvement for me is the editing tools to change the land to how you want it. In the old version you placed a building (often on grass) and that was it. This new one lets you change the floor types so you can add paths, pads and driveways. You can also change the levels so the whole farm flows much better. A few more jobs to do in this version. Huge number of really good free mods. I don't have some high end PC and it runs on high graphic settings without any problems at all. I should have ignored the negative reviews and given it a go sooner. I waited for the Steam sale to grab mine and it is well worth it.

I ride horses and I really enjoy horse games. I have a good amount of horse mods and I usually just play for fun. It's a great game for anyone who wants to experience owning a farm. The game has great graphics and there are plenty of mods that make the game great.

Farming Simulator 19 is a great game if you're looking for a no stress gaming experience, and you can sink a lot of hours into growing your farm.

There is a bit of a learning curve if you don't have much experience around farms and equipment, but this can be overcome quickly by doing the in game tutorials and reading the help screen. And if you need further assistance, the Farming Simulator players are some of the most helpful players I've run into.

Graphics in FS19 are the best in the series, with a newly revamped engine. Highly detailed equipment and realistic day/night effects and lighting are great. What's not great is the lack of optimization, with my 2080 struggling to maintain 80+ FPS with all settings on max @ 1440p.

A very active mod community really enhances the playing experience. You can customize your experience to replicate farming in your part of the world, or try farming in far flung places such as Australia or South America.

I heard a lot of negative things about FS19 but in the end i just had to see for myself and frankly its all true. There is not much to offer besides the John Deer integration and a graphics overhaul. Most of which you could acheive give or take with mods in previous installments. 

If FS19 is going to be your first Farm Simulator, then yes I can recommend it.

However if you're coming out of FS17, I have yet to see anything new for returning players --- in fact it plays feels and operates like FS17 with enhancement mods.

I was hoping there would be more vehicular simulation; traction simulation, load bearing limits.... 

The only improvement I've seen is the level of detail on things like motors and parts. 

...this installment is not innovative in any way. 

The default maps seem to leave a lot to be desired particularly Ravenport, where your starting farm is cradled by mountains and the farm hands literally cannot navigate your fields because of it. My first 4 minutes in I told a guy to plow the field and another to harvest the starting field while I went and sold some unneeded equipment. I come back and find both the harvester and the tractor parked up a cliff side. 

This game is Farming Simulator 17 repainted.

Yes the graphics are good, yes the machinery is still authentic enough but for what you get its not really worth it if you already own Farming Simulator 17.

Truth be told though my first few minutes in I got a little nauseous at the soft shadows everywhere while my seat and camera was bouncing like mad in the cab.

I think I'll go back to FS17 where the gameplay meant more than the graphics.

With games like Euro Truck Simulator 2, Spintires, and previous installments of Farming Simulator out there, I admit expected a lot to compete, but did not expect this little...

I recommend this game because it is very realistic for to real life farming if you choose to play that way! The games multiplayer is great for playing with others for even more fun!! This game is totally worth it!!

I'd never really understood the desire to play a video game about doing work. Car Mechanic Simulator was a fun gimmick, but Farming Simulator? That just sounds ridiculous... and it is.

This game is ridiculously relaxing, rewarding, and enjoyable. There's a lot more than just "farming" too. There's the aspect of building a farm, laying out where buildings will go, organizing tractors, trucks, and tools. There's the whole financial strategy part too; do i buy this tractor, lease it, or continue to use the old basic piece of junk for another harvest or two, and should i plant corn and turn it into silage, or plant soybeans for profit, maybe plant oat and bale the straw afterwards? It's just crazy how much honestly goes on in a simple simulator. And with mods, this game can even become a farm manager game as you send workers out to plow, cultivate, harvest, transport crop, etc.

I love it though. I can work all day, getting stressed and frustrated, but then come home and relax as I just let the tractor drive lines up and down a field planting, or use a harvester to collect crops, and it's just so damn easy to get lost in.

I know a lot of people look at Farming Sim and laugh, but this is honestly one of the best games I've put my time into. I mean, 568 hrs at this point in time... It's worth every penny.

The perfect game to chill out. I have not played previous FS games so my opinion is from someone completely new to the series.

At the beginning you'll get stablished with a piece of land, and some cheap tools. You have to sow your fields, make grow and take care of them, and harvest your profits. With the money you'll eventually get new equipment, and so on, and so on.

It's the perfect game to relax after an stressful day of work at the office, or to disconnect your mind of that important project and his deadline. You only have to put some music/radio/podcast, relax and start to enjoy by working on your fields.

This game as odd as it sounds, it's extremely addictive even when it's EXTREMELY repetitive. You will always have an objective on mind (buy that impressive tractor, take care of your chickens or horses, expand your farm with a great piece of land or do the favor that neighbor is asking for). No matter that you have to work on the same fields over and over again. You feel your crops, your farm (and even your dog) as "yours", and you really have to look after them.

As for the simulation aspect of the game, the machinery is beatifully recreated. With all his working parts that you have to operate (deploy, start, etc.), it's really amazing. You will use the flashing lights on the road, the beacon lights when working on the crops,... the attention to detail and the interior cockpits are great. The physics of the fields are amazingly modelled, when your tractor/tool gets in contact, it's really nicely done. You have to watch your speed or some maneuvers if you don't want to roll your tractor and damage everything. The level of simulation is fully customizable, from an easy experience to a more demanding game. I play with an Xbox One pad although I would love to try some special farming sim peripherals. It supports TrackIr which works as expected.

Unfortunately the visuals, depiste great things like the tractors and tools models, the beautiful (germany) map , and some lighting conditions where the game looks stunning, the overall is that it has some flaws like the drawing distance (even expanding it in the developer options menu), some textures that doesn't look that great and the fact that is not well optimized, although I play it at 1440p with all maxed out at +100fps (i7-8700k, rtx2070,32gb ram), it feels that it still needs some polish or maybe a major graphics engine update. Anyway this goes to the background the moment you get hooked to it.

If you like games like ETS2, PC Building or Car Mechanic Simulators, etc. this game is for you. You decide your level of challenge and game pace. You can use it to wind down from more demanding games (after a tense session of flying or racing sims, this game fits perfectly).

Sometimes the situation has been inverted and I need to switch to more serious games to stop playing this FS'19.

Farming "[i]Simulator[/i]" 19

✔
It doesn't comprehend all of the intricacies of actual farming but nonetheless operating the machines and performing tasks is quite relaxing and fun.
The tractors are satisfactorily animated, in particular the independent suspension and tyre pressure. Overall unfolding the implements and working with them is also entertaining.

There's a lot of different stuff to try out and it provides lots of playtime.

❌
The downsides are the crappy DLCs as well as the fact that it's a bit superficial. It would be nice if the game allowed the players to actually immerse themselves in the farming world by punishing rough driving, requiring the player to hook the implements and trailers, connecting hydraulic lines, air lines, electricals, PTO, etc., plowing, sowing and harvesting in timely manner, etc. ...

Hopefully the sequels in this series will tackle this. It's understandable that it's a huge game.

★
Honorable mention to the modding community. There are a lot of good, useful and fun mods. Especially Seasons 19 which radically affects the game pace and makes it more realistic.

Having no interest in farming it's strange how compelling this game is to play. The fact that you construct your own world to play in, modify it extensively with external mods and then interact with almost everything you make is, perhaps , what makes it fun to play. 

The only let down is the profoundly poor game engine that it runs on. It's poorly optimized with no real atmospherics in the game world and poorly implemented physics and collision detection. Even on a high end system this game struggles to hold 60FPS and frame drops and stuttering are a frequent occurrence. 

Rain and water has no bearing on the game at all, which is weird for a farming game, and nothing gets wet, there is no mud simulation or water visible anywhere. Just an annoying rain fall sound and nothing else. The AI traffic is profoundly stupid  and just gets in the way all the time. The helpers you can hire are almost as stupid.

It's clear that all of the effort has gone into the machinery design and implementation which is excellent (when the physics aren't flipping your tractor upside down for no reason) but this game desperately needs Unreal 5 and some serious work under the hood to beef up the physics and collision detection and the AI and the atmospherics. This game leans to heavily on a mod community adding things to the experience that should already be there, like Follow Me, innumerable building objects, Course Play and so many more. If an unpaid modder can do it, then why can't a professional game company, however small?

This game is very addicting lots of realism, very challenging from a sim manager perspective. It gives you the first person feel with a strategy game feel. Not sure why or how anyone is running in to difficulties running the game, maybe they're attempting to use cracked versions? All together fun, the community is pretty awesome overall I believe the if there were more people playing with that certain dev know how that some of us (me) lack that mods would get even better. Which brings me to my next point the original game developers don't seem to have a problem with modding in fact it appears in some cases they've adapted better versions of user made mods. To summarize, if you like the idea of game that requires putting in a large amount of time for a large reward this is your game. The theme is there, the realities of farming and agriculture, as well as some of the more "recreational" aspects. I can't wait to see whats in store for us in the coming years. I know I'm definitely not the only hoping for big things! Thanks!

Great Game, careful of the mods as some affect the game (we are warned by Giant, so this is not their fault). Steep learning curve at the beginning of the game, like most very deep games. Lots of depth, still some glitches (one of my horses got lost, I left him in the field and found him by accident outside the field when I took another horse riding). I thought this was mods, so removed all and played vanilla, horse was still lost, subsequently found in game, nothing to do with mods. So still slightly "glitchy" (which is again true of almost any huge game with so many elements). I play X4 Foundations and years after release it still has glitches. But like X4 this is highly entertaining and (unlike X4) non violent (which is hard to find in a game today). This game is a real breath of fresh air when most games demand death and destruction as the basic premise. This game is deep, well made, has mods for those who want more, extra maps etc. Absolutely loving the game, highly recommended (even for those who don't think of this genre as being for them, try it you will be surprised (if you allow for the steep learning curve initially, or perhaps I'm slow to learn (it may be me)). Take a look at a great game

What a game! I've played it with all of my gaming friends and once they're in, they're hooked.

I think the biggest improvements over past FS titles are the ability for every member of a server to own and operate their own farm with friends or independently, improved graphics, and addition of new equipment manufactures. The amazing modding community also builds on an already solid foundation and adds hundreds of hours of new and interesting tweaks to the core game experience. 

The ability (with mods) to farm with the same tractor and implements I remember my grandpa using when I was just a kid makes FS19 a priceless addition to my game library. Highly recommended to fellow farm, co-op, and simulation fans.

Awesome!

What can I say about this game? So far I have logged 273 hours. Shouldn't that be enough? It seems like there is no shortage of 'things to do.' Just as soon as you get one task mastered (be it growing crops, making hay or grass bales, raising animals, whatever) you find a different way to make that task more efficient - or even find a totally different thing to do. You can end up filling up your virtual 'days' with an endless amount of farming, constantly upgrading your farming arsenal to more and more powerful machines. (And there are... I don't even know how many trucks, tractors, trailers, and machines to buy. A newbie will be a little overwhelmed by all the stuff that's available.)

The graphics are fantastic - absolutely stunning, and the attention to detail (ie. tire tracks in a freshly-plowed field) are almost unnecessarily realistic. The ambiance (dog barking in background, birds chirping, etc) is enough to lull you into a sleepy daze as you harvest the fields. (The game is not boring at all - very relaxing and VERY chill - so much so that a couple times as I have been knocking down a massive field, I have caught myself dozing off.) There's no rush at all, and no 'goal' - you plan out your day, what you want to accomplish and when, and just... work your butt off, I guess. Despite this very, very chill approach, you don't find yourself losing interest - quite the opposite, you find yourself sitting there thinking, "Ok, after I get this field, I really need to run some loads over to the grain elevator for some extra cash, then I can get my new seeder so I can..." etc.

Yeah, this is not the kind of game you play for a while and then wind up forgetting about. Trust me. You'll be back.

Overall good game, has provided me over 1000 hours of entertainment both on solo play and multi with friends. You will get your moneys worth out of it if you enjoy agriculture at all or always wanted to drive tractors and harvest corn but never could IRL. The game has it's flaws, but what game doesn't. For me, the modding community makes the game, and that's the reason I continue to play. Would it be fun without all the fancy John Deere, Case, and other brands that have been modeled in 3rd party? Probably. But with this being  the 6th installment in the series, and something like GPS in tractors and combines still missing from the vanilla game lineup, it comes up a bit disappointing. I shouldn't have to rely on the modding community to provide things a farming Simulator should include. Not to mention the game engine is in need of an overhaul. The bales act the same way they did when 09 was released. And while logging was a nice touch, better be careful and don't close the grapple too tight, or you'll have 6 meter logs flying everywhere. Those are just a few negatives, there are a whole lot of positives. I play realistically, not arcade style, and some of the physics make it frustrating for me and others to really get into at times. Finesse is the key with stacking pallets or bales. And good luck having the bales stay there and not fidget about. I would REALLY like to see a toggle installed in game, or more customization for Realistic and Arcade. Tractors are not able to go up the side of a cliff, be leaning more than 45 degrees, and not roll over. Granted, it's hard for me to write a review off of "vanilla game," as I haven't played that in years. As stated, the modding community keeps the game alive for me, your results may vary. I have more than gotten my money's worth out of FS19.  Will I buy the next version of the FS franchise and continue to play? Sure, we all will. Anyone who tells you they won't and has played this game in previous versions (FS17, FS 15...) is lying to you. I will however, be a little slow to slap my money on the table if the next version doesn't bring something ground breaking (no pun intended) to the table.
best farming sim to date

As a base game, it's very fun and relaxing... and quite OCD friendly. 

The game certainly has it's limitations on machinery/maps and stuff. But that can be fixed by mods. It's just unfortunate that mods are so heavily dependant on with this game. 

Overall I would still say if you're a "Vanilla" enthusiast give the game a try and if you want you can always add mods. 

The only two majorly bad things I have to say about the game is the AI that you can hire to help you is... buggy at the best of times. Often leaving massive areas of fields unworked. 

And the fact that this game is so heavily dependant on mods and it doesn't have a proper steam workshop like other games do. (They do have a main menu mod area but it only shows mods the developers like not all the new or "cheaty" or OP ones etc. )

Overall Proabably a 6.5/10

I want to give a comprehensive review about this game now that i have 600+ hours on FS19, and have been playing the FS series since 2011 (logging closer to 1500 hours across all FS titles). 

System specs:

Intel i9-9900k overclocked to 5Ghz
ASRock Z390
GSkill Trident Z 32GB
Zotac GeForce RTX 2080 Ti

I think FS19 is a great game, it can provide you many hours of just average fun. Most of my hours were spent on single player saves, while I did try a bit of multiplayer it wasn't for me (details to follow). The more I play this 'game', the more I find things that are glaringly wrong with it or need massive improvements. It is clear that Giants has enjoyed years of relatively uninterupted "farming simulator" gaming market, while there are a few other competitors working on their own farming games, none have really been able to create a dent on Giant's undisputable control over this niche market. 

Let me start with the positives.

1) The modding community is what makes this series successful. For some reason Giants decided to spend a lot of resources on acquiring licenses and modeling more in game content, but why? The amount of time and energy players have spent bringing their own equipment into this game is insane. Sure there are some mods out there that... look like they were textured in MS paint and are really just off putting, others are extremely well done. If it weren't for mods, FS wouldn't be as nearly successful as it is. 

2) There is a decent amount of economics in the game, mostly with the help of the seasons mod. It's cool that there are a plethora of crops in the game, some more unique than others. I don't think many people do cotton, but its neat that its there. Animal management is meh, it's fun to be able to have a relatively self-sustainable operation by using manure / slurry instead of buying fertilizers. 

3) The community for the most part is pretty solid. I mostly spend my time on the FS subreddit where people exchange ideas and ask for tips / help, and I would say most people are really friendly and encouraging to new players.

4) Visual graphics have been improved in FS19 and it shows. I am able to play FS19 on maxed settings, 4k resolution at 120Hz. It isn't a ground breaking graphics improvement, but it at least feels somewhat up to date. Nothing to write home about however.

Here are the negatives.

1) Giants obsession with adding their own licensed content to the game kills other meaningful improvements that the franchise needs. As I mentioned above, modding is this games biggest strength. Thanks to mods like Seasons, vehicle realism, and global company, we're able to have more realistic aspects to FS19. I feel like the "simulator" part of "Farming Simulator" doesn't do any justice - as this feels more like an arcade mobile game now than an actual simulator. Reasons to follow.

2) Lack of soil health! If you play without seasons mod, you can plant soybeans every 'season' and enjoy absurd profit margins, rinse and repeat and you will soon find yourself burned out and not wanting to play. The implementation of weeds in FS19 was a nice intro into this area, but there still needs to be more work. Applying three layers of fertilizers or herbicide and calling your fields protected is hardly realistic and doesn't imply "simulator". 

3) No dynamic texturing or geometry. This might be might biggest complaint about the game. The only time fields look good is when crop is growing, but if you look at a field that you recently work (whether that is plowed, cultivated, seeded, or freshly harvested) you will notice repeated textures every few in-game units. This is very immersion breaking to me. It is just an eye sore especially with big fields! Why not at least let the textures rotate every few units so that they don't all look the same? (Easier said than done, I know). 

In addition to the horrible texturing, ground terrain needs to be able to mold and change based on a variety of impacts. I know that Giants has mentioned that they've tried experiementing with this system but if i recall correctly, they mentioned "it doesn't work for them" or something along those lines. I call bullshit. There are smaller studios with much smaller budgets who got dynamic ground geometry to work for them. It's the single most painful part of this franchise. What is the point of changing tires if the game doesn't take into consideration soil compaction?

4) Finances & economics, also need drastic overhauls. Forget about drawing on loans in this game, you might as well edit your farms.xml and just give yourself money there. Using the ingame loan function, you get a fixed 300% interest rate (i could be wrong about that exact percentage) and you will forever pay principal without ever paying down the loan itself. There is also no such thing as buying used equipment, and leasing is seldom worth it for large equipment (this can be dependent on what type of equipment, how long you use it for, and what you are using it for). Also, the game's price fluctuations are just ambiguous and you don't feel like you have to compete on a market. The other 'farmers' that are on the map make zero impact on prices. Seasons mod helps address this quite a bit.


Synopsis; i enjoy FS. I would probably be farming on my cousins' farm in Denmark if I wasn't allergic to everything. But I feel like this is more of an arcade game than an actual simulator. 

Thanks for reading.

The base game is great, mods make it even better!

Eventually you will hit some challenges or limitations with various tasks. Particularly collection of round bales. Mods will alleviate this greatly.

My favorite map mod is No man's land. - Why?

It's a map where you start bare bones, no contracts, no neighbors and untamed wilderness.

You even have to buy some of your sell points.

The game encourages you start with a farm. I decided sell everything and go all in on a timber company to start. Busy work but excellent Cash per hour.

Considering I climbed straight from timber to corn silage I'd say it worked pretty well.

There are a few ways to play this game that are very different. Explore and find what you like.

Highly recommended.

Overall a pretty fun game, but rough around the edges. Definitely recommend playing multiplayer with someone who has experience if you haven't played previous games. 

The AI is by far my largest complaint. It can drive in a straight line and maybe turn around, but it has absolutely nothing beyond that; if two AI controlled tractors interfere with each other they simply stop and notify the player. Additionally, some of the larger sowers/planters/cultivators/etc will miss large parts of the field if your AI worker ventures anywhere near a boundary such as a road.

Other than that, it seems that running a dedicated multiplayer server requires having a second copy of the game (possibly only purchased from GIANTS website), which just makes me feel like I'm dealing with an old school software licensing company. However, you can still host from the game itself (non-dedicated) and there appears to be an option to rent dedicated servers.

Overall a tentative recommend. The price is pretty low for the amount of content, even if much of it is carried over from previous entries in the series, and the mod support really extended my enjoyment and desire to keep playing past the first 30 hours.

I haven't played any of the prior Farming Simulator games, this is my first. It seems very nice, playable,. good graphics, semi-realistic mechanics, etc. I will say that the game doesn't make it "easy" for beginners. The help menu is good in offering the basics of everything, but lacks detail of how to actually do something. The tutorials could have the option to be more extensive, for example. The equipment could be a bit more understandable to match with other equipment, etc. I just get a feel that the game relied on players already understanding the games mechanics via previous versions and the new players are just left to fend for themselves. I'm not saying the game should be easier, I get it's a simulator, but some more in depth guides in game would help, so I don't have to keep switching the screens to get the info I need that really should be available in the game to start with.

If you are looking for a farm simulator, this is a great one. I believe my interest will be held long enough to learn the game, which is usually a big ask for me.

I have been a big fan of the series since I was a smol boi. Ten years ago, I first started playing the Farming Simulator 2009 in my old pc. I loved every moment of it, it was basic but fun. Then I played every other game that released after it. And now we have the FS19. Firstly, it is as fun and vast as the previous games. Refreshed graphics look good but might be a bit too much for the eyes, new equipment and crops, animals... horses are a great addition to the farming world. The ability to showcase the vehicle before buying is a vital addition in my opinion, since you actually see what you want to buy. Purchasing lands directly from the pause menu also makes the game easier and more mobile. The community mods such as Straw Harvest and Seasons are the cherries on top of the cake.

There are a few irritations in my opinion. There are not enough flat surfaces to place the animal pens, and for the people with severe OCD like me, that means hell. I mess up every time I place those pens. Also, I think Giants needs to move on, since the game engine and the game as a whole feels exactly the same as it did with FS2013, which I played the most.

Apart from that, nothing more to report so far. 8.5/10. Another great FS game, but time to move on.

I've been playing alot for the last few weeks to pass some COVID-19 quarantine time, while stoned. I opened it up around 9 or 10am and began playing around. Before I know it, my girlfriend walks in and asks if I'm thinking about coming to bed at all...it was 1 in the morning!

This game is addicting! I'm always telling myself "ok, one more harvest and I'll turn it off" which turns into me wanting to plow, cultivate, and sow even more! I keep getting caught up with watching workers make perfectly straight lines along long fields of wheat and barley as they harvest. It's just so satisfying to watch. I just want to keep growing my farming empire. I haven't showered in days and I even have dreams about what I want to do, fix, or buy next on my farm.

3. I should be able to see the economic wreck that the lockdown has had on my business and have to dump tons of milk and other produce away.
4. I should be able to mount twin machine guns on my tractors and pay the local village a visit.
5. Sorry about the last one, I've been playing too much "Hatred".

Ok let me just start this by wishing all at giants a safe and healthy lockdown period, and hope to have you all back safe, fighting fit and raring to go...........Right, now down to it, i have played the FS series of games since the first one. I work on a farm in real life, so this game has always been a favourite of mine. If you love farming sims, this game is by far the best that is out there by a long way.....however, i have been slightly annoyed by this game since fs13, firstly Giants decide that AI traffic is invincible, and not even a 10 million billion mega ton nuclear bomb can even budge them off the road. Also the weather system has remained, for the most part the same as it always has been since the early versions, and here we are still with the same old same old. Also the animals have not changed much, ok there are horses now, and the chickens have a rooster, but it makes no difference if you have a rooster or not, they still breed, but at least there is a visual male presence in the chicken coop, unlike the cows, sheep and pigs that seem to just accumulate by magic. If Giants do come out with a FS20, or FS21, then for them to stand any chance of keeping top spot for farming games, then they will need to sort those areas out. I would suggest implimenting seasons, and having a better breeding system for animals in the future versions that come out, if at all there will be any. I would recommend this game as it's always been top of the pile of games to play. Anyway, lets all stay safe, and keep healthy. :)

this game has so much potential. It's such a shame that the ui is complicated, that it's riddled with bugs and that the devs clearly didn't put much thought into making a game that's easily understood, or at least playable to a new player.

The game is honestly amazing in concept- for an advanced player, the game is super realistic and really quite stunning. If you've played farmsim before then i'd recommend it, but before you buy and possibly waste money, please PLEASE understand that you'll constantly have to be consulting google and various forums to work out how to do simple tasks like using herbicide and weeding, for example. Even the core idea of selling your crops for profit has lost me. The very limited tutorial shows you the absolute basics, and without that, i wouldn't disagree with the thought that this game is next to unplayable. It took me about half an hour of actual playing to ragequit over something minor that would have taken seconds had it been explained by the game.

Altogether this is a decent game if you know what you're doing. But honestly, i'm not sure i'll keep persevering unless there's an update with some form of help guide that explains how to play the entire game. I understand people hate tutorials, but with a game this massive, it would be helpful to have one. It can be pretty buggy at points too and in the two or three days i've had this i've needed to restart from scratch as i've either been stuck somewhere or have had vehicles trapped on tools that they were supposed to be grabbing.

tldr, i'm giving it a 4/10. Difficult to use, impossible to learn, but aside from that, pretty visuals and well developed realism.

This game just wasn't for me. I can see the appeal, but I got so frustrated at the fact that I spent 34$ on this (went ahead and got the price reduced DLC version) and was just disappointed. I played for five hours. Five hours of trying to figure out what to do, watching youtube tutorials, googling what to do and where. Then I finally got started farming. And Ho. Ly. Crap. Does this game get boring. And ANNOYING. You want your farm to be nice and pretty looking, straight lines in rows all up and down? Good luck with that. It's hard enough to get your tractor positioned correctly to attach anything to it. You have to buy so many different tractors and pieces of equipment that it's best that you have some ACTUAL heavy equipment experience. That was one of my immediate turn offs, is that most of my first two hours was spent googling and watching tutorials. Whenever I decided to try and play without online help, I ended up buying random things that don't even work like I thought they would. No game should have you feeling this lost. YES, it has a tutorial and even a beginner's level. But as a true beginner with no real life farming experience? Good luck having fun with that if you're like me.

I was unexpectedly surprised with this game, in a good way.  I usually play survival games and was looking for a relaxing alternative.  Most games I've played with a farming component the farming was one of the more boring parts of the game.  After watching a couple videos (and getting a good sale price) I decided to try this.  The farming in other games I've played was just part of the game and dumbed down to avoid being too time consuming.  In this game the farming is the whole point and the developer tries to make it as realistic as possible within programming and hardware restrictions.  

I would strongly urge new players to do the tutorials.  They don't cover everything but provide the major controls for the game and there are a lot of things to control.  You can drive everything from pickup trucks and small tractors to huge harvesters and large trucks.  

This isn't just a farming game, it is also a management game.  Hire workers or not?  What equipment to buy?  What crops to grow?  Want animals?  Which ones?  What do they need to be profitable?  Where to sell crops/animal products for the best price? Expand your farm or wait for more cash flow?

IT's not perfect.  There are some quirks to watch for but nothing game breaking so far at least. I installed the game did the tutorial and started the simplest game mode to get a feel for how things work in the game.  Eight hours later I decided I better get some sleep.

I'm not a big fan of mods in most games.  I see it as just a way to cheat to make the game easier.  With this game modes are almost a must but most involve different brands or types of equipment, buildings, and other maps to use.  Nothing (at least not much) that would make the game easier or remove all the challenge of playing.

There is a bit of a learning curve but if you like farming games or management games you may want to try this one.  I was pleasantly surprised.
