MY ORIGINAL REVIEW \/
I feel really sad and disappointed to be writing this negative review. I was hyped for the game, pre-ordered it and put over 540 hours into FS17. I also own FS15, FS13, and FS11. I even made videos highlighting the awesome new things coming to this game. I can say I was disappointed. If these things get added or fixed, I will be happy. Until then, not impressed.

11/24/2018 This is my first adjustment to this review based on what has been happening in the last few days.

1. Mods are beginning to come out. These mods should have come with the game but they are slowly trickling in. Not all are there that are needed so you might have to wait to see that essential tool you need to play come through.
2. Still no: Greenhouses, beehouses, windmills or any real placeable that can earn passive income
3. Placing placeables where you want them is tricky and not easy at all. It becomes really frustrating especially a game that is trying to highlight it's ability to create your own farm.
4. You are able to "create" farm but you have very few options to pick up sheds, shelters or halls 
5. Hired hands are still bad. In fact, they are worse than 17 to which I thought they were decent with the occassional tree crashing. But now, they will leave the corners and ends of a field not harvested. 
6. Raveport is a map full of squiggly roads that seems to just make you have to drive twisty and super thin roads uphill and downhill to artifically make the game more challenging. 2nd map isn't better because it has the same issues. Roads mostly do not directly lead anywhere as you have to take mutiple turns and side roads to get anywhere useful.
7. Animal pallets like egg crates will NOT appear. I was able to get wool pallets to appear only if no equipment is in close proximity to animal pen.
8. You can't buy multiple pallets/bags of seeds. Seriously! You need to buy one by one and confirm you want to buy it instead of typing how many you want or having a drop down menu and select amount.
9. There is now a penalty for resetting/fast traveling items back to store. You fuel will GO TO almost 0 after teleporting/resetting[! You will have to fill up tank AGAIN which costs up to $300 plus. 
10. Mission reward amounts are super low vs. work and time you put into them
11. They changed the icons for the crops, hay, grass, straw etc. and they are so similar to one another and hard to decipher and they are not named in the prices window. You have to hunt for the icon legend and GO back to verify which icon is which crop they are. Hay, Grass, Straw, Silage and others are hard to tell apart.
12. The controls for the Forestry Cranes have changed and they are strange to say the least, not intuitive at all. I loved forestry and now, decided to sell all the equipment back.
13. No placeable roads to connect locations


I want to update this review in time if these things get fixed because I want to give this game a good review. But I also want to be transparent.


These are just some of the issues in the game. If these are fixed, I'll be excited to play it again. I can't believe the price is $34 and I have to wait for mods to do CORE things in the game. I understand first day bugs will happen but the game seemed more hyped up than anything. Beware!

I bought Farming Simulator 19 on a whim during a midweek sale; I wanted a relaxing simulator and there were few games in my vast library that I knew would fit the criteria. I have little prior experience with farming sims; I played Farming Simulator 13 for around twenty hours, became frustrated with its lack of direction, and ended up dumping it because I had a technical issue that the developers didn't help with on the forum. Thus, I was a little leery of supporting this one.

78 hours of gametime later, I'm in love. Farming Simulator 19 offers you many tutorials and aids to help newcomers learn how to grow crops (of which there are different types of harvesters, sometimes extra steps, etc.) and raise animals. Sometimes it still shows lack of direction--I spent five hours on a starter map looking for the next step in the tutorial. The game wouldn't let me freeplay until finishing it, but it was missing. So I restarted on a freeplay map and figured out everything from scratch. Still, this wasn't overly stressful; the game advances at a relaxing pace to where you have plenty of time to prepare for the next venture (new field, new equipment, new crop/animal, etc.) and research its requirements online. Trial and error is to be expected. Early on, I almost ran out of money because a new field I bought already had sugar beets planted, so I decided to lease all corresponding equipment to harvest it since I couldn't afford to buy it. Leasing everything cost me $23K when the harvest granted $26K in profit. Thankfully all was well, but had I any idea how complicated it would be beforehand, I would have waited for the AI to harvest it before purchasing the lot. The game doesn't warn you when you're about to make stupid decisions, so with each major purchase, you need to do a lot of research!

In fact, Farming Simulator 19 never tells you what to do. It is a true simulation that allows you every freedom. Everything is customizable, even a lot of crucial game options. You can choose whether or not your equipment gets visibly dirty, weeds grow with every harvest, lime and/or periodic plowing is required to maintain yield, and you can even quicken or slow down time. This last point is my favorite because it allows you to play the game at any pace you want, from where 24 hours passes in 12 minutes (120x speed) to where it's based on real-time, so each in-game minute is one real-life minute. I'd often play in real-time until all my chores on my land were done, then do missions from other farmers to make money until there were no more jobs I wanted to do (Hint: harvesting jobs make the best profit, for you get the job money and a percentage of the harvest income). Then, "fast forward" until other fields develop, do more missions, etc. In this way, you can manipulate the world to where you can maximize the amount of money you make in a day to further protect you from bankruptcy. Because you can hire helpers to do many jobs for you, you can focus on doing those you like best (say, harvesting) while getting the AI to do the others. All of these jobs can be happening simultaneously. As long as you have the equipment and time, you can be working the land all over the map at once with aid from workers.

I grew up on a ranch, and out of all the pets I've ever had (more than two dozen species), chickens were by far the most fun. Farming Simulator 19 is one of the few games that allows me to experience just a bit of that joy as an adult living in the suburbs, and I'm grateful to it. You can also raise horses, sheep, cows, and pigs, though you can only name horses. I would have loved the option to name all animals to give it a more personal touch. Additionally, I hope in the future Giants Software considers building upon the helper system. It's great to have helpers, but they don't have names and aren't hired for good. I think it'd be nice for Farming Simulator to go the way of SCS Software's Truck Simulator series (Euro and American), to where you could hire and manage actual employees, even assigning certain jobs for them to do automatically. The only other request I'd have is for more crops and corresponding equipment. I'd love to tend to orchards or even just grow something more exciting than the roster of grains (and few others like potatoes, sugar beets).

In summary, Farming Simulator 19 is a perfect gateway into farming sims for players looking to start. You can play your way: actively, by tending to every task yourself and fast-forwarding through growth phases, or passively, by assigning AI to tasks and slowing time down to a crawl. If you love tending to and building a business in a relaxing atmosphere, Farming Simulator 19 is one of the few games that captures that unique feeling. This game sits next to those in the Truck Simulator franchise as one of my go-to relaxing simulators. I look forward to seeing Giants Software continue to innovate and grow the series.

I had never played any of the previous farming sim titles but decided to give this one a try, especially as I had recently built a racing setup and heard that Farm Sim 19 was wheel and pedal compatible. I was not impressed by the wheel and pedal support (no force feedback and poor control mapping), however I had quite a bit of fun with the game itself. It has a special appeal with friends to get in there and just get some farming done. The map we played on was neat, with a bunch of little easter eggs and was fun to bomb around in our trucks and explore. I do feel, however, that a lot of obvious features are missing from the game, some that are added via mods, however I almost feel like the developers lean on the modding community a little bit too much. I don't really know anything about farming outside of experience with this game, so the DLC doesn't really mean much to me but it seems a little overpriced. I would definitely recommend getting this game on sale if it piques your interest.

Edit:  On it's own, without mods I still give this game about a 5/10. It has certainly improved, but the maps aren't very fun, and not enough has been improved from 17 for this to be a true standalone evolution of the series in my opinion. However, with mods, this game is makes 17 obsolete as Seasons is vastly more intricate, and my favorite maps from 17, including goldcrest valley and lone oak farm are now available as official mods. So, thanks to the modding community alone, this is a rival to 17. Without mods, 17 was much better. I played 17 for almost 600 hours before I modded the game.

This isn't a game for everyone but if it's on sale, I highly recommend giving it a try. It's a great game to chill and/or relax too. There's a bit of a learning curve but there are many youtube guides to help with that. There are MANY mods to change up the gameplay. Usually nothing broken, just alot of quality of life options or more brands and models of vehicles and equipment. The mods are very well done and I've had no issues with crashing. Also, if the game is too much simulator and too little game, it has a whole bunch of options to adjust the difficulty/realism. From how brutal the economy effects you when you go to sell, to whether or not you have to plow or Lime your fields. You can also turn these settings on or off at any time so there's no pressure. The game is set up in a very "Play it how you like" kind of way.

Pro (Enhancements over 2017):
-Cotton
-Oats
-Dog
-Horses
-Field birds
-Landscape editor
-Slightly better graphics
-Buy land instead of fields
-More realistic steering (overall better. Steering for the wheel loader is superior, but steering for conveyor is bad)

Con:
-Slightly more buggy
-No longer have in game vehicle sales events
-The landscape editor breaks game immersion
-Chainsaw does not work as well as 2017 for cutting branches
-No reputation system. In 2017, if you did tasks for a farmer, then you could get a better price for their land.
-Train is less useful. Train automatically runs around the tracks, thus have to constantly move it back to where it is needed. You must be in the train for loading and unloading -- if you exit, then the operation will stop. 
-Still uses magic seeds instead of crop specific seeds.
-Giants editor is more complicated -- may discourage mod creation.

Overall better than Farming Simulator 2017, but you are loosing some 2017 features (vehicle sales, a reputation system, better trains).

Oh boy, where to begin. i have 200+ hours in this game, and for good reason. Farming Sim is one of those games where after a long day you can sit down an chill with some music while you play. Whether you're planting soybeans or harvesting your wheat, this game is relaxing, and fun. The loop of planting->fertilizing->harvesting over and over to buy new machines and land is a great game base in my opinion.

Now onto some of the downsides. There is one big issue I have with farming sim, and I hope they fix it in later releases. Graphics. This game's graphics look like their from 2015. The render distance is also bad, as even just barely zoomed out you can see the circle around you of what has been processed. I really hope that Giant takes their time with the next game, and improves the graphics. While this is annoying, I can look past it given the game is fun, and I enjoy it.

Essentially, yes, I would recommend this game to a friend.

the horse training needs to be done manualy as the constructed elecrtic horse walker can not be used for its intent, the movements and jumping are done in slow motion and turning is unrealictic,.   but first most notcibale is the hud text colour is white on the white sky background cant see the time or finaces or weather icons, tnx a lot,.   with all the talk of better grafics improvement from FS17 the volumetric fog still exists and making everting look like BLEH, nt very pleasant playing in grey colours,  .   most mods are incompatible tih the new format making the most usefull scripts of "follow me," "AI Combine/tractor drive"  unoperational on a lot of base inbuild equiments,.   speaking of wich, what i find the most aggravating in this gamer so far is, when its time to reset vehicle becouse it got stuck in the invisible dimple in grass, it cant be selected indivudally as the ingame menu map view has removed the equipment selection and so forcing us to vew the map selecting each dot at time to find the 1 thing u want to reset, and becouse when zoomed out to view full map all the dots dissapear and again another unpleasant point to it, we have to keep scrolling the map inch by inch for that equipment search, besides which some of the dots overlap and at max zoom can not be selected, so have to reset the neighboring dot as wel even ifts have a full fill level and loose all that fill,  And my latest discovery the so called "autosave "  funstion is totaly useless and worthless as it only save when u visit the menu even thou it has point to saev at intervals, it does nothing,  and some people go thru long duration mission and don't bother to stop to visit menu and do required  save,  and if god forbid anything happens to close game in mid progress , you will loose it all and have to start from scratch. what genuis had programmed that? I have 14h of this game so far, while the concept is really good and could be fun, developers seem to enjoy making your life
difficult somehow. First of all the game lacks information by a lot, I understand part of the fun is to figure out how the machines work and how to use them, but I don't understand the point of not having any information at all and having to dig out everything from google. Secondly the game play I consider to be one of the worst experiences I have ever had in a game, most of game is driving around and handling machines, transporting stuff with trailers is just ridiculous, I see no point on getting stuck with the trailer on a postbox or a electric pole, or to loose visibility of the vehicle because trees are everywhere. Driving vehicles on the cockpit is unplayable and impossible to handle with a trailer, there wasn't any attention to gameplay when this was developed and no improvements after release either.
My main note is, could be a very fun game to play if they had put more time into making the gameplay better and also if devs had spent more time putting information available. Also the game is still quite buggy at this stage.

I wouldn't spend the money if I knew what I know now.

Although there is a newer version release about every 2 years, the modding community here is huge and keeps the game very dynamic even after the developers have moved on.  With each new release there seems to be a shift of focus, be it geographical, brand specific, or crop/animal specific. At times even announcing a new company getting on board with licensing (John Deere was a HUGE step) very enjoyable. can be made not too dissimilar from real farming, but a lot less dust, bloody knuckles, and breakdowns,

No other farming game will ever compare to farming simulator. The game is truly immersive in several realistic ways and keeps you wanting to play for hours on end. The fan base is incredible between making mods and making youtube videos. You don't need to be a farmer or even enjoy farming to play this game, it will suck you in for hours without you ever realizing. I cant wait for farming simulator 21. I can only imagine the realism coming with next gen.

I bought Farming Simulator 19 on a whim during a midweek sale; I wanted a relaxing simulator and there were few games in my vast library that I knew would fit the criteria. I have little prior experience with farming sims; I played Farming Simulator 13 for around twenty hours, became frustrated with its lack of direction, and ended up dumping it because I had a technical issue that the developers didn't help with on the forum. Thus, I was a little leery of supporting this one.

78 hours of gametime later, I'm in love. Farming Simulator 19 offers you many tutorials and aids to help newcomers learn how to grow crops (of which there are different types of harvesters, sometimes extra steps, etc.) and raise animals. Sometimes it still shows lack of direction--I spent five hours on a starter map looking for the next step in the tutorial. The game wouldn't let me freeplay until finishing it, but it was missing. So I restarted on a freeplay map and figured out everything from scratch. Still, this wasn't overly stressful; the game advances at a relaxing pace to where you have plenty of time to prepare for the next venture (new field, new equipment, new crop/animal, etc.) and research its requirements online. Trial and error is to be expected. Early on, I almost ran out of money because a new field I bought already had sugar beets planted, so I decided to lease all corresponding equipment to harvest it since I couldn't afford to buy it. Leasing everything cost me $23K when the harvest granted $26K in profit. Thankfully all was well, but had I any idea how complicated it would be beforehand, I would have waited for the AI to harvest it before purchasing the lot. The game doesn't warn you when you're about to make stupid decisions, so with each major purchase, you need to do a lot of research!

In fact, Farming Simulator 19 [i]never[/i] tells you what to do. It is a true simulation that allows you every freedom. Everything is customizable, even a lot of crucial game options. You can choose whether or not your equipment gets visibly dirty, weeds grow with every harvest, lime and/or periodic plowing is required to maintain yield, and you can even quicken or slow down time. This last point is my favorite because it allows you to play the game at any pace you want, from where 24 hours passes in 12 minutes (120x speed) to where it's based on real-time, so each in-game minute is one real-life minute. I'd often play in real-time until all my chores on my land were done, then do missions from other farmers to make money until there were no more jobs I wanted to do (Hint: harvesting jobs make the best profit, for you get the job money and a percentage of the harvest income). Then, "fast forward" until other fields develop, do more missions, etc. In this way, you can manipulate the world to where you can maximize the amount of money you make in a day to further protect you from bankruptcy. Because you can hire helpers to do many jobs for you, you can focus on doing those you like best (say, harvesting) while getting the AI to do the others. All of these jobs can be happening simultaneously. As long as you have the equipment and time, you can be working the land all over the map at once with aid from workers.

I grew up on a ranch, and out of all the pets I've ever had (more than two dozen species), chickens were by far the most fun. Farming Simulator 19 is one of the few games that allows me to experience just a bit of that joy as an adult living in the suburbs, and I'm grateful to it. You can also raise horses, sheep, cows, and pigs, though you can only name horses. I would have loved the option to name all animals to give it a more personal touch. Additionally, I hope in the future Giants Software considers building upon the helper system. It's great to have helpers, but they don't have names and aren't hired for good. I think it'd be nice for Farming Simulator to go the way of SCS Software's Truck Simulator series (Euro and American), to where you could hire and manage actual employees, even assigning certain jobs for them to do automatically. The only other request I'd have is for more crops and corresponding equipment. I'd love to tend to orchards or even just grow something more exciting than the roster of grains (and few others like potatoes, sugar beets).

In summary, Farming Simulator 19 is a perfect gateway into farming sims for players looking to start. You can play your way: actively, by tending to every task yourself and fast-forwarding through growth phases, or passively, by assigning AI to tasks and slowing time down to a crawl. If you love tending to and building a business in a relaxing atmosphere, Farming Simulator 19 is one of the few games that captures that unique feeling. This game sits next to those in the Truck Simulator franchise as one of my go-to relaxing simulators. I look forward to seeing Giants Software continue to innovate and grow the series.

EDIT: I've added some things that I find annoying about this game that really detract from its value. Please take that into consideration.

I've been a "fan" of the farming sim genre for a while now. I got really hooked on Farm Simulator 2013 -- I probably put 200 hours into that game, which was way more than I anticipated.  I tried again with '14, '15, '17 and now '19 but so far nothing has recaptured that feel for me yet. 

I'm not even into the game that far yet, but I can recognize they've added a bunch of options and made it much more customizable. For one thing, you have a lot of options for crops to raise.  Back in '13 it was wheat, barley, canola, corn, potatos, and beets, and oh yeah, you could just let the fields grow grass and cut that for hay bales.  This game has a lot more options for crops -- 13 different crops including grain, root crops (potatoes etc), cotton, sugarcane, and sunflowers.

There's also a lumber side-gig you can do where you chop trees down (with machinery) to sell to a lumber yard.  I don't know if that's really going to be something I'll want to do since to me the idea of waiting for a tree to grow so I can cut it down and sell it for profit sounds like a boring job.  If you're talking about a forest then it's different.

The types of animals you can have has also increased from just "Chickens, sheep, and cows" in '13 to chickens, cows, horses, pigs, and sheep, as well as additions to you can do with them.  Before it was just eggs, milk and wool... oh and manure for slurry/fertilizing.   I don't yet know if this is a good change, and as I figure it out I'll edit this review. 

Of course they've added a bunch of different machinery types, so you can feel all manly driving a multitude of different tractors and other vehicles, but they also gave you options for buying vs leasing (which is actually more like renting).  If there's a vehicle you only need rarely, you could just lease it and then return it when you're done instead of spending the large amount of cash for something you barely use.

Another change is that they've added the ability to buy and place your own farmhouse.  In the original game you had one farmhouse with a small nearby field, and then you slowly bought up all the other land plots around you to increase your farm's size.  Now you could potentially buy/build a new house for every field if you wanted. 

There's also mods supported much like every Farm sim game ever (at least as far as I know) and you can play this online with friends.  In fact I'd go as far as to say that playing it online is probably the best way to go, since offline single-player feels like you're the only person in town.  There are AI cars that drive around, but they really don't do anything more than provide scenery and obstacles for you as you drive from point A to point B.

Unlike older games in the series, there's very little online documentation about this game unless you like watching youtube videos that take 26 minutes to get to the point you're wondering about.  I prefer a nice manual or at the bare minimum, a wiki that I can consult for help.  The in-game help is just about useless by telling you almost nothing about each category, so without a wiki or a manual you're going to be running to the steam forums to find the answers.  The really bad thing is that nobody finds out the answers without a lot of trial and error and in some cases, LOTS of errors.  How hard is it to make a dang manual Giants?

The older games also had some kind of extra side-quest type stuff that encouraged you to fully explore the map.  In 2013 there was a bunch of horseshoes littering the countryside (but no horses strangely enough) and if you found enough horseshoes it would trigger an event.  One of the later games (2015 maybe?) had you looking for actual gold bars lying around.  I had an easier time believing that someone might leave horseshoes lying around, but both served the same purpose: find them for an achievement and maybe to trigger some event.  So far as I can tell in 2019 this doesn't happen.   

It was kind of a pointless easter egg hunt in the earlier games so maybe they decided that few people really cared about it and removed it.  I liked it because it gave me a reason to wander around the map on foot while I waited for my crops to grow.   I could easily have just cranked the time compression up to max and then back down to real-time to harvest, but that was equally boring since I just wound up staying there watching the crops grow.  

Overall though, I don't find this game as interesting as the first game I played.  I don't know if that's because I already burned out on the idea of being a video game farmer, or if it's just that the game mechanics are kinda dry and repetitive.  This is a game I'd give a "meh" thumb to if I could.   It's not worth investing hundreds of hours into without friends who are also into the game, but it's not so terrible that I'd warn someone off of it entirely.

I'm starting to think at this point that you'd be better off getting FS 2017 and then modding it up to 2019 standards.  I've had the game crash on me a couple of times out of nowhere (just randomly as far as I can tell. I can't reproduce the error anyway) and I've purchased an item that sells in the store as a planter only to find out it can only be loaded with dry fertilizer).  

My advice would be to try one of the earlier incarnations of this game that are much simpler in scope like Farm Simulator 2013, and if you like that one, you might also want this one for the expanded options.  The thumbs up is basically because I don't hate it...but I haven't really yet come to love it either.  Your mileage may vary.  If you enjoy building your own farm and paying back a loan then maybe you'll find it engaging enough -- That was one of the original aspects of the game that I enjoyed.

What to say. It's farming simulator. If you are interested in farming and machinery and if you don't find repetitive gameplay boring you will find this fun. THIS IS NOT HARDCORE SIM. I know it say "Simulator" but it really isn't. It wouldn't be this popular if it has 100% realistic game mechanics. For example, you dont need to worry about 100 different types of seed or fertilizer or super detailed soil management. You just get a cultivator or a sower and you drive across the field. One MAJOR pro is that modding is REAL. Like Skyrim levels of real. There is so many mods, even those supported by GIANTS themselves. Modding is what makes farm sim games great in general. And its all free! There are few DLC's if you want to buy them as they are quite nice but not necessary at all as you can get similar things from mods altho official models tend to be of higher quality. TEND to be because these day mods are of very high quality as well.

Honestly, I can't see why this game has the positive reviews it has. Not a lot has changed since 17, and the graphics aren't really that much better. The devs have stripped content out, greenhouses are gone, passive income buildings such as solar panels and wind turbines have gone. Granted these things don't necessarily make the game, but they were nice to have.

The modding community added to FS17 what the developers have missed, and clearly they have not learned from this, as a lot of these things still have not been added to the game.

My biggest irritation is that forklifts still operate as if the forks have grease on them and the objects have zero mass to them, after several attempts to try and load a pallet I was ready to give the game up there and then. I didn't even get on to logging but have been informed it as still as frustrating to try and move things about as it was in 17.

To me, the devs have just took FS17, upped the graphics slightly, made a new map, and added some mediocre extra content, like adding lime to fields, and released it. If you have FS17 in you library, you may as well just stick to playing that.

If you are looking for the best farming sim on the market, look no further. What it may lack in graphics (mainly trees, but this might be a personal gripe) it makes up for with its versatility and community. Here are a few plus sides they might not tell you. 

Modifications:
You name it, chances are, there's a mod for it- that is- if it's not already in the game. These mods include everything from machinery, to maps, and the game mechanics themselves. They're easy to install thanks to an accessible folder that comes DEFAULT with the game. There are plenty of websites to get mods on, and even a mod hub in the game itself. 

Experience:
The Farming Simulator franchise has been around for a while. They know what they are doing. With many DLC for purchase, and the default vehicles and mechanics, you are getting a lot of bang for your buck. 

Multiplayer:
Go out and run a farm with your friends! They make it easy and fun for you to do this, and there's always plenty of people online.

Joystick Compatibility:
Do you have 2 joysticks, a steering wheel, and a pedal that you want to use with this game? Use them all at the same time and customize all the controls with ease.

That's all I really have to say. I think it's a great game with plenty to do. As of writing this, I have 300 hrs. in this, and I haven't truly gotten bored once. Happy farming!
Nice farming game have playe this starting with farming simulator 2015 and still play gets better with every new one.

I think this is the first Farming Simulator that I don't recommend. I keep the right to change my opinion once I invest a couple of hundred hours into it... Let's wait and see.

[h1]So - why "Not recommended"?[/h1]

Once again, Giants have just re-packaged their game. This is FS17 with two new maps, a bit re-shaded graphics and minimal gameplay enhancements. Add a few FS17 DLCs into the base game and you get FS19.

Yes, it looks nicer than FS17 if you have the graphics set to max, but my i7 7700/GTX1060 laptop can't handle them. So, to get the smooth FPS, I have to play on mid settings - and they look horrible. Way worse than FS17.

Price is also over the top (for what they are offering). Giants are just milking this cash-cow at the moment. Buy yourself FS17 or some DLCs for it - way better value for money.

I already felt cheated when I bought FS17, but now I'm just dissapointed. This is the last time I buy the actual FS. From now on, I'll just play the one that's a generation old.

[h1]Edit 1 @ 33 hours:[/h1]
I'm not sure what grass Giants were consuming when they wrote the minimum specs - 4GB RAM. ??? It seems this game is a memory hog; I could barely run mid settings with 8GB. I have now upgraded to 16GB, and am delighted to report that I can run the game on High settings. (Still, nothing to write home about... it still feels like FS17 with a bit of a shader applied.) I still think you should save your money and play FS17.

[h1]Edit 2 @ 470 hours:[/h1]
Well, yeah, I'm playing it seeing that I already own it. Since my last edit, there was a couple of DLC releases... Only one worth the money though - the John Deere DLC. The platinum expansion was a fiasco - not even a map included in it. No thanks Giants. I'll pass.

This is a good game with minor bugs, poor tutorial and it s bad at not prompting or warning you that some actions create large problems. Your best help is watching videos of other people who test and make tutorials for the community as there is not much written up by the devs. My largest problem is I am unable to get friends to play with me because Giants expects you to buy an extra copy of the game and all expansions to run a dedicated server. I run 7 dedicated servers for my gaming group on my private server. I have never purchased extra games to do this in 20 years of server hosting. I was hoping to get everyone in but I do not plan to pay $100 US extra for a game and expansions to play with my friends. Also there is multiplayer but after a couple of people connecting it gets a bit laggy thus the reason I run a powerful server for everyone to game on. So of the 11 people looking to hop in and try only 4 of us have the game and they are not interested anymore after finding that out. If I had known this ahead of time I would not have bothered buying the game. Lesson learned. I am hoping others like myself looking to get into Farm Sims read this and know all of this ahead of time.

I regretfully have to give this game a bad review.  It does have some great upgrades from its previous versions but the implementation was done quite poorly.  Some of the DLC's (Platnium Expansion) did not add any additional features to the gameplay; all it added was more equipment and its prices at $20.  
This game needed more refinements before it should have been released but for the most part they have been flushed out.  Some of the game representatives have also been less than par (to put it mildly) with their attitudes with us.  I do believe that this company could stand to go back to and take some customer service refresher classes.

The game is in an O.K. state now but Giants reputation with me has been severely damaged with me and I have lost a lot of faith in them for producing a knockout game.  Based on their continuing choices I doubt that will change anytime soon.

I like big machines, and building my own empire/business/world. 
This game is enjoyable, relaxing, and feels good to play.
The biggest two things though, are 
1. having a server with friends. With 2-3 buddies, you help each other out and compete to make your land the way you want it, but when harvest time comes, its all hands on deck, everyone helping each other out.
2. mods. there are so many FANTASTIC mods for this game. On a server with some buddies we use about 210 mods to keep it simple. I run over 400 usually in single player.
The community is wonderful, and there is so much to do!

Have not played long enough to make a full review but right away it's engaging and incredibly annoying. If a drop of water equals a bug there is an ocean within this game. It takes hours to remove trees with the various equipment available. Everything becomes stuck on the tree or the tree becomes stuck with the ground .... its pathetic that there are 19 tries to get this game right and they are not even close to it. Lazy ass devs the screw people out of their money imo.  I expected a far more complex physics system: tires should dig into dirt and leave better impressions; metal should denature if stressed; plants should lay flat if run over by x tons of weight, a minimum amount of construction equipment should be used to landscape rather than a terrain editor (although I would not scrap the editor), chain saws should cut where the user chooses to in place of the "snap to area" mechanic etc. If Giant would fuck off and allow a group with good intentions to buy the project it would be a great game instead of hot garbage.

There is something cathartic about immersing myself in this virtual world of farming. What makes the game especially cool is the level of detail found in the mods that are available. The simplicity of animal husbandry and the ease with which row cropping is done makes for a very relaxing activity while listening to a podcast or even taking part in a conference call. The world of simulators and the access to a growing library of maps and equipment mods have made it so that players can choose to be as realistic or unrealistic as they please. Along with the invention of course-play, seasons, seasons: geo, the massively popular, global company script, among others... FS19, regardless of the map being played on, is completely unique for every player. From role playing in the game to playing the simulator as a simulator, there is no end of things to do as you build and modify the world you inhabit. FS19 is a fantastic, wildly immersive experience that you can get absolutely engrossed in.  Whether you are into the world of farming and all it entails or just a fan of simulators, I highly recommend checking out Farming Simulator 19.

At first, I got FS17 on my Xbox one without knowing anything about the game. I only played a little bit and then gave up. A while later I decided to try it out, and I enjoyed it. I hopped on my PC to look at the price for FS19, and decided to buy it. I don't regret that decision. It's my favorite game, however, you will need extra storage for mods. It's fun on its own, but with mods, it makes it 10x better, maybe even 20x better. You don't need too much to run it, and for me it runs AMAZING. I have almost 700 mods, which is around 70 gb in total. There are maps, vehicles, and more mods you can download. It has amazing mod support. My favorite site to get mods at is https://mod-network.com/mods/farming-simulator-19/1 There are way more sites than this, and Facebook groups. There are unlimited mods! Definitely pick this game up, you won't be dissappointed!

Seems like a pretty fun game, but I wouldn't know given I ragequit after wasting several hours just trying to get the multiplayer to work. I got it specifically to play co-op with my girlfriend, but there's just one problem: the neurotic level of DRM.

FS19 is the ONLY modern multiplayer game that I have ever played that doesn't even support playing over LAN. On top of this, the expectation is that for a dedicated server, you either have to buy another copy of the game for hosting purposes, or you use an official server and pay a monthly fee. What kind of garbage business model is that? I even tried searching Google for help setting up multiplayer and even though my search terms were innocuous, about half of the results were piracy and game cracking sites. Wtf. Though, I suppose now I understand why.

If you only want to go for the singleplayer, I suppose it's a good game. However, do your research before attempting multiplayer, and if it doesn't seem worth the trouble, don't bother wasting your money.

---

WORST GAME EVER! The idea of these games are brilliant and the effort put into the machinery, the animals and the logistics are astounding. But then they completely ruin the game by having a very poor worker system. You can only hire workers when you are at the field of choice. Which is nice. EXCEPT! because of this you pretty much just spend hours driving the tractors back and forth or your trucks back and forth to sell your grain. They really need to implement a system where you can manage the game without personally driving, so maybe like workers can drive to fields and stores, and your grain can be sold on farm at a reduced price instead of having to transport it everytime. And because they dont have this the entire game is pretty much just driving around tractors which gets boring after a few hours. The real fun comes into managing your farm, making money and growing your business. But its impossible to do so when you gotta focus all your efforts on driving the tractors to each crop or sell point. 
I remember playing John Deers American Farmer back in 2004 that had these capabilities. How can a game that is from 2019 fail to implement it?? I really wish I didn't spend the money on this...

This has been the best farming simulator in the farming simulator series so far! The graphics are outstandingly better in this game than in the previous versions. The physics in this game are also much better, with bales being a lot easier to handle. Workers are smarter and better, and there is a wider range of vehicles with well designed interiors and amazing details, like hydraulic lines attaching when you attach something with auxiliary hydraulics. Over all it is much better than the other versions of this game and I highly recommend it. Beware that to run this game on the most beautiful settings you will need a somewhat beefy computer.

This was my first game of the series and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for the farming experience.  There are so many different activities you can do and everything looks great.  I harvest wheat and corn in the real world and I was introduced to equipment through the game that I did not know existed.  This is a very in depth simulator and sometimes tutorials are a must.  All of the major equipment brands are here and the customization is appreciated.  There are also plenty of mods from the website to add more creativity to your game.

When FS17 came out, I thought, come on, really... who wants to play a farming simulator?

Then FS19 came out and I noticed it was on console. But I still didn't bite. Finally at $14.99 I bought the game.

Here's the thing. European developers are really good at niche sim games, and this one is right up there with Euro Truck Simulator 2. The game is hard, but once you start to get the hang of it, it kinda creates a vacuum. My first 5 save files went bankrupt because I had no idea what I was doing, and the tutorials will do little to help if you don't understand basic farming. But everything from the graphics, to the machines, to the audio. It's a really good simulation and really easy to get addicted to.

I love the series, has been a lot of fun and time spent on all the games.  However, they get old VERY quickly on single player.  The single player aspect is what I love about the game with the occasional multiplayer experience.  That being said, this is where the game is lacking heavily.  

Without fundamental AI improvements, and in Single player being able to become a "farm manager" of sorts, its basically worthless to try and have a farm of more than 5 or so fields to work.  It becomes IMPOSSIBLE to manage a farm of any large scale due to a crushing AI experience.  The workers do function better in 19 than any other series, however to have the ability to park them in a shed and say 'Go to field 19 and do...x, y, z" would seriously enhance the single player experience.  

Until this is done, this will be my last Farming Simulator game.  It becomes extremely tedious and redundant.

Multiplayer is hit and miss, which can be a blast with the right people.  However there are a lot of trolls in the game and they just try to break the farms.  Or you feel like you're doing all sorts of work for someone else.

Overall Im just done with the game until the single player experience can become manageable.

Many, MANY hours on this game. I've also played FS17, and 15. All wonderful games, and I love how each title (although fairly expensive) is basically just an update to the same "platform." All of them use the same basic build, and everything (GUI, physics, etc.) is all relatively the similar. However, Farming Simulator 19 has definitely been the best. Amazing graphics, easy to use menus, and relatively simple, straight forward gameplay. Only a few things I can say other than amazing. Lacks a realistic transmission setup with gearing, which is really only an issue if you're extremely into detail. Other biggest issue for me personally (maybe others) is that, as I said, it's an extremely basic game without mods. Farming is it. Until you get mods. Mods are nearly required for this game, especially if you're into that kind of thing. Lastly, if you have too many things (machines, tractors, cars..) it lags BAD, which is to be expected, and can only be fixed through better PC specs (so fair warning). Other than that, wonderful game. Would totally recommend for anyone, so long as you have the ability to install mods.

I have bought this game twice. Once for Xbox One and once on Steam. I used to be one of the gamers that saw it in the store and outright laughed, "who would ever want to buy that game?". Well...I bought FS17 when it was on a super sale...and now I am hooked. I've put well over 500 hours into FS19 between both of my systems (I play what I want, where I want, when I want) and I'll keep it in my regular game rotation until FS21 comes out.
I love the fact that I can get lost in a map. Working the fields, taking care of the animals, playing around with some amazing machinery...it seems slow paced, but your list of things to do is never ending and the day is over (in game and IRL) before you realize it. 
I've even done research to figure out what some of the things in game are, how they're used and when they're used. I grew up in a rural farming area, never really caring what the farmers are up to. Nowadays, while visiting, I'm trying to see what tractors and implements they're using.
FS19 may not be for everyone, but I suspect that it is a gem that many gamers would love as much as I do. If only they'd give it a chance and dive in.

2020-01-17 REVIEW:
A lot better than it was at release, but still lacks basic quality of life improvements. My last straw: I accidentally swiped with the landscaping tool and no undo option is available. When I opened the menu to quit, the game auto-saved. I deleted the save game then uninstalled FS19.


OLD REVIEW:
This game is buggier than I would have hoped for from a big studio release.


1 - When trying to unload a harvester into a trailer, it doesn't recognize the main body as a dump zone, but might catch the very edge of the truck as acceptable. The result is it's very hard to unload, and if it does, it's unloading outside of the trailer.

2 - I just accepted 3 missions, leasing the equipment. A popup shows up saying that the equipment at the store. The equipment is not at the store, and I don't have any missions. I just accepted three in a row (you can only have one at a time).

3 - I drove over a train safety railing and got stuck. After the train passed, the railing lifted the harvester into the air. Quite unrealistic. I had to use a trailer to ram it down.

4 - The lighting is very flickery, even on my 1080 Titan,

5 - "Helper B has stopped unexpectedly - for an unknown reason" - Reason: Invisisble rocks on fairly flat ground between fields 25 and 26

6 - "Icons - Part 2" in the help doesn't have a #5, but instead shows #9 twice.

7 - The game should be called "Transport & Delivery Simulator 2019". I can hire workers for the farming tasks, but not for driving/transport/delivery. Therefore, I spend the vast majority of my time driving, not farming. I don't care for this. I wish it was like the mobile 2018 game, where I can order a vehicle to drive to B, or unload and return from site C, or auto-refill tanks, etc.

8 - I want the camera position to be remembered between play sessions, not just between vehicle cycles. As it is, I have to start every game session with gobs of scrolling out. This will only get more and more tedious with the more vehicles I purchase.

9 - The vehicles are super bouncy. It's very easy to tip them over. I recently spent a half hour getting a mission-leased semi unstuck from a tree by ramming it with a tractor, which itself flipped over twice in the process. This, combined with driving from A to B, was the vast majority of my play tonight. No bueno. I'd love a simply "Flip me right-side up" button.
9.1 - Update: It's getting very frustrating, during my forced transports (no auto-pilot), I'll bump a tree, or a sign, or a trash can, or a car, or a rock, and my tractor and trailor flip. Then I have to spend the next 15 mins+ getting another tractor there to ram me right side up (which did 5 mid-air barrel rolls before getting flipped itself after taking a sharp turn). This is a transport and tractor flipping game. I do very little farming. I am aware I can "Reset" tractors from the map, however, you penalize me hundreds (if not thousands) in cargo/fuel. That is unnecessary and uncalled for. Very frsutrating.

10 - I wish all of the icons would say what they are when I mouse over them.

11 - Looking at my Owned Items in the Garage, I expect the pictures to look like the tractor I have, not the stock, unmodified tractor (ie. one of my tractors has 8 wheels, but the photo of it in my garage only has 4)

12 - Again in the Garage, I'd love to see the tractors/vehicles coupled with the accessories/trailors they have currently equiped. This'd help me identify which one of many I am looking at, as well as which accessory. For example, if I want to sell one front-weight, which of my dozen do I need to sell? Or, which of my 8 green tractors is the one I want to identify?

13 - Why can't I use a helper to fertilize or lime?

14 - I'd like to have am/pm times for the clock. Not just military time.

15 - Let me sleep during the day. The only purpose of the house, otherwise, is to speed time only at night, which makes it much more tempting to just sell the house and pocket 175k.

16 - Can we get a x240, or even a x480, time speed? When I've nothing to do but watch as crops go from planted to grown, it still takes quite a while, even on x120.

17 - If I run into a car with my tractor/trailor, I go flying, and the car doesn't budge. I should be able to shove them out of the way...

18 - Why don't you post patch notes? I believe you've updated a few times since launch, yet no patch notes. Without knowing what you've fixed, I'm forced to assume nothing. Not communicating didn't work out for No Man's Sky...

I'm sure I'll run into more issues, and I hope Giants fixes these release bugs asap.

I keep trying hard to like it, I really do, but no matter how "modern" and "improved" the Farming Simulator iteration is, it keeps feeling a 10 year-old game to me.
Improved graphics ? Really ? wow, I am sure for the year 2000 these "improved" graphics would be terrific, in 2020 ...not really, no, not even close.

Same goes for the animations, interface and  general mechanics, they just look totally amatorial to me, I don't know, I guess if it would be an indie game that would be great, but for a franchise that is on the market since forever instead, FS19 still has a very sloppy feeling.

The only detailed and professional level thing in the game are the machines and farming tools in general, which sure, are very important, since is a farming simulator, but if all the rest feels 10 years old, is like driving a Ferrari in a ghetto.

Besides, I had way more fun with FS17, it probably felt more user friendly, even if you are not a professional farmer I mean.
I will probably keep playing it, but I believe the franchise is far away to be  triple A, probably a single A at the moment.

The game's title is misleading! It should be named "Farming Vehicle Simulator". That would reflect the gameplay content adequately. The minuscle additional farming-related content that this gaem has is really only  a thin layer of icing on the cake.

If you enjoy the simulation of sitting in a tractor and driving slowly, endlessly over fields then this game is for you (and I pity your life).

the graphics are great, the options for buying your vehicles are better than the previous ones, the options for growing crops are more extensive than previous games. I have had this game and spend all my free time on this game I am glad that I purchased it.

I came in expecting to be a farmer, hoping to plant seeds and watch my crops grow, but after having experiences that were deeper than with any previous game, I became more patriotic towards the US, suddenly I realized what the American dream meant and what it was. I became a grass farmer and made endless cash, watching it all unfold made me shed a tear in all its glory, god bless the US, and god bless Farming Simulator 19.

I wrote a review one year ago. Game was to raw for that time, I noticed some bugs for example "the harvester New Holland CR 10.90 stuck for example on the field number 12 on the map Felsbrunn, because it's header falls too low and clings to the soil and the harvester can not go". Developers fixed this one, one "+" to them. So, I was playing this game for one year and noticed some bugs more. 
1. I know that it is "optimization" but shadows behave really wierd (I'll leave some screenshots). 
2. Not a bug but it's really annoying, NPC cars... They're stony and very primitive, without them every map looks abandoned but when they are "on" they can really be a interference, they stop only when they almost touch you, you can't move them coz they are stony. I really want smart NPCs will be in FS21 to they can give you pass through, to they are not stony (like in ETS2 you can move them when you hit them but pay for it a fine), one "-" to devs. 
3. Next disadvantage it's glitchy forestry process, when you load logs with manipulator, they (logs) can suddenly fall in epilepsy seizure (I'll leave link to video in youtube to prove my words), in FS17 everything was OK with forestry process. 
4. Next issue it's shimmering elements of controls of technical equipment, this issue exist in FS17 for example in "Stara Imperador 3.0" arrows on joystick shimmer and one tiny element shimmers in FS19 too, it didn't in FS17, second "-" to devs. What more that besides arrows on controls mirrors in some tractors shimmer too now in FS19 (I'll leave a link to video). But now let's speak about good side of this game. FS19 much better than FS17, graphics improved, gameplay improved, physics improved with some issues described above but improved anyway. I really love FS games, I just constructively pointed out the shortcomings. So steam doesn't have "neutral" review button so I'll recommend this game if you can close your eyes to this little issues. But if you can't live without good graphics and you love to find fault with little details and everything should be almost perfect I won't recommend this game.

This game is good but fundamentally lacking. FS17- oh wait, we're on 19 now, brought a disappointing lack of improvement. The graphics are better and there are some new things to play with, but it generally feels like the previous installment with some mods and a reshade. The next game is likely to come out in 2020 so it's probably a bit late to buy this one, but if you want a Farming sim right now then this is still the best one to get. I'm hoping that FS21 (assuming they go by the same naming system and everything) has some real improvements. If it still lacks gearbox simulation and proper rain, I don't think I'll be buying it at all. Really, the rain is just a joke . . .
im adicted

Let me first mention that I'm a farming sim veteran with hundreds of hours in the previous games. Main issue: LACK OF REALISM. This game is 1) not a new game, it's the same one, and 2) it's a buggy mess. They had many chances to fix what this game is lacking the most: realistic physics. I'm really tired of having tractors, enormous trees and huge f-ing harvesters bounce around the map like beach balls. Implement gravity! I admit it's fun to leap 50 meters with by 20 ton truck while driving over a bump, but that's not how gravity works. Items in the real world have weight, see. This has been broken for 3 games now, because it's the same game engine.

Then there are so many small bugs that continuously breaks things from being enjoyable. Like, they finally fixed it so that you can't drive over your crops. But you must remove weeds from them, so then you have to drive over them and destroy them. Or you can hire a helper who magically doesn't destroy them. Hot keys for machines suddenly disappear randomly: no straw swatch on the harvester, no seed option on the seeder etc. The option is still there, but the hotkey is gone.

I google some of these bugs and find that they have been unresolved since 2015. Pathetic.

This version has been a big disappointment for me.  Seems like it was rushed to release without adequate testing.  I expect glitches and functionality problems with modded vehicles and maps, but when the default maps and vehicles don't work consistently together, it's just pure frustration.  Example:  I purchased a field (18, I think), which had a crop of corn growing in it.  I tried at least three different harvesters, with three different corn headers, and every one of them got stuck at starting edge of the field.    I started a new game on a modded map, saved it at least 6 times while playing, and then I had to do a forced reboot, and when I went back in, my saved game was gone.    There are so many little annoyances in this game that I can't get immersed in it like I used to.  I wish I could get my money back.  I'm very disappointed.  I've been a faithful fan of this franchise for several years, and always look forward to the new releases.  But this one was a big downer for me.

Fs19 is a superb game in its base form. The two maps offer a really nice experience for those new to the game to get started with. It offers a nice learning curve and the dynamics of running a pretty profitable farm are fairly simple to grasp. 

However the game comes into its own and really shines through the addition of mods (which are very easy to install). The mods on offer are fantastic at really extending that real farm feel, from vehicles to buildings and other dynamics. 

I highly recommend Seasons and a couple of choice maps like Loan Oak and This is Ireland to really get the full Farming Sim 19 experience. 

The you'll have to get yer famer on, plan sowing and harvests, care for your animals properly and decided how you're really going to run your farm and its hugely rewarding.

So it's a super recommend from me, get the game, get aquaited then get the mods and really go welly deep into farming sim 19!

Been playing the farming simulator series since FS 2011. Every new game is better than the last, and the developers are super invested in the in the community (Mods, etc). The Farming Simulator 17 was a lot better and I desire to spend my money on a game I will enjoy more. Believe me, if people enjoy the game, they will invest into it and you'll make profit. I sadly barely speak German and other foreign languages and I am not very interested to play in English.

Also, keep in mind that most games will use mods and be private. If you want to have fun, get the mods first. Honestly, Farming Simulator 19 looks more like an update/upgrade for Farming Simulator 17 with new eyecandy graphics and worse physics plus new maps and a few additional vehicles as usual.

Banana Slicer Saved My Life: What can I say about the 571B Banana Slicer that hasn’t already been said about the wheel, penicillin, or the iPhone…. this is one of the greatest inventions of all time. My husband and I would argue constantly over who had to cut the day’s banana slices. It’s one of those chores NO ONE wants to do! You know, the old ‘I spent the entire day rearing OUR children, maybe YOU can pitch in a little and cut these bananas?’ Then there’s, ‘You think I have the energy to slave over your damn bananas? I worked a 12-hour shift just to come home to THIS?!’ These are the things that can destroy an entire relationship. It got to the point where our children could sense the tension. The minute I heard our six-year-old girl in her bedroom, re-enacting our daily banana fight with her Barbie dolls, I knew we had to make a change. That’s when I found the 571B Banana Slicer. Our marriage has never been healthier. Speaking about farming ye thats preatty good game i really like it.

So I don't have all that much time into Farm Simulator just yet but I can totally see myself putting some crazy time into this game. There is just so much to do as far as the different crops to harvest and then all of the different machinery you can potentially buy it's honestly a little overwhelming at first. But after some tutorials and a few YouTube videos I can start a new game with confidence. This is the type of game that anyone, regardless of age, can hop right into. It's relaxing and yet it keeps you engaged with all of the tasks that you have to preform to keep up your crops or livestock. You can make it harder or easier through the settings menu and change all sorts of different aspects of the game from the speed at which time goes all the way to how much gas your equipment uses. If you have never played a FS game before this is an excellent place to start!

As a long time video gamer, this one stacks up there nice in the simulator world. Having just passed the 1900 hour mark, I will state that I have played about every situation available on this but the arcade style sim league. Not a fan of that, but to each their own. The maps that come with this game are real fun to play, or tack on some mod maps and see how you can do. I have a few game saves running. One I play from scratch and the other one I did the money cheat. Seasons mod really adds the realism one would expect as a real dirt warrior. 

The graphics are fantastic on my PC's. I utilize twin 1080 GTI cards from 2017. That said, some of the glitches in the programming make the game a bit quirky, as in the dairy cows walking right through your character.  If you can put that all aside, then game on, because this is pure fun. The addition of horses is a great feature, and you really do have to ride and care for them everyday to max out your profits. The timber industry side of the game is a lot of fun, too.

The equipment used in this game is far reaching, and again the mod world has only added to the huge selection one can play with. I haven't yet tried multiplayer and would imagine that could be a ton of fun, especially when a player has to clear those bales from the fields, the hired help can't do it. 

My biggest like right out of the box is the in depth realism and play options available. My biggest dislike is the AI needs help in the hire a worker department. It seems most times they skip parts of fields, don't catch the end rows well, and usually find every way possible to collide with objects. In a game world this big, my gripe may be small, but if your paying help to complete a field, the AI should knock it out.  Course play helps a little in that area, and there are helpful mods to speed up your working progress. 

I could go on about my hits and misses in this game, but eh....pick yourself up a copy and kick them there tires. All the dust and mud you want to conjure up is in there! Farming Simulator 19 certainly kicks the llama's arse!
it is the best

I've been addicted to this game since the 2013 version came out. I started on console and went to PC shortly thereafter because the mods make the game 9000% better. Don't get me wrong -- it's pretty decent on console with the few mods they get, but the community mods are what makes this game worth playing for the ten thousand+ hours I've put into it over the years.

It's a great escape from my mundane IT job and life in general, and gives me the opportunity to do virtually what I'd rather be doing in real life.

It's a relaxing game to have going on the side.  Generates low amounts of wife aggro, as I'm able to keep up conversations and play at the same time.  There's a lot to do.. it really is an open world farming game and feels  huge when first starting out.  Grow crops, raise livestock, forestry,   Small or large farms.  Buy or sell land, and set up your farm however and wherever you want. You can use prebuilt farms, or buy a field, pave it over and make one yourself - lay out your buildings however you want.  There's landscaping where you can add pavement, dirt roads, plant trees, level out soil.   Start with a pickup and a chainsaw and work your way up to the big machines, if you want.  It's easy to add money if you want by enabling the developer console.  So you can give yourself a budget to build out a starter farm, and then run it and make it profitable.  You can play however you want.  So much variety in maps and equipment.  Literally hundreds of pieces of equipment available to try.  Add the seasons mod for a whole new style of game play.  It's a big (and still very active) modding community, and new maps and mods are screened and approved by the developer and released pretty much daily. - accessible in-game without having to go to third party sites.  Also has a fun youtube community.   I've gotten a lot out of this game.  After almost 900 hours I finally feel like I'm hitting a point where I've done about every aspect and there's very little challenge left.. but there was plenty of challenge along the way, and I still feel drawn to play it - if anything to try out all of the new maps and equipment that keep getting released.  Plus, in the process, I've learned quite a bit about different types of farm equipment and find it all pretty interesting.   It's really been a fun game for me and I'd totally recommend it.

When you had a stressful day at work and you need to get lost in a game for hours on end to get your mind off life, this is the game to do that with.  It's the type of game I expected to spend a couple hours playing a week.  I sit down at 5 O'clock after work and next time I look at the clock it's midnight.  The modding community in this game is truly second to none and if anyone is interested in checking it out prior to buying i highly recommend going to Daggerwin's Youtube channel and checking out his survival roleplay.  If you have the imagination for it this game has endless possibilities.  This game deserves 2 thumbs up, 5 starts and 9.5/10 on all media platforms.  Absolute gold.  Cheers fam and here's to hoping we get a story mode in FS21.

I clocked 13 hours in this game, on the first day I bought it.

This game is weirdly clunky to start, the tutorial is weirdly confusing and not very informative. And yet, once you put an hour or so into the game, starting to figure things out by yourself, this game then becomes weirdly addictive.

I used to be a fan of the farm sim 14, but I've then dropped the series for other games. Now with the farm sim 19, 5 years later, I've grew strange to the controls and many of the concepts of the game, but once I got through the rookie stage, I have to give this game 8/10 (and if you're a fan of the series, then 10/10).

Also, the multiplayer is just amazing. Lag never seem to be an issue, everything is so smooth, and it would be perfect if you have a mate to play the co-op with you, you can just chill and chat and bond with your mate, and just plough through the day (lol), you would never want to go back to single player.

I dunno why but I found myself wasting so much time into this game than I thought.
I think part of it is that, compared to ATS and ETS 2 or other loved games like H3VR, I don't have to use a wheel or put on the HMD and controllers, respectively. I find that this game is best played using a controller as, compared to the likes of other vehicular games, you need to be moving the camera around a lot and a dual-analog controller fits better than a steering wheel. Add in the fact that this game has no Force Feedback and a handful of machines do not use the usual wheel an pedals that you're used to and it makes more sense to use a controller.
Farming Simulator 19 is also a big step in that, much like previous games with Challenger and New Holland, this iteration brings the first licensed appearance of John Deere with the Platinum Expansion adding CLAAS later on.
In terms of simulation, I'd say this game handles more like those R/C farm exhibits that are especially popular in Germany with a controller and I don't say this like it's a bad thing. That makes it easier to sit down and play this game for long sessions at a time.

Another praise is how easily you can mod this game, GIANTS keeps their files readily in standard formats versus the 95% of developers that use hard-to-crack proprietary formats. This leads to a lot of mod potential and you can find these mods to add additional realism to the game such as GPS steering for straight lines, seasons with crop rotation, realistic gears and terrain handling for vehicles, etc.
Granted, Sturgeon's Law can apply but most low-quality mods are not even on the website or in-game browser and you can filter to only see the top-rated mods to ensure you get quality.

For every reason besides one this is the best game in the FS series. If you love farming or just messing around then this will be a fun game. Im not going to go into it very much because im sure others can explain it better. The biggest problem is lack of mods/community for this game. In FS17 there were new mods almost every week for the entire span of the game that continued to impress me. There was also a striving community, plenty of Youtubers were getting on and trying the game out and it just felt more like there was a community. Now that has mostly changed. It seems like almost no new gamechanging mods have been added at all in this game and its a year old. In 13 we had logging. In 15 we had Courseplay. In 17 we had Seasons. There has not been a mod that ive found that has seriously changed the game to where Giants might add it as a feature in future versions. There is also a problem with maps. This could be partly community, but there have been less than 3 maps that are brand new this year that i consider good enough to start a game on. The rest are all from previous games with small addons. I dont have a reason for this, but its very sad. This is one of my favorite games and i have to put up with terrible mods and nobody to talk about the game with. Wish we could go back to 13-15-17. Hopefully Giants can find some way to make 21 feel unique and exiting to get. Shoving more brands and better graphics in our face will not work and im sure they know that as there are still alot of people playing 17.

Game title is pretty self explanatory. What I like about Farm Sim, is it can be as realistic or as simple as you prefer. Want to be able to short cut across your field without damaging the crop? Turn off crop destruction. Want to feel like you are running a multi million dollar operation? Turn on periodic plowing/lime and weeds. Giant still needs to license some 1 ton pickup trucks (legit, like all the farming equipment) but they are on the right track for my preference.

I am rewriting my review so that it is more so a review of constructive Criticism instead of a review of doubt and disbelief of the game.
I now have over 400 hours on farming simulator 2019 i love playing the game but i believe that it has taken a more arcade approach than a simulator approach towards farming i would like to see a physics implemented in the game that allows you to get stuck in mud the more times you drive over the same place i think it also need more features in the machines such as GPS also i think it would be a lot better in my eyes if the pricing of machines and land was a lot more realistic with added features such as the ability to have machines on demonstration of if you can not buy them out right then finance on the specific machine you are looking to purchase.
The ability to own land and rent it out to other players on multiplayer also the ability to sell you products that you make such as bales crops or even you machines to others NPC/Players on multiplayer for a more emersive simulator feeling the cost of bills could be a little better also such as road tax insurance etc on anything that is able to go on road as that in my eyes is what a simulator is to simulate life.
One more thing i would like to see more info on machine spec such as torque weight etc and the ability to buy new or used machines.

Farming Simulator 19 is in many ways an upgrade from 17, and there's plenty I like about it, but there's many times while playing 19 that I miss things about 17.

[h1]CONS;[/h1]

The maps in 19 are horrible. I've played both maps for many hours and I can never get used to them. They are plain, boring, small, and overall not fun to play.

Parts of the maps are unavailable with larger tractors because of how poorly they are designed. The selling locations often have very tight corners with random junk in the way making getting into the locations (such as the ports) a huge pain. Some of them even have entrances but no exits, requiring you to back your semi truck back out of the selling locations. They are just overall very bad design.

Some tractors in 17 are missing from 19 for seemingly no reason? You can get a Case IH Steiger with both wheels or tracks in 17, but in 19 you can only get a Steiger with tracks. There is NO OPTION for a Case IH Steiger with wheels..

Physics are wonky. I often run into invisible objects that make my vehicle glitch out and sometimes fling across the map.

UI in my opinion is worse. The white UI disappears when against the sunny sky, and you need to move the camera angle down into the dirt to see what time it is or how much money you have.

Giants have released many official "mods" on the Mod Hub that are great, but it can get annoying if you want to play with your friends and you have to download the same tractors. I don't understand why the official "mods" from Giants are not added directly to the game via an update. That way everyone can easily play with all of the tractors without having to download them all individually.

[h1]PROS;[/h1]

[list]
[*] Store UI is amazing. Being able to see the model and customize it before you buy it is incredible.
[*] Graphics are much better and look less plastic than in previous games.
[*] More crops and animals adds more to the game.
[*]John Deere being official is great.
[/list]

The game is good. Luckily mods can fix most issues and they are available directly from the modhub in the game. Hopefully Farming Simulator 21 improves on these issues and doesn't require mods to make the game more fun.

[b]Overall:[/b]
It's a nice step forward in the Giants Farming Simulator series and it is well worth the money if you're new to the farming simulator genre.  Giants is [b]THE[/b] top dog in the farming simulator world of gaming.  But for long time fans/players I would wait for it to go on sale because, sadly, there just isn't enough new additions to justify paying full price for this release.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
At the time of writing this review I've only tinkered with FS19 for around 5 hours but I feel, considering that I'm a long time player that has played every iteration of Giants FS series since FS2009 [b]and[/b] I have released maps/mods to the community over the years as well, that 5 hours was enough time to preview all of the new additions to this version.

Sometime between the release of FS15 and FS17 I began to come to the slow realization that Giants was turning their Farming Simulator series into a cash grab.  While each version of the game arguably has an impressive, real to life, lineup of machinery to use in the game it just seems that Giants has lost focus on a few things.  What I mean by that is while it may be nice to drive around a pretty tractor if that tractor can only drive around there really is no point now is there?

There is so much more to farming that just planting, tilling, fertilizing, harvesting, and raising animals.  What about agricultural industry?  What about seasons?  Mods are filling this void and I hope Giants is taking note of this.  They have in the past and I hope they go back to that as they once did when they added the most popular mods like logging, cruise control, vehicle washing, etc, etc.

Is this a bad game?  No.  Not at all.  It's a very good game.  It's stable and it plays very nicely.  There are quite a few new additions that are really nice and I'm not complaining one bit.  It's just that I believe Giants needs to get back to being more mindful of their community going forward is all.

About Multiplayer, I see so much Improvment since Farm Sim 17.
First that comes to mind are the graphic, way better grass, shadows, sky and so on.  The way the grass and bushes move then  you drive over it is awesome.

Second, That you can own your own farm in Multiplayer mode are so nice.  First  you start to buy the land areas you wanna start your farm on,  then you buy the tractors and equippment you want. And your friends can choose there own way to run there farm, not as in the previous Farm Sim when you share one farm. And you can still give your friends access to your farm and vise versa so you can still help eachother out.

Third, Repairs, its so nice to finally see another "running cost"  then before.  In previous Farm Sim you had to sell and buy a new Tractor or Equippment after a while cause of the daily running cost. Here you can go back to Workshop / Store and repair the veichle, so here you dont get "forced" to sell a tractor just cause its old and cost a fortune to own.

Fourth, Beautiful maps, I have only played on one map and just checked the other one out, but the dynamics are so much improved. The feild are not just flat and boring.  One think Im little dissapointed at are the traffic, still looks very stiff and not so animated and they drive like crazy drunks.  But thats not what this game is about so I can live with that.

Now I havent more to write for now, still a very new game so hope they make some bugfix and so on what players find in the game.  :)  :D
