Being a reasonably experienced Farm Sim player since 2011 (also own previous versions), I had high hopes for FS19 before release. It seemed as if Giants had done a complete overhaul to the engine and made it look much nicer than previous versions.

And in my opinion, they didn't dissapoint. Of course, my potato bag of a computer isn't quite the machine you'd want to be playing this game, but upon opening the game, I was already impressed by the new GUI/HUD and loading screens. The graphics, after some tweaking, look much nicer and full of colour than FS17, albeit a slight bit more saturated for my liking. Lighting and reflections look much better and bounce of the tractors and implements nicer.

Vehicle handling seems to have improved. From what I remember as a comparison, FS15 was very slidy, tractors would tend to drift everywhere. FS17 fixed this, but hardened it too much and made the tractors grip to the ground like velcro, but I personally prefered it to FS15. FS19 has loosened it up a bit, but the gravity of the game feels lighter, as if you are nearer the moon than anything. As far as detail of vehicles goes, serious improvements. They look much cleaner and nicer, and lighting for screens and dashboards is another nice touch, along with cab suspension and moving parts inside (pedals, levers, etc). Steering is another change to the game, where instead of the steering returning to its normal positioning when the button is let go, it will stay in it's current position, and steer back when the tractor is moving.

The placeable buildings feature is something I'm not very keen on. I preferred it when the sheds and silos were preplaced, like in previous games. This only applies to 2 of the 3 gamemodes, where the first 'Easy' mode already has tractors and sheds laid out for you, where as the other 2 leave you with nothing (one does give you a hefty sum of cash to start out with).

As many reviews say, bugs are a big problem in the game at this stage. Graphics, handling issues, glitches, many things to name, but as of now I shall not mention any because they have been in pretty much 90% of all reviews. The game is in its very early stages, people, give it time, the game is in store for many improvements. Patience.

So if you are keen on FS19, whether it be the new tractors, horses or just want an upgrade, get on now! But if you want to hold out until Christmas or maybe earlier/later, FS17 will do you fine until that time. Instead of naming every single feature in this crappy review of mine, I'll leave it to the other reviewers more serious than me to take care of that, or even better, get in your wallet and buy it yourself. From my point of view, it'll be worth it.

Let's take a look at FS19.

Well Giants did it agian. They amazed me all over again with FS19. "But RavenAlpha what about the pros & cons?". Well here they are.

Pros:
New engine.
John Deere (Who does not like them!?).
Horses... Everybody loves horses.
Birds.
Cotton.
Oat.
You can choose to build your farm from the ground and up.
No more buying fields. You buy pieces of land.
You can sell those pieces of land again.

Cons:
Still much to work on.
No Claas.
No danish map (Seriously Giants where the f**k is Denmark!? We are one of the biggest in export of farming goods).

That's pretty much it.

- Ravnholt

Im not much of a fan of farming and the whole tractor stuff, yet i still find this game a relaxing experience, just to chill out and plant my wheat then feed my little chickens. Of course its not perfect and of course more could have been added but i feel when the community starts to create a range of mods, it will completely change the game.

Pros:
I love the fields system
Graphics are lovely
Improved placeable system
Improved field care (with lime and weeds).
The repair feature instead of daily maintenance cost so i can keep all my old tractors and equipment in a sort of storage area.

Cons:
No penalty or reduce in price for either doing contracts on a field or selling your field. I can easily start a game and buy a harvester, header, trailer and tractor then go round buying fields with grown crop, harvesting it and selling both the crop and field to only gain more money.
Lack of placeables or inability to place concrete down, or maybe dirt for roads but hopefully mods will fill in this gap.
Excellent game! The game constantly improves and offers great fun.

The game is great; we are excited about the next farming sim version and looking for new features, changes which could be great for upcoming farming sim versions.

# Force feedback settings for wheels
# May have server slot reserve option for listed players
# More wide and open space type farm map as default base official map
# Improved weight mass and physics
# Sync data with other players may be done without pausing everyone in server online.
# Welcome page for a dedicated server to show server rules, owner contact information, social media links etc. (players may have the option to open and close the page while playing in server)
# Ability to ban/kick a player from a server using dedi app web page/interface
# Migrate ban list with dedi web page/interface so we can add/remove without depending on the save game file.
# More realistic economy system
# More character / face / shape 
# Season option without depending on mods
# Automated missing mod installation when joining a server (of course with players confirmation)
# Automated missing mod installation from dedi server app mods folder to players mod folder without exit the game. (on dedi app server owners may have the option to turn on/off mod distribution automatically)
# Bigger animal pen as optional
# Bigger parking shed/hall for bigger machines like Big Bud, etc.
# Color choice for all machines to suit players choice and farm specific usage.
# Ability to turn on/off unloading anywhere feature (especially for dedi server)
# Transparent shield around the water surface to block anyone driving into the water at least for dedi server (to prevent trolling, which is the most common practice of trolls that ruin the whole gameplay)
# Player based earning system and history to specify players effort on a specific farm. (must have on/off option per player in server settings)
# Visual damage effect, realistic, specific repair option.
# Telemetry datacasting to generate live status of moving objects and maps of a server in the dedi app for the mobile device. 
# ability to read/write text (chat) in-game server using dedi mobile app as admin.

1) This game feels like previous versions, with some texture updates. Does this make it worth upgrading to? Does it make it look nicer? Yes.
2) New equipment - notably from John Deere is nice, however lackluster in the amount. Same with Claas in the (lackluster) DLC. Just as well off using DLC
3) No more grabbing a stick and flying across the map :( 
4) Feels like a well rounded game, but some of the pricing seems off esp for selling crops. This is a real world vs fictionary area thing though
5) Two maps? Really? There are SO MANY modded maps out there - I find it very hard to believe that you couldn't certify a few of them (and maybe pay the modder(s) for huge community approval? DLC anyone?
6) Very mixed feel on multiplayer. The synchronizing on server every time someone joins is horrific - why? As a computer tech I understand a need for a 'break in production' to bring in a new item into a live database, but why can we not smoothly transition like so many other games (read:ARK) The world there is almost the same size as ravenport with as much detail.
7) On the subject of servers. What the f. Why do I have to pay for an extra copy of the game (not to mention all the DLC I want to run) to run a dedicated server? I mean yes this is MUCH cheaper than renting from a worthless host and much more satisfying for experience. but WHY? Almost every other game out there gives me a FREE dedi app
8) Also on the subject of multiplayer - whawt the f is up with this freezing during play? Every 15-30 minutes. Yes I know there are save points - again as an IT person I know that databases deal with online saves that don't interrupt services. If this wasn't the case there would be 5-20 minute windows every 1-2 hours where hospitals would be offline. Not only that but games such as ARK and Minecraft have 0 issues despite huge maps and mods...
9) Oh! As a dedi server admin FIX THE UPDATE FOR THE DEDI APP. I don't need to download 4GB of data and run a patch every time when my client downloads 100mb and can update the client. Get your crap in a heap GIANT.

Overall - Great game, if you haven't hit another in the series I seriously recommend it. I would hugely say forget the DLC and go get the mods. As a community game for a streamer there are minimal issues. Check out the Modded maps. Have fun!

New user perspective.

It is absolutely amazing if you love a good vehicle sandbox. If you already played FS before then you already know it's great, but graphics, John Deere, and horses are fun enough for another try if you're considering it! Alternatively, if you've never played, this is a great time to start. Excellent vehicle sandbox where all vehicles have tons of features, options, and uses. Raising animals is awesomely fun. Even if you have played a lot of the previous simulators consider that there are new maps, content, and the fact that us noobs need your help please :P 

You've heard the ups, now here are the downs. 

-For new players, the tutorial doesn't cover menu usage, where to sell most things, multiplayer game mechanics, or how to do any maintenance on animals. Veteran players, Youtube and the forum are a great resource at that point. FS19 is still pretty new, but I've found that some FS17 tutorials are really helpful still. 
And I can't stress this enough, if you're a gamer instead of a farmer, you WILL NOT have a clue what's going on, and the game will give you very limited tutorials that make you feel extremely frustrated. If you find it worth it, look up what information you can but the game itself will not provide enough useful information to enjoy it.
-That's all, play it.

So I have been following this franchise for quite some years now, and this is by far the same thing as every other game they have produced. I've updated the review to a recommend, and there is much to love about this game that is well described elsewhere.  I'm leaving my post release review here though in the hopes that FS21 will be less shoveled out the door.

This game just wasn't ready for release. I've shelved it for a while until it's ready. The controller support is laughable, there is a line about 3 feet in front of my combine where the graphics change that just moved along a fixed distance in front of the vehicle. I've had a couple of crashes that seem to relate to controller mix and I'm fighting with stupid things like not being able to properly rotate the vehicles in the 3D preview. None of this is game breaking but it is hugely frustrating and I don't want to fight to make my games work in my very limited free time. I'll come back in a month, try again and adjust the review as needed. Next time get this beta tested by non pyscophantic you tubers ☹️

I have been playing the Farming Simulator franchise since their 2009 release. For 10 years, their development team grows bigger and stronger. From listening to fans and upgrading game physics/graphics, they continue to better themselves each release. Each new game, offers new gameplay and better improvements worth paying the small one time fee. Honestly, the DLC packs are not entirely worth it unless you specifically are wanting material in that pack. Reason why I say that because the modding community is so large, you can get a massive piece of content from an independent creator for free. Which brings me to modding. It cannot be easier to download and install mods for this game. I do wish there was workshop support, but I feel that would become over saturated quick. There are thousands of websites out there with hundreds of mods, and each site only contains 30%-60% of the same mods that another site may have. This is a great game that I would recommend to anyone, who wants to experience the farming life.

The terrain sculpting feature has ruined this game for me.

I tried so hard to appreciate it, and all it does is act as a constant, buggy, thorn in my side.  

Being able to modify the terrain sounds great in theory, but instead, because of how the fields are laid out, becomes a necessity. And it's ridiculously expensive, finicky, and will downright glitch out fields so they are unusable.  

You thus spend more time and effort just trying to create a canvas of land to work with, before you can even start the elaborate process of re-drawing fields with a plow (which you will have to do again).  Leaving you with an utter mess. 

If newer iterations of the game do not remove, or completely overhaul this system, I can't even see myself trying them. Which is such a shame, because I LOVED Farm Sim 17!!

At about 30 hours in, I can tell you honestly that this game is oddly satisfying and insanely addictive. Another aspect that I find alluring, yet unexpected is how relaxing it is. As a pilot, my job is often stressful and I find this simple Farming Sim to be a great place to unwind and enjoy the scenery. I haven't even explored the world of logging or animals yet! 

Pros: 
-simple gameplay with complex elements, basics are easy but there is a depth to the economics and the machinery that keeps it interesting past the first harvest. 
-gorgeous landscapes!
-Try the radio function, I particularly enjoy the live stream of current hit music.

Cons
-Driving gets a bit squirrelly at higher speeds and the physics with the vehicles/terrain/trailers gets a bit wonky. This isn't a driving game so I'm not to bothered by it, but getting a trailer stuck on a stop sign is at times annoying. 

Verdict: If you have any interest in simulation style games, this one is a fantastic way to pass the time!

Firstly, for context, I am a 36M, married with 2 kids who also play FS. After playing hundreds of hours in FS15 and FS17, mostly vanilla, after only 8hrs I find FS19 is a complete let-down. I play primarily for the logging experience, which in FS17 wasn't perfect but was far far better than FS19. The logging physics has been completely ruined in FS19. Stock wheel loader has lower reach making loading the log trailer very difficult unless parked lower. The log grabber doesn't tip back hardly more than horizontal making it very difficult (especially on a grade) to roll logs deeper into the jaws. The closing physics of the log grabber is also broken resulting in many logs clipping through even when gripped evenly, firmly, and moving slowly. On average, only 3 logs can be grabbed regardless of size etc. Even the tractor log grabber is worse now than FS17, with sticky and clipping logs happening far more often.

The only truck I have so far is the Warrior, which apparently has only 1 gear, or maybe a CVT? The horn is also absolutely pitiful.

The train horn has also been "upgraded" from FS17, which had a very realistic crescendo and auto-repeated if held. FS19 train horn is just a single note that starts and ends abruptly. Why would this be changed?

The only improvements worth mentioning is the visuals and more realistic hydraulics and steering.

After reading through the reddit sub I see now that all these logging issues have been complained about for up to and over a year now with no improvements. Very slack of the developers not to address these issues. I will be returning to FS17 for the logging experience and will not be recommending FS19 to anyone looking for improved logging.

For a game that set up his slogan as "Farm like never before", I expected more, much more.

I cannot feel any change in the engine, mainly on the vehicles. Game mechanics still unrealistic, no difference between different types of terrain, vehicles are way too responsive. Giants software thinks adding tons of brand new vehicles is enough to "farm like never before".
I just cannot have fun without downloading tons of mods because the base game are just insufficient.

Honestly, this is another game that has so much potential on top of the fun it already is. The MODs help this game out a ton! I recommend looking up the MODs available to ease troubles and add more realism to the game. Little bugs that are not game changers but i can tell time was not put into detail (harvesters unloading into trailer and it shows harvest going through the trailer), those kind of bugs and lack of detail. Despite my little issues this game has me hooked! I have not stopped playing this game since I bought it! 

I am excited to see more additions to this game in the future. Curious why a watering system was not considered as part of a farm simulation? Irrigation up to small straight line wheel watering units and later upgrading to the big round field units, seems like a no brainer to me. More home choices. When i sleep my helpers are sped up to where they would be in the hours i slept. Instead I sleep and they are still in the area of field they were working on when i wake. 

I would like to see more "Farming" simulation as opposed to farming machine simulation. Making contracts with local businesses or big business outside the valley. Like for instance a major food chain chooses your potatoes for their fries. Selling hay bails to local farmers and other states. Picking a contract and then selecting machinery  you have to use and lease item you don't. Lease to own equipment. Natural disasters and seasons. Predators of livestock. I want to farm, not simulate equipment (though it is still fun). Farming simulator 20 could be pretty dang awesome if more of the "Farming" is implemented. Add more fields. Orchards, fruit fields, vegetables. Love what i have available though MODs or not.

Pros:
John Deere

Foliage bending
 Weeds and Crop Destruction added to game without mods
Beautiful base game maps  (Ravenport for USA and FelsBrunn for Italy)
New Sounds 
Dynamic Weather.
Cabin physics (like the seats bouncing up and down and moving pedals.
Very Modable


Cons:
Vehicle Handling is Different this year
Trucks Bottom out when emptying at Railroad Silos
Tutorials aren't that good and you may have to turn to Youtube for Tutorials
Not as Much John Deere as you think there is.

Coming from action/adventure games I was taken by surprise just how fun this game have been for us. Farming Simulator 19 is a great experience for a group of players who enjoy teamworking a company (or farm) together. Share the workload with friends, diversify your sources of income and learn to recognize real life farming machinery and brands.

Before I purchased this game, I read a lot of the reviews. So many made comments about graphics issues and how horrible the graphics were. So I watched some YouTube videos of folks playing the game and really could not see any of the problems mentioned.

My PC is, to be honest, a box of crap. My graphics card is kept cool by another fan laying under it, blowing up. I have just 4GB of ram. So I assumed the game would be sluggish. In some ways, yeah, it is. Some grass textures and groups of vehicles are two of the things that makes the game stutter until whatever it is passes out of the camera view. I use a lot of mods which are all loaded with the game. Other than that, no issues.

I'm loving it and have about 500hrs into it so far. I only play solo so have no report on multiplayer. Without mods, this game would be boring as heck and not worth it. The same was for FS 15 (which I played a LOT) and FS 17 (which I didn't like and didn't play much at all). 

is it worth the cost? Sure. Catch it on sale like I did.
Are the graphics horrid? Things at a distance or whatever distorted? Problem with lighting? Nope. Not for me and my crappy PC.
Everyone should play this game. It provide the player with a real taste of a farming experience. The realism and detail is flawless. I highly recommend to play this game.

What draws me to this game again and again is that it's immersive work. I makes you appreciate the hard and complex work that is farming. Now, I play on the hardest settings and I'm still pretty sure this isn't even 1% of how hard it is to be a farmer, but I appreciate the challenge this game gives me.
It has a great variety of equipment I had never even heard of before. And each piece has its own properties and quirks I need to get used to and I find this variety fascinating. They add new equipment in each DLC.
But the game doesn't have to be all this hard - you can set it up to be very forgiving for a simple and calm farming experience to just chill out. For a calm evening, just driving a tractor and listening to a good radio (Simulator Radio is awesome, btw), I would *highly* recommend this game.
The gameplay is solid, still has a few small kinks to iron out, but enhanced greatly with mods. There are simple quality-of-life mods (like precise angles or more information), as well as grand mods with new vehicles and even entire maps when you've beaten the original two.

Hello fellow digital farmers,

After having played this game / simulation for more than 700 hours, i thought it was time for a detailed review of this so addictive game / simulator. And why so extensive? Because this game / simulation simply deserves it and it is not that easy to explain, why this is so attractive and becoming more and more popular.

To begin with, you see as a reader, that i find it difficult under which category i can place this game. It can lead a wonderful life as a simulation, but it is just as well a game with its limitations within the game engine.  Of course it's just A game and you'd say it's done. But the "game" includes so much more than that. 

The developers of this game have made a nice balance between: just a good game and a relatively realistic simulation. Elements such as invisible walls / hit boxes are still present here and there, but are not overwhelmingly present. A balance between an arcade game and a simulation is perhaps a bit too black and white in a comparison, but it certainly has roots that direction sometimes.

You notice that every time it is 2 aspects  that mix with each other every now and then. They alternate well each time. That not only ensures a good gaming experience, but makes judging about this game / simulation quite difficult. Sometimes you get annoyed  by the "woody feeling" that the game makes you feel and at other times it presents itself wonderfully smoothly. 

A game with two faces.

Graphically beautiful, but again not really eye candy.
Sound is certainly not bad,  but not great either.
The gameplay is pretty easy to do, but really well-arranged, no.
The tutorial is pretty good and teaches you the basics, but there is so mush more in the game, that you sometimes have to discover it by trail and error. 

As you read, every time there is something good, but also a bit less good things.
A balance that is so well mixed that you can make every setback disappear again, by something good that the game / simulator will surprise you with. 

What is the real power of this game / simulator than?

Can you drive around with big fat cool looking tractors? Yes! - Check.
Can you work with the largest and most expensive equipment? Yes! - Check.
Can you design and build your own farm? Yes! - Check.
Does it also support, keeping animals on my farm? Yes! - Check.
Oh, does it support MOD's? Oh yes and how! - Check.
Can i also use other landscape maps than the vanilla ones? Pff...yes! - Check.
Does it also support multiplayer? Thats almost the best thing about it! - Check.
Is there perhaps also online in-game radio? Yes! Yes! Yes! - Check.
But can i change the colors of my purchased verhicles?......yeah.
Is it also educational and do you learn somthing from it, in the field of agriculture? (the parent says) Yes ofcource.
Is it replayable than? That is the purpose of this game...lol.
Is it expensive to purchase the game? Not really.
Are there DLC's too? You're kidding, right? Bloody hell yeah.
Are there any bad things about this game? 

No, not worth mentioning and now keep your mouth shut and make me money at the farm.

If you're looking for a good representation of anything agriculture and livestock for anywhere outside of Switzerland, you will not find it here. Giants, the developers of Farming Sim, have a clear, unethical, and unapologetic bias for central European agriculture and equipment. Every tractor is modeled after the EU version, with all EU hitches and Germanic signage on the equipment with large EU wheels and front linkages. This game is marketed as a Farming Simulator but in reality it is only about central European agriculture and not simulating. 
The BIGGEST CON:
The most frustrating part about this game is a dark legacy of Farming Simulator games, the physics, or lack there of. There is not realistic physics simulation in Farming Simulator 19. Each vehicle is adjusted via xml file with a hand full of simple stats in order to create the illusion of vehicle physics. There are simple animations of the vehicle that actually have their origins in community mods of previous Farming Simulator games. Much like every major improvement to each new FS game, are refined community mods from previous games except for the lighting system in this game.
The performance on large maps or small maps with a lot of equipment,
 (about how many pieces of equipment a medium farm would have in real life),
is poor. The frame rate is inconsistent in these two conditions, maxing out when looking away from your farm, but chugging when looking at it, or sometimes in just a certain direction of the map. This can be caused by a hidden issue with any given map, but it is usually an unexplainable phenomenon when looking at the map from the Giants Editor program. This is with an i7 7700k, GTX 1080, 16GB OC ram, 1TB WD SSD. A system that is not a slouch by any means.

Overall, this is a fun game but you HAVE to come to terms with these few things;
 - It will NOT be a simulator.
 - If you want any other style of map, equipment, or farm buildings, you will have to look towards the 
   community mods.
 - Performance on high grade PCs will be subject to variables due to the way the game is built.

As well as all of this, the fact is, this game is the best option for a farming game. If there was an alternative with a focus on North American agriculture, I would play that instead. 
Again, the worst thing about this game is its inherent narrow focus on central European ag. 

TLDR;

Pros:
Sizable modding community
Multiplayer
Easily modded for absolute beginners
Fun with controller

Cons:
Not a simulator
Primitive 'physics'
2D crop textures
Extreme lack of Global ag styles (lacking North American and other worldly equipment, maps, buildings)
Performance issues (on high grade PCs)

Please read before buying Farming Simulator 19!!!!

I've read through on alot of the reviews and came to a conclusion that FS19 is about average or above average. There is alot of good, but there's alot of bads too, I'll give some of my opinions and share some aswell!

Alright I'll start with my opinions
Good:

• The visual overhaul is great as it gives more life to the environment

• The HUD change is great as it looks clearer and looks more pleasing to the eye, as well as the additional options such as being able to change the keybind without having to go to the main menu is also good!

• The addition of John Deere equipment is great!



Bads:

• The new Platinum edition/expansion is in my opinion not worth the name Platinum, it's more like an CLAAS DLC since there is only equipment. No maps... NO MAPS?!?! I've followed you since 2015 and both 17 and 15 had new maps, and now I came across 19 where I only get pitty equipment with no fun map to play on, smh for sure.

• Physics is an enemy of mine when it comes to the farming simulator franchise, one example is that I cannot load bales manually because the bales are basically rocks that weigh less than a gram, seriously, where is the squishy grip?? I cannot grab a bale without it sliding off or flying to space. And while I managed to load 1 bale and about to place 1 more on the trailer, the slightes bump will make it slide off the trailer.

• The game is overall boring, whenever I feel like playing farming simulator 19 I hop on a map on either SP or MP and while I can easely play for 20 minutes as soon as I reach about 30 minutes of gameplay and I get workers doing most of the jobs because it is either too boring or it takes too long to do. And I'll just kinda quit because It's boring.


Overall conclusion on what this/next game needs to update on:

• Better gameplay experience
• Better physics
• Plan better DLCs (Overall poor)


Don't take this as hate, I still play the game, but I think I could get a better experience if the game was a bit updated with the things I've listed above. If you like the FS series, this isn’t going to disappoint you. I was scared at first about it not being as great as i had hoped it would, but it really is. I’ve being enjoying for a few hours, and theres many to come. Overall, i give it a good 8/10.

I greatly enjoy this game, however I wish they had a store that you could by used equipment from. If you try to play the game properly, I feel that having this would be a great benefit. However, I truly enjoy this game, especially because they offer numerous mods.

The good bits first. The game game mechanics are good, the concept is good and the execution makes sense. Certainly worthy of some lengthy sessions as I can see it will be rewarding. The detail in the vehicles is great and the vast multitude of brands and items is impressive.

However, it's 2019 and there are some other games that simply embarrasses Fs19. Take SpinTires for instance. This game shows how terrain can be faithfully reproduced and how it can be affected by vehicle tyres and weight. 
I feel like I'm in the year 2000, FS19 simply doesn't cut it. Then there's the physics, it's a struggle to contemplate the way some vehicles behave, especially when you're driving at a fair speed and you can simply drive up or over things and there seems to be no realistic shift in weight or inertia in these huge vehicles. Then there's the night setting, where driving along a road is dangerous as your headlights only illuminate about 25 metres ahead of you. Just basic stuff that seems overlooked. 

Come on guys, for 2021 you need to step this up, look around you at the other simulations out there, look at the graphical and physical masterpieces on offer.

Farming Simulator 19 is a great game if you enjoy the feeling of accomplishing something while you're doing something else.

When I started playing FS19, I had no idea what I was doing. The tutorials are great, they show you what to do to have a successful harvest, how to do it and in what order, but that's about it. Then it throws hundreds of machines at you and says, "Have fun, make money". It took me a bit to get used to what does what, which is better than what, and so on, but while the learning curve could be a bit high for someone who's only used farming equipment for tobacco on a 1-acre farm (ME!), it was a lot of fun.

I enjoyed the visuals. Graphics are very nice, though sometimes I notice blips here and there that take me away from immersion, especially when I'm plowing a field. Not a big deal though. Every machine looks great. As you use them, they get dirtier and dirtier, and I really enjoyed that. At home, we never cleaned the machines. We just had a mentality that they were gonna get dirty, so why bother cleaning mud off? So you have the option of using a pressure washer to clean your machines if you prefer them to look shiny, but I never bothered. I really enjoyed the look of a dirty machine after plowing or seeding a field. It made it look like I actually did something.

The sounds are great, too! When you get in a tractor and start going, you feel like you're in a machine with lots of HP! You can turn your machine sound down if you prefer, along with a slew of other sound options (nice touch), which I definitely liked. I didn't care for the radio much. I would usually turn on Spotify while I was farming, so didn't bother much with their in-game radio.

The game itself can get a little rote. Some fields, especially modded ones, can be huge, and they can take literal hours to plow, seed, fertilize, etc. Its here that my beginning statement shines. I love audiobooks. I find myself with a lot of time at home were I'm conflicted on what to spend my time on. Reading? Gaming? Why not both? I'll start an audiobook, turn down the sound on FS19, and then get to work. Hours later, I have accomplished two things at once. And who says only women multitask?

Farming Simulator is a great game with a huge number of machines at your disposal. Does it get every aspect of farming right? Probably not. So I'm not sure how accurate the "simulation" part of the game is. But is it fun, and can you see the fruits of your labor rather quickly? Yes, and yes.

10/10, would play again.

***10 Month Revisit*** Giants finally got it together and have a solid polished product. If you wonder if you have waited long enough...the answer is yes. It's time to click that buy button.

***Release Review***I haven't seen garbage this hot since the last time i went to the landfill. Controls have been plagued with issues since release.  Ingame collisions and physics are absolute garbage, you will see thing happen that would never happen real life. Hydraulic power and operations are a joke with no way to even invert the controls. Logging, holy hell what a mess, did you guys even test your copy and paste garbage? Has anyone at Giants even ever operated any kind of machinery aside from a car and a lawn mower? Severely disappointing product. Dont waste your money. Wait a year then give it another look.

This was on my wishlist since release, and I bought this during the Summer Sale. Let's just say, i'm glad I didn't pay full price.

I have over 150 hours clocked up in FS17, which was a game I found to be highly addictive. So I thought I was on to a winner when I bought FS19.

Unfortunately not. Don't get me wrong. This is just as addictive as it's predecessor, but..... that's about it. I Only started playing a couple of days ago, and having clocked 10+ hours now, I still haven't really noticed any improvements or advantages over FS17. One of the marketing claims was a massive graphical improvement. Well... where is it? All i've noticed is a horrible and somewhat exaggerated orange peel effect on vehicle bodywork. I haven't seen anything else which has been graphically improved.

The main things that annoyed me in FS17 are still present in FS19:

- Helpers still cannot identify a separation between fields. So if you set up one worker to plow a field, keep an eye on them, otherwise you could be losing an entire neighbouring field of crops as well!
- Helpers still cannot finish a task if the field they are working in is not square/rectangular. I've already had messages popping up saying "Helper X has completed their task" when in fact half of the field has been missed, because it curves one way or the other.

The beacons all appear to have broken lenses. The silver colour of the rotating reflector is always visible, as if a piece of the lens is missing.

The controls are a bit messed up compared with FS17. I have assigned all the same controls between the two games. But in FS19, when I press the button assigned to Rear Work Lights, I get the Pause Menu. On foot, if I walk forward, the chainsaw appears. I ended up having to sell it to solve that problem.

There are various little issues like this which you really wouldn't expect to find in a game which claims to have been massively overhauled and refined since the previous version.


Maybe I just haven't put enough time into the game yet, but the fact the helper issues are still present is incredibly frustrating. Having to go round after them to correct their mistakes or finish the job they were meant to do (just as I had to in FS17), defeats the object of hiring them at all.

I'll continue to play, since it is, in essence, still very addictive. It's just a shame that it's really a re-badged version of FS17.

If I find a good enough reason to change my opinion, I will update this review accordingly. But for now, I remain unimpressed.
love the game and can't wait to see what FS21 will look like

The Farming Simulator Series is an ever-evolving franchise as well as being continuously refined. Each release brings forth new graphics enhancements, new features, new game mechanics, but overall it's the same game. Each year along with all the new points comes the questions of "why wasn't this added yet" and "did they release this seemingly unfinished" product.

Not unique to the FS series, a lot of games appear to be released falling short of their vision and ambitions probably due to time and budget constraints. Sometimes it's painfully obvious. Other times, it appears as though they rely on the modding community to make up for their shortfalls. It may even be strategic. They may be just focusing on what is needed to get the game out and leaving the rest to the modders. 

To properly set the tone, I like FS19 and I expect to put in a many hours as I possibly can, having two jobs and a wife.

So the criticism here isn't simply to bash Giants or this series. It's simply to help push this already great game to an even greater game, where it should be.

Let's start off with addressing the multiple bug issues. This is quality control and quite often the best beta test is the initial release. So, despite all the bugs, some having affected me, they WILL be addressed and therefore, I don't want to talk about them. I want to focus on design and direction.

MAPS:
For the first time, Giants has produced some high-quality maps with textures, details, and an ambiance that really immerse me. The layout appears to be good, but I'll only know for certain once I'm several hours into the map. It's even been said, these new maps are almost GTA quality. That's saying a lot. I have noticed a severe absence of trees, but that's likely to prevent overwhelming weaker machines. For me, I have to customize my map, adding more forest and trees before I'll start. It really enhances the immersion for me.

EQUIPMENT:
Of course the tractors and such look even better than before. Every release, they'll improve the detail and textures as the player's hardware also improves. Are many different types of new equipment but very little of it dramatically changes the players farming strategy.

FEATURES: 
New crops, better chicken management, horses are added. Nothing exciting, but they're very much welcomed.

BUILD YOUR OWN FARM:
FINALLY... I've always wanted to start with nothing. No ability to get a loan. Oonly has a chainsaw and a pickup truck. Then go dominate the map.  Still can't quite do that but close enough. For now. The different game modes and improved contract work make this far more enjoyable. 

PATCH 1.2
Landscaping! About time! This is a feature I will really enjoy. How could they have implemented it better? By attaching the landscaping code/script to the machines. I want to level ground with a machine not a mouse cursor. That would be the ultimate feature to this game.

BEEFS:
Ok. Maybe it's just me, but I guess I compare things to a vision I have. There are things to me that seem obvious and how and why they've been neglected will just give me ulcers if I spend too much time thinking about it. 

- Decorative placeable objects: I don't mean the "trees and shrubbery" and such.I mean the buildings and "garages" and sheds that are purely decorative. Why are these decorative and not functional? There are barns, houses, shacks and sheds... and you want me to buy these for what? In fact, one of the barns is completely finished on the inside, with amazing textures, but can't you open the doors to get in and use it. I would really LOVE to see these "decorative" objects be patched with completed and functional versions. Also... why one house?

- Bushes/Shrubs: Sure the landscaping tool can remove them, but why can't I mow them? This is something that should have been added in FS15.  Mushrooms... mow them. Or pick them. 

- Certain objects: I love the junked car carcasses and other junk lying around. What I would love even more is being able to pick them up and move them or have them taken to the dump. I like the idea cleaning up my yard.

- Logs to Lumber: The modders have done it. Why hasn't this been implemented into the core game yet? So many things can be done with lumber.

I'll add more later.

This is the best release yet and I will be putting hours into it once a few mods kick in and I find a good map.

it has it's bugs now and again, but nothing to cry about. Since me and my cousin play it pretty regular, it's been an awesome experience for the both of us. It's rather educational, and for this I'd recommend it to all ages. The mod community is nice, although you won't find a workshop on steam. (the steam mod community for those less fortunate to not understand.) I have the g29 steering wheel and it's a big help, although there's about 90 degrees of dead zone to the left and right for an overall 180 degrees of dead zone. Which, I'm almost sure can be worked out, but if not it's not anything i'm going to $hit my pants over. The multiplayer aspect is what really sold me on it, the shear fact that I can have anyone join in and play along is so nice. Graphics wise it's not exactly gonna bake your graphics card if you have a decent card, but it's a step above world of warcraft enough to make it jealous a great deal. Not a necessity, but I'd recommend having something with macro ability, i.e. razor naga, nostromo, logitech gaming keyboard, or something. The button combos to do certain abilites can get annoying sometimes. All out gamers and budget gamers alike can enjoy the crap out of this if you like chilling and keeping your mind busy, but not too busy. It's really open sandbox, basically you versus yourself, or it can be you versus the bank. Just make sure you shop the market when you buy equipment so you're not broke in 5 minutes. Cause a Deere (or any badass equipment) will break you like stone cold just ran out of beer and you're the only one he has in sight. If you're really struggling with the game hit me up, I'll get back to you as soon as possible.

Bought thinking yay!!! Time to relapse My FS13 & 15 addiction .... at least this one looks stunning and has john deere :D... But was disappointed to find that even with a top of the line PC and all settings cranked (Compared to when i used to play FS13 on a mac book :(   ) it doesn't actually look much better... very jank L.O.D and render distance/quality. I feel like they've been bitten by the same bug as SCS did when ETS2 got popular... and they've got so focused on adding features and getting licensing deals and relying on existing fanbase that they forgot that over the last 6 years the graphical standards for games have increased to a point where low res low poly distant scenery is not really acceptable in a $50 game (NZ pricing)... if it was $13 then yeah what a fun good value game... but when I already own two near identical games why is $50 a price I want to pay for a different number in the title...

Well... long story short... I refunded it... Hopefully the use a better game engine for the next one... or just hire someone to help bring the rockface textures and trees up to current standards :(

Farming doesn't even interest me, and I love this game. It's a game that you can sink hundreds of hours into easily.

Pros:
1. Realistic approach to farming is actually very calming. It's a nice way to chill after a stressful day
2. The game is very immersive, so it creates a very Zen experience
3. Graphics are realistic, and there's the right amount of "shake" to make you feel like you're actually operating the vehicles
4. Multiplayer makes the game lots of fun to play with friends / family
5. Numerous ways that you can play the game, so you're not trapped into just crops if that's not your thing
6. Can be played as either a Tycoon where you try to amass as much wealth as possible, or you can pursue a more Zen experience (my personal approach to the game) by simply immersing yourself in the world. The game is very open world, so you are free to pursue what you would like

Cons:
1. The controls of a couple vehicles (the tree crane thing from the tutorial comes to mind) are beyond ridiculous, and very hard to learn.
2. There's a bit of a learning curve for the game in general. You'll go through an hour or two of tutorials before you feel even mildly comfortable starting. They haven't done anything wrong here. There's just so much that you can do in the game, and to achieve the level of realism they have reached it's necessary.
3. The game needs to explain (preferably with tooltips as your hover your mouse) all of the various icons. Someone who's not familiar with farming isn't going to instinctively know that baler X is only used to create round bales (or that there is no equipment that loads round bales, you have to do it manually), whereas baler Y will create square bales. The shop will just display some cryptic icons that mean nothing to anyone except the developers, and those that have spent hours googling to decipher these strange mostly unintuitive symbols. The text won't usually be helpful either for answering compatibility questions. It will simply say something like ARCO 650, and NONE of the equipment anywhere mentions ARCO 650, so you have no idea what it's compatible with, so you end up wasting many thousands of dollars experimenting. This is my biggest gripe about the game, and it's what turned my wife off to it even though I think it's a fantastic game. It just requires so much research outside the game to understand how to play it.
4. Forestry tools were designed by a sadomasochist with a penchant for "the claw" vending machine games, and thusly decided to provide all of the forestry equipment with similar performance characteristics to his beloved vending machine game.

Lets get this out of the way. I've been playing FS since 2013. Its one of my favorite game franchises. But it seems that after FS13, Giants has never really gave the games a big improvement and supposedly this was supposed to be that big improvement. The graphics are....okay. But I'll get into that later.

Pros:
- Lots of Brands! Great variety (although they insist on keeping the EU SMV warning signs so when you go to an American map it breaks my immersion)
- Purchasing land is a lot more realistic to me and more enjoyable.
- Finally, after years and years of waiting, we have a store where you can see what you're buying.
Cons:
- Hardly any real new improvements. Graphics are virtually the same as FS17 but with a few minor changes.
- Physics, they're laughable. Hit the accelerator in a John Deere 6155M and suddenly immediately you're going warp speed. Steering is still awful and gives no feedback, suspension on vehicles is stiffer than stiff. For a simulator series thats been going on for 10+ years, this is really bad considering I can boot up FS13 and get virtually the same experience.
- Horsepower? HA! That's irrelevant in FS19, doesn't matter what Harvester you get, you are stuck at the speed the game tells you to go.
- The game is optimized TERRIBLY, that reason alone is why I REALLY recommend to stick with one of the older games like FS15 or 17. Its jittery, barely runs at points if you look at more than one piece of equipment. For a game that graphically isn't much better than 17, its terribly thirsty for a really beefy system, and I can run games such as BO4 and GTA V at a solid 60FPS AT LEAST.
- Everything drives like a arcade racer. 
- AI workers are still, not useless, but about as close to useless as you can get. Because as long as you keep an eye on them and fix their mistakes they make (like not finishing the edges of a field) you should be fine. But that's just a band-aid for poor design.

Unfortunately, it seems Giants is more interested in adding things like....dogs? To the game instead of fixing existing issues. There's more cons that I haven't bothered to list since I believe they've already been so well documented to the point I think it should be easy to look them up. Its a shame, look at a game like Halo CE and 9 years later in Halo Reach, you can see major graphical improvements. Every iteration of FS doesn't feel like something I'd pay $30 for again but more so a $10 update to a previous game. Lets be honest, everything new in FS19 isn't anything that couldn't have been added to FS17 or FS15, and that's becoming a big problem with this series. I still can have fun with it, but I'm very underwhelmed.

Farming Simulator 19, another title in the decade old Farming Simulator franchise. Does this one meet expectations?

UPSIDES
The game looks beautiful, and has a lot of potential with the mod support.

The new customizable farms are fantastic, same with being able to see the customizations on your vehicle before buying it.

Giants finally got John Deere in the game, though they still haven't gotten any car brands for the pickups. Cotton and oats join the party of crops, along with horses and birds making their debut. The vehicles also lose paint over time, which is a nice touch. I also love the new mission system and land purchasing.

DOWNSIDES
And then there's the issues. First of all, the vehicle handling. This is a big one. Turning is not much different from Farming Simulator 2009. Driving a truck, which should feel like driving a two-ton vehicle, instead feels like driving a Hot Wheels toy car. A truck filled with 39 tons of grain drives like a car towing a shopping cart. This is dissappointing, as Euro Truck Simulator 2, a 7 year old game, handles like the real thing.

Glitches are a big problem in this game. Apart from glitches other reviewers mention, there's the problem where trailers wil run off if not hooked up to a tractor, while FS17, a two year old game, doesn't have that problem. The wool harvester will suddenly have the mechanical part inside the chamber clip through the roof. Will Giants fix these glitches? Well, not after one announcement where they said they will focus on DLC and only fix game breaking glitches.

With that being said, they can improve all this by improving the physics and keeping vehicles from FS17 in the basegame, and fixing the bugs plaguing the game. If they do this, I can finally reccommend this game.

+ Beautiful graphics
+ Massive selection of vehicles
+ 3D customization
+ Customizable farms
+ Vehicles now rust
+ John Deere is now in the game
+ Works on most computers
+ Mod support


- Game feels bland
- New maps are boring
- No gearbox
- Vehicle handling is still awful
- Horse handling is as awful as vehicle handling
- Background is overly blurred
- Unrealistic physics
- Glitches and bugs
- Barely any improvements on realism
- Traffic is still slow
- Old vehicles have been downgraded to mods
- Expensive DLC
- Some mods on the Farming Simulator website aren't on the ingame ModHub

This game was a major dissappointment for me. If anything can save this game, it's the modding community.

3/10, wait for sale or buy the downpriced FS17.

Edit 1: I found some mods on the website's ModHub that enhances gameplay. But when I look for them on the ingame ModHub, they're nowhere. You can't even use the search function to find them, either.

Edit 2: Made the review more constructive

Wrote a review earlier, so this is a correction.

Giants patched the game today, so; I can actually get into the game once again; at least that game breaking bug was fixed.  but with no patch notes avaliable, I don't know what else was fixed.  

as far as play-ability, for the most part, its a decent (not great) game.  there are still a few bugs and glitches, like sometimes not being able to connect to trailers, or combines/harvesters/bailers still registering a seed type in them even after emptying them, making it difficult to fold the units for transport on the maps.

I do appreciate the more realistic, tight and uneven farms that the maps have, adding in the complexity of having to determine the proper equipment to be used on the field in question.

I do not like the fact that there is no equipment trailers for small equipment like skid-steers, or forklifts that the pickup truck is able to pull; hopefully they fix this before the next edition of FS comes out.  driving a forklift/skidsteer across the map at 8-11mph early game when you can't afford the big lowboy trailer and the truck to haul it is a pain.  also the low-loader trailer (lowboy) doesn't have a way to strap down the load from what I can tell, it may be there, but it doesn't appear in the tool tips, or appear when next to the trailer; so large equipment tends to shift when using it to haul.  there also isn't any crates or pallets to store the chicken eggs in in the default game, there are some player mods that do this, but I guess Giants isn't looking at what the mod community is doing, as including their own variations of the most popular mods would greatly improve the quality of their product.

my previous review stated that I wouldn't recommend this game; however I am clicking Yes, this time simply because its a break away from the normal games I play, and it has actually been fairly relaxing... yes, a bit stressful when dealing with rain, and you need to harvest (can't harvest in the rain/hail) but, growing up on a dairy farm, that's actually fairly accuate; most equipment have difficulty operating in those weather conditions, so most farmers wouldn't even attempt it.

Well, epic fail on many levels. 

(Physics) There are basically no attempts at this at all. FS17 with MR and other mods the tractors and vehicles felt great and added a lot to the game. Also, in FS17 the ground wasn't glass smooth which is a killer for me. In the end with FS19 you have plastic toys driving across glass.

(Graphics) Good and bad. Lighting in SOME instances is better and in others looks cartoony. Tractos and vehicles look OKAY mostly plastic like they drive especially the tires. 

(Gameplay) This is the only thing that has improved with a lot of new options, but in the end terrible physics make or break the game for me. 

(Verdict) FS17 is the better game with mods and close without. All the new flashy features do not mean crap when the physics are terrible considering most of the time is spent driving something...same thing happened to Mudrunner...made a beautiful game and ended up being worse because of crap physics. Same here.

I can't recommend this game in its current state. If they offered even a half refund I would take it & walk away from this series likely forever. Many of the same issues that have plagued this series for nearly a decade continue to do so. Giants tends to integrate a small handful of things in each new title that matter very little (i.e. moderate graphics & sound improvements which seemed to significantly sacrifice hd draw distance) into their mostly copy/paste model (with the exception of adding a couple of new maps which are both terrible this time) and little to zero focus on things that tend to make the game much less fun. 

A couple issues from the long list
-Atrocious AI (which they somehow managed to make worse than the 2 previous titles?!?)
-No policing/almost zero support to prevent rampant multiplayer trolling
-Don't even get me started on their broken physics

Edit: Servers were never great, recently they've become terrible. Players frequently lose connection to mp games!

They only way I could recommend this game is if someone who is considering purchasing it would be a casual solo player or someone who is able to line up a group on friends on a dedicated server & accepts the frustration that comes along with Giants (lack of) production.

Ah yes, FS19, the buggiest big-budget farming game you'll ever experience.

Not only are the controls extremely fucking clunky, and the hitboxes are absolute trash, the game in itself is boring without someone to play with.

Along with this, the multiplayer is buggy.
There's a train in singleplayer, where is it in multiplayer, why can't I use it?

Along with this, there's several bugs present in multiplayer, one of which being the fact that the terrain doesn't load in properly, meaning floating machines and livestock, and your player falling through the ground.

There's also night-time, which is extremely, extremely dark, to the point where you can't see anything unless you change the settings of your monitor to the point where literally anything else will completely blind you.

There's lots to be desired here, the game feels empty, and the fact that you can't use mods in multiplayer without having to rent a server or host it yourself, which for me and my friends isn't worth it since we don't play often enough to warrant it, is to be honest, completely idiotic on the developers part.

As for the AI, it's improved alot from previous versions of the game, but it's still completely braindead, to the point where a 6-year old could do it better, it's not that fucking hard to back the tractor up and turn it around WITHOUT hitting the other one that's standing 20 meters from the field.

The building system is a good addition, it makes it feel more like you're controlling your own farm, and that's a good thing, but the fact that you can't place the buildings anywhere except on your actual fields, despite you owning the area you want to place it on, is completely fucking braindead.

Not only are the controls fucked, the steering feels like it's made up of cardboard, rubber bands and glue. It takes 5 solid seconds of holding down A or D for the machine to even react.

As previously mentioned, it feels empty.

In FS17, we had solar panels and wind turbines built in, where are they now?

We had lots more machinery and things to do, where is that now?

----------------------------------

I get it, you need to push the game every year, just like every other big budget studio to get the fanboys to steal their parents credit cards and go buy it, development isn't cheap, but come the fuck on, atleast put some fucking effort into testing your game, and don't release it when it's less than half empty of content.

I would highly recommend this game to those who are into farming, this game provides some amazing, new, more realistic and improved features that the previous versions, just wait for FS 21 to come out. Let's go over the pros and cons.

Pros:

Better game mechanics
New brands
Improved graphics. (best to set the graphics to medium and brightness to 0.8 for the best results)
The ability to create a farm from scratch. 
Revamped currency system
Weed improvements
Clean GUI
Farmhouses for skipping the night
New crops
Realistic scaling
Horses in the game without the need for mods
Realistic skies
A better in cab view with animations (I personally like using first person when driving in the new FS19)
Better bill payment system 
More vehicles and equipment
Improved yielding system
You now have to buy land to use it
You get the crop damage from driving over crops that you see irl, you know those rows where there was spraying or using tools on the field. That is now added if you do not use thin tires. Slightly a con that you cannot see crop damage with thin tires because even the thin tires would do crop damage irl.
Ok, so let's get onto the cons or problems with the game.

No seasons
No rules on crop rotation
You do not have to wait for crops to dry when the rain stops
You cannot see your body when you go in cab view. 
A few random glitches that happens here and there with the physics. 
Weight doesn't do much.
The removal of greenhouses. 

Overall, I would recommend this game, maybe they could make updates to the game to add a few minor things I pointed out. At least we have a greenhouse mod. You will most likely enjoy the game, if not there's FS17 which I have on console. But I use my new computer nowadays. GIANTS studio will normally work on their previous game, revamp it, add more, improve it and then get a more realistic and better Farming Simulator. For now I can just imagine how perfect FS21 will be when they make it.

I honestly can't explain why this game is so much fun, you just need to see it for yourself. I've played FS17 and that was fun but I feel FS19 is more realistic looking, I haven't encountered any bugs (yet). I can't see any significant differences besides the looks from FS17 but it is nice to see John Deere in the game. I really enjoy this game and it is a great game to relax to at the end of the day.

Map-		6/10
Building-	        6/10
Multiplayer-  	7/10
Mechanics- 	7/10
Graphics- 	7/10
Kid Friendly-	Yes

Overall I would give this game a 7/10

Unmodded there is not much of an improvement to the overall gameplay when compared to Farming Simulator 2017 with the exception of the horses and two extra crops, Oats and cotton. Oats are just the same (gameplay wise) as the other crops but cotton needs has a special harvester and trailer to move it around. But it is the mods that make this game much better than just the vanilla version.

Overall I think that this game has much more potential than the previous farming simulator games in the series.

I think this is one of those "love it or hate it" games.  Most of the stuff I'm currently playing is FPS and vehicle shooter/sims like WarThunder (you can tell I'm a naval player by that comment).  I've also played Farming Simulator since FS15.

I really enjoy having  a game to casually derp around and build stuff without having to fight and defend.  It does require a little strategy if you don't want to go broke without using finance mods.  That said, this version has mod support built into it so you don't have to mess with unzipping mod packages into to game folders and that is really cool and convenient.  

The mission system is improved.  DLC stuff you bought for 17 seems to carry over or be available in the base game from the mod menu.  You get to do a bit of vehicle customization/optimization when you buy or rent them.  There are more crops and animals to manage.  The cloud/smoke/particle graphics are a better, but still need improvement.

All said, if you are a fan of the series, buy 19 (especially while it's currently on sale).  It's a definite improvement.

If you have played and liked any of the previous games in the series you will like this one. There are some changes from FS 17 but honestly none of them are very revolutionary and seasoned players will adapt quickly. Horses can be profitable and can be a pleasant diversion while waiting for your crops to grow. Lime and weeds alter how you care for your fields a little bit, but soon you settle into the new rhythm. Cotton can be quite profitable on a large field, enough so that you can get by leasing the expensive cotton harvester. Bottom line it is still Farming Simulator and still fun and relaxing, it just has a new coat of paint and few more bells and whistles attached, oh and John Deere if your into that sort of thing.

I have been playing this series since Farming Simulator 2013. I have always enjoyed these games and I believe i will continue to enjoy them in the future. Farming Simulator 19 brings a lot of new features including horses and cotton as well as a new mode where you can build your farm. This mode adds a lot to the game as you can make your farm as big or as little as you want. If there's one thing that I would like to happen, it is to make placing buildings a lot easier and remove the cost for leveling the land the structure is placed on. Many times it is not possible to place a building where you want it to be and when you can, you can't use it due to the way the terrain is changed. Other than that, this is a game I continue to enjoy and I would totally recommend it to people who like simulator games.

The Farming Simulator series of games continues to get better with each new version.

Having played since FS13 each version is more an evolution rather than a revolution.

While I think Giants does a pretty good job expanding and improving each new iteration of the game - but please understand it is the modding community makes this game worth buying and playing long-term.

If you like what this game has to offer - it's a no brainer recommendation from me. If you haven't played a farming simulator (or like simulator game) before watch some YouTube videos to get an idea what you are in for.

Plow, spread lime, cultivate, fertilize, sow, spray, weed, harvest, watch the crop prices, sell, buy new equipment - do over again...

Take care of your animals in between and plan your agricultural kingdom (or bankruptcy.)

With the right mods, its coming along fine.  Still missing some of my key favorites from FS17 however.  The in-game mod manager needs work.  There are some strange omissions in the list, and you will have to rely heavily on 3rd party sites to find some quality of life mods that overcome the terrible physics Giants continues to be plagued with - They really need to add a locking function to some of the forestry equipment so the claw doesn't drop things too easily or worse clip through logs!  

Giants also has stopped adding things directly to the game and now provides them as new official mods available in the in-game mod menu.  For multiplayer, this creates a few issues (see below)

For multiplayer, sharing mods - particularly as they get updated - is absolutely archaic.  Players can get SOME of the mods (only those found in the in-game manager) from a link, but it seems to be one at a time!  While I recognize the thinking - security issues - having an automated method of at least syncing the officially supported mods would be a godsend.  Adding a single-click method for downloading all mods - even unsupported - would be sensible.  At least some way to automate or simplify the system so players can keep up with server mod updates and new mods seamlessly.  Else they lose interest and simply stop, and we let the server rent expire.  Our solution has been to always feed the server owner's mods to a shared "read-only" Dropbox using a windows simlink.  We have not yet automated the download side of this but it should  be similar (most have stopped playing because of the hoops you have to jump through to get this done, and as such the server has been discontinued).  Working out a way to automate the syncing of mods between the hosted server and the owner's local folder has not yet been tackled, either, though it is minimal effort to do so manually. 

All in all, the visuals are decent, looking forward to more support and expansions.

great game 10/10

[h1] Don't get fooled by the positive reviews. This is my worst game experience so far... [/h1]

You are going to use vehicles, aren't you? It's a farming game. You're gonna drive them in roughly 98% of the time.
Well, you are going to get annoyed by the constant revving of the engines, because the incompetent dev team can't fix a simple sound bug for 200 days.

[b] Today it's 2019.06.30 and it's broken since 2018.12.12. That is TWO HUNDRED days of ignorance. [/b]
I say broken because there were no problems with the "day one" patch.

What's the issue?

You hop into a tractor and start the engine. The Steyr CVT has a base rpm of 850. Pleasant sound. It's great.
Now, you move forward, and all you can hear is a monotonous screaming of the engine. How is that possible?

Let's check it with cruise control:

Tractor at idle, the engine is at 850rpm.
Cruise at 1km/h on flat surface: 850rpm
2km/h: 1372-1390rpm
3km/h: 1892 rpm
anything more than 3km/h: 1892rpm

So above 3km/h, there is no ups and downs based on performance and load changes. All you can hear is one, monotonous and annoying engine sound. Imagine that you are in your car, and from the very moment you accelerate over 3km/h, you hear the maximum rpm, that can be 3000,5000,7000, whatever. It's annoying and not healthy, right?

Well, you can expect this in this game.

It WAS wonderful, I played literally hundreds of hours, let's say 300 hours with the 1.1.0 version.
But ever since I bought it here, and they broke it, I only install it from time to time, to enter, create a game, buy the machines, check the sounds, exit and uninstall. It's broken AF, unplayable for me and definitely unplayable for audiophiles.


HUGE potential, nice implementation, but ZERO commitment to offer a quality product to the audience and ZERO communication.

Needless to say, it's all about money, because they released a nice paid DLC in the meantime. Of course.
Priorities apply. Money over quality.

I have been playing the Farming Simulator series since FS09 although my copy of the game from back then was bought on ebay and mailed to me over the Atlantic ocean where i could farm wheat till my parents yelled at me to get off the family computer and stop rotting my brain playing games (I now make a living as a physics programmer for video games).  Back to FS19,  What I love most about the Farming Simulator series besides the fact I get to manage and run a farm with some of the most expensive and largest heavy wheeled equipment out there is that there is an amazing fan base making an endless stream of mods of everything from tractors and farm equipment to cars/trucks and what i find is the best part are the groups that make non farming equipment like construction equipment and emergency vehicles for when you just aren't feeling up to harvesting your field the size of Texas.  The best part about the mods is the company supplies amazing software so anyone can learn how to mod and put vehicles OR even lua script files ingame.  My review may not be the normal kind of review But i have logged hundreds of hours on each of the farming sim games and I never find it boring.

So, I'm biased a bit because I feel like Giants' business model focuses on them making money at the expense of the consumer rather than it being more of a mutually beneficial exercise. The game engine improvements are nice but often don't warrant having to purchase an entirely new game, new (or the same) DLC, and wait for modders to port their mods over to the new game.

SCS and their ETS2/ATS products have a much better, more fan-friendly model that's all about upgrading the game you invested in ages ago and paying for new content via DLC. With the various equipment licenses, mapping options and the like, Giants could be rolling in plenty of money without having to start over every time.

That all said, the latest edition of the game is "good". They didn't go backwards for the most part and added some much needed improvements to the engine. The visuals? Honestly, I don't see the difference (I've got a RTX 2080 and had a 1080 on FS17). Looks fine, bushes and trees still don't look any better so I don't see what the fuss was about. Ground still looks like same textures, etc.

However, there are some great changes: 

- Instead of the static animal sites on the map, you now place them with two sizes available for larger animals like cows and pigs.

- You can adjust terrain finally! Smooth out those weird mapping decisions made by Giants.

- Instead of  buying fields you now buy parcels that include 1 or more fields and other structures/sites. 

- There's a new contracts system which takes the old "jobs" system from FS17 and makes it more free form. You aren't currying favor to get fields at lower cost. You're just doing jobs like moving merchandise from one site to another and doing the usual field maintenance tasks as before. The rewards are not necessarily outstanding but they can be useful during the early game or when you have downtime and need the funds.

Meanwhile, there are things they completely missed despite the obvious logical step conclusion one would normally make:

- You can't remove junk/structures/etc. from plots you buy except for the base "home" plot you get when you first start. So there's this big chunk of land that has a fence and some broken down cars on it. Fun...but why? I can adjust terrain and sell starting structures but I can't pay a fee to clear some junk on my land? I can't buy a bucket for my wheel loader and shovel that crap off my land?

- The America map included in the base game is both insulting and frustrating at the same time: the place is run down like they picked the worst, most depressed part of the Rust belt and said, "Welcome to America". Meanwhile, it's more like canyon country than farm country. Small fields dotted around a plateau with a few big fields with windy roads barely able to accommodate a tractor, let alone a harvester.

- The train returns but in worse shape than before. At least in FS17 you could just leave the train wherever and be done with it. Now, the train automatically travels around the track whether you like it or not. You can still get into it and control it but if you aren't running it, it's trying its best to mow your equipment down as you get stuck because of the physics engine on the tracks. Yay.

- Horses are an interesting addition but they're overly simplistic and a big time sink. You can't use helpers in any way and the only way horses are valuable is if you run them regularly (ideally every day to maximize value increase). It's fun for a bit then it gets tiresome. You can only tab into a horse if you recently rode it. Otherwise, you have to head to the paddock and hop on again.  And instead of basic movement controls similar to your character, there's this acceleration system that puts the horse on auto at a particular cadence. It's awkward and takes away from the fun. It's not the end of the world or anything but I feel like the implementation is lackluster.

- Equipment and mods are like every FS iteration: you start with a decent if limited selection and modders fill the stable out. Giants has released some mods with old favorites and items you're used to but since they're mods and aren't paid for, it begs the question of why? Why not roll them into the base game? And the mods in-game (which tend to be safer than hitting up a modding site and hoping the one download button out of 20 on the page is the right one) are taking forever because the vetting process is slow, from what I've read. 

- And of course some minor quibbles are still there and still not addressed for whatever reason. For instance, my pet peeve is the fact that tractors shut off when you leave them. Hold on, you might say, there's an option to leave them on. Au contrare...it doesn't work right. If you go far enough away or tab through enough vehicles, they still turn off in that mode. You might say, per the words of the company, that it's a technological limitation given updates to active objects, etc. But then FS17 had a wonderful mod that turned them on and kept that state just fine. It hasn't come to FS19 yet (and may never, who knows?) but it's missed. Many a log has fallen from a logger because of an errant tab (you know, because Steam's overlay key combination counts as a tab in-game).

All in all (and this is the tl;dr part), it's a fine edition of the game. You get features you can use and the Europe map makes up for the lackluster inspiration of the American map (I miss that Montana map now from FS17...felt like home). The animal feature and terrain tools are big steps that are welcome but the horses and map design hamper what could be a great version of the game. Depending on your ideal price point, you aren't missing too much by sticking with FS17 if you have it and waiting for a sale on FS19. But if you really want those new features, you won't go too wrong by getting FS19 at this point. Plenty of mods have made it over and more keep coming.

I have owned every Farming Simulator since 2011 till now.  The Focus has continued to make what I would consider to be small upgrades but overall the game has not changed.  They have added animals and new equipment which add to the overall gameplay experience.  
This version has been even better than the last visually.  Everything is shiny and the power washer is used very often to keep the equipment looking that way.  
Along with that, the vehicles have been more stable.  I have only tipped over the $400k sprayer a couple times to the point I couldn’t put it back on the wheels.  I do warn you though, if you reset the vehicles, sprayer, planter, ect., you will lose all the seed or fertilizer you had in there.  I normally use a tractor and tip it back over to save the $9k worth of fertilizer or seed inside.
The Land editing tool I do like.  It does cost a lot to use if you are flattening a large area.  It will create better land to cultivate and harvest or make flat space to build an animal pen.  I will warn you though, you have to remove any trees from the land and stumps as well.  If you leave any piece of tree behind the Land edit tool will not work and leave spires of land where you were leveling.
The grind is what I would consider more massive then any of the previous versions.  Cultivate, add lime, plant, fertilize, weed, fertilize again… Oofta… Just for one or two loads of grain that gets sold at a small price.  I would challenge to say real farming is easier.  Even if you shut off everything and have the game on easy setting, making a good amount of money will take hours to accomplish.  I’m 40hrs in on easy, and finally own my own large seeder, harvester, tractor x2, sprayer,  and 4 larger fields.  Hitting the 10 million achievement is going to take forever.
Would I recommend this?  Yes of course I would.  I am a simulation guy and this is one of these games that should be played if only for the experience.  
Pros
Graphics have been upgraded
Vehicle stability has been improved over other versions
New Land editing tool 
Better way to buy Land

Cons
Land editing tool bugs
Massive grind to gain money
Night lighting

I was about to propose to my girlfriend when my roommate Joseph barged into the room out of nowhere, tripped, and fell over, breaking a glass table with his face. Totally ruined the mood. Now I don't know Joseph THAT well, don't even remember where he was from, but let's say I put my plans on hold to help him through his injuries.

Joseph had gotten a big glass shard in his eye, making him completely blind in that eye. He was walking around with one of those big cotton pads on his eye for a couple of months. Then suddenly, he disappeared, along with my girlfriend.

Apparently they'd bonded during the time after his injuries, and eloped together, leaving me behind without as much as a note. I tried to track them down, but never could.

In conclusion, if it hadn't been for Joe with his cotton eye, I'd have been married a long time ago. Where did you come from, where did you go? Where did you come from, cotton eye Joe?
