TLDR: Don't waste your money, buy FS 17 or FS 15 instead.

The Good:
The new version of the store where you can see the equipment better before buying is kinda cool.

The Bad:
Logging has been ruined:
- The controls for the Ponsse Scorpion are clunkier than in 15 or 17 and it seems to glitch out and drop trees more often.
- The Ponsse Buffalo is a joke and handles like one, can't even pick up multiple logs reliably.
- The New Holland wheel loader with log forks isn't tall enough to put logs in the log trailer without collideing with the side, so you have to place the forks between the pillars to be able to dump the logs,which only works in certain places on the trailer where the pillars are spaced out enough. Overall this thing is a joke and they should have kept the same wheel loaders that were in FS 17.
- Barely make any money due to the land buying mechanics, can't use as a starting cash method anymore.
- No stock map includes a lake drop off point for logs like 15 or 17 had.
Less brands than there were in FS 17.
Less placeables than in  FS 17.
Less brand/vehicle options for non-tractors.
So addictive jump on for a quick game, four hours later your still going and no end in sight.

I really wanted to like FS19, it has a lot of potential. Unfortunately the modding community needs to step in to take advantage of that potential. There are some mods out there, but the majority of them are just as broken and clunky as the game itself is. FS19 is visually much prettier than FS17, but its gameplay leaves alot to be desired.

As a note to the Devs (if you are even reading this)......Seriously? This is sad. You bring nothing to the base game thats new except John Deere being available from the in game store, and the pretty graphics. You have improved on nothing from FS17, if anything you've taken a step back.

If you are thinking about it, just wait. Stick to FS17 where the modding community has sorted things out. Give FS19 time to mature and pick it up in a year when its on sale.

farming simulator is a lot better than fs17 but you have to make sure you're pc is good enough

The good:
Lots of brands.
They added a store where you can see the equipment before buying it.

The bad:
The gameplay has not changed much from the original 2009 edition, less so from the 2017 version.
Many vehicles have defects in their models, many unacceptable considering they have licences (Valtra N series has both electronic and mechanical controls, since its a reused model of FS17 that was modified).
Maps have horrible defects not present in older Farming Simulators, for example, rail track crossings actually sit over the road instead of in it.

The game calls itself a simulator despite having all models of reduced weight and filtypes that most of the time weight less than half of their actual weight, for example 1000L of water weight less than 600kg.

Game does not posses gearboxes as promised, this combined with the reduced weight of vehicles makes tractors handle like Go-Carts (mods have been built in the past for this, ignored by Giants).

Zero crop simulation other than the amount of times fertilizer is applied and weed control (which happens all the time no matter what). Weather does not affect crops, there is no growing seasons so you can seed and harvest crops at the same time, eliminating any sense of order in the game. "Compaction" is incorrectly fixed by using ploughs, a tool well known to generate compaction (both by reducing the soil structure and the building of plough pans).

Horsepower of any type of harvester does not matter, you will still harvest at the same speed no matter if you combine has 200hp or 500hp and no matter the size of the header. Same with balers.
In any type of work, the only limiting factor is speed, not throughput, not pulling force. Mods simulating this have been build in the past multiple times, but Giants keeps ignoring them.

Ai workers are still not smart enough to drive on the road or do anything other than field work.
Ai drivers still miss spots, get caught on trees, stop unexpectedly, turn in the wrong direction, etcetera.

Manure or any product put on fields can't be cultivated over if the field has already been cultivated.
Dedicated no till drills still remove every residue on the soil.

Graphics;
The ambient in general looks oversaturated with light.
Far away mountains look worse than a 2005 game.
Metal textures lack roughness and many look like base colours in sunlight.
They couldn't even fix the problem of rain falling through roofs of buildings and vehicles, it basically rains inside the cab.
Wipers are just plain moving sticks, there is zero interaction of rain with windshields (a feature present in basically any car or truck simulator in the market a few years ago).
Crops look very spaced, nowhere near the density of a real crop. Same with grass.

A friend of mine who sells Ponsse machinery laughed at the way the Buffalo handles logs, IRL the machine can pick and load multiple logs in one grab with utter precision and force. In game the machine can barely grab one log, and the log tends to slide and glitch out of the machine, the claw has no force at all.
At the end forestry machinery ends up being frustrating and unrewarding to play correctly.


I could keep on going, however all you need to know is this is not a simulator, and don't expect nice graphics anyways.
All of this would maybe be acceptable if this was the third or fourth iteration of the game, however its the seventh, not considering the platinium/gold editions.

Now that the new 1.2 patch is out with landscaping, this game is much more enjoyable then it was before. I would now recommend this game, and it is a lot less frustrating with this new feature. I would give it a 7/10 instead of a 3/10 now. Here is what I wrote and what the game was like before the patch:

I pre-ordered this game about three months before its release. When I first jumped into the game, my heartbeat was 180, and I was so excited to see what this new, highly anticipated farming game had to offer. I have played every Farming Simulator game since the release of 2013 (including the mobile versions), but this game by far, is the worst one I have ever played. Keep in mind that what you find below is mostly my opinions, but there are a lot of facts, and/or I am doing something wrong in the game.

When I loaded up my first game on Ravenport, there was a few things that I just hated. I am playing on the "Farm Manager" mode.

The first thing that really got me frustrated was the new system for buying fields. When you start on the "Farm Manager" mode, you do not start with any land, you do not even own your farmyard (which is empty), but instead have to buy the farmyard, AND the field north of the farmyard if you want the whole thing. The land is ridiculously expensive and if you want the whole farmyard on the mode that I am playing on, you have to buy two pieces of land which drains about half of your starting money. Additionally, if you want your farmyard to look like a farmyard, it would take all of your money to actually create a normal looking farmyard with the farmhouse, sheds, etc.

Another thing that really got me mad was how the land gets flattened out when you purchase buildings for your farm. I love how it flattens out the land, but I tried to place a building and it put it like five feet off the ground, and there was like a 50% grade that I had to climb if you want to get on to the actual area of the placeable. I ended up selling the placeable but the pavement for the placeable was still there, and there was no way to flatten it out.

I tried using the four wheelers for loading seed and fertilizer, but it is really hard to get the trigger right for when you can dump in. I spent five minutes trying to load the seed from the back of the Mahindra into the seeder. Sometimes the trigger is on, but you have to press the unload button fifty times before you actually get the back of the Mahindra empty.

Most people haven't realized this, but you have to buy the animal pastures and they are expensive too. It is like 40k for a chicken coop and 300k for a horse stable. This isn't really a technical problem, but just one thing that I wanted to point out. If you play on the hardest mode, you would have to put in about one hundred hours before you could get a decent number of fields, stables, etc.

The dogs are honestly so bad I wish that they weren't even in the game. When the dog walks, it looks like it is having a seizure. It does not go after the ball, and it does not adapt to the terrain very well. I also really hate how in the CGI trailer they showed the dog in the vehicle with a farmer and I cannot figure out how to put the dog into a vehicle in the game. The dog doesn't fetch the ball when you throw it either.

One last thing I wanted to point out is the trains. The trains move at like 50mph and the railroad crossing bars aren't even down all the way when the train passes the crossing. I ended up getting hit by a train with combine, and went flying in the air, which made me really frustrated.

These are only a number of the plenty of issues that are in this game, but there are mostly good things about it such as the graphics, birds, and a number of other things.

I would personally not recommend this to anyone who is looking for a complete farming game. This game contains a lot of issues that would need to be fixed for the game to be somewhat substantial.

My honest review in comparison to FS17: 3/10

This game is just an update to FS17. It is not worth the $35 right now.

Despite all of this, GIANTS is great, so I am sure that they will be releasing a patch for this in the future. Until then, I will not be playing this game very much and will be sticking with FS17.

Thank you for reading my small novel, and I hope you enjoy playing FS19. Be careful before you buy though.

FarmSim gets a new version every 2 years on the odd years, and with each new version comes new additions. People are quick to complain about this and the other, but fact of the matter is they can't give us EVERYTHING we want up front, from a business point of view. This version has new crops (oats & cotton), new machinery (cotton & John Deere), in-game terrain altering tools, and a new farm animal (horse). The next version will have something new and so on and so on. People are quick to jump at the fact that there is no improvement over the previous (FS15) version, where there clearly has. This game has and always will be "about the mods" so you just have to be patient with that aspect, and FS21 will be no different. I've been playing since FS13 and have been nothing but pleased with the franchise, always waiting for the next installment to publish.

Played FS17 for a while, 100+ hrs even just the vanilla, Yet buying FS19 i just feel like i shouldn't of bothered, i wasn't expecting a whole different game, but at least maybe more detail then the previous game or maybe more mini things you can do. (NPC or even Buy tools to fix your own equipment)
Silage for quick cash is no longer profitable, or worth while. For a bale which is 4000, you'd get on average of £2,100 for 4000 of soybeans you'd get £2000 or more depending on a spike in the market, but considering that in "Real time" it takes too long to harvest grass then row it in lines, then bale it, then wrap it, then collect it then sell it. This extra effort use to be worth the tedious an long task in FS17. But now its Save time and cash on equipment for just simply planting soybeans hire a worker.  Thats Plant - harvest - sell, for the same reward which saves you 20 to 30 minutes of in game play. 

Graphics or pretty much the same, Theirs nothing that stands out to say they've been working on for the last few years,
Animals or not worth the buy either, the only way to earn money with animals is too stick your game at full speed and let the days roll past for next 20 mins in Real time. The hassle of constantly cleaning up, watering and feeding for a poxy £1,650 a crate of wool, just isn't worth the headache. 

Overall, i was left unsatisfied If you have FS17 i'd stick with that, you're really not missing anything. I'd  only recommend getting if its on sale for around £20 or less.

Ok, if I could give this one stars, it would only get 4 stars due to technical difficulties.  I had the same problem many others seem to be having with the game crashing at start up.  Somehow, I figured out that if I unplug my game controller (Wingman Formula Force GP with windows 10 driver) the game will start up every time.  I wait until the game is loaded, then plug the controller in.  It has a couple other minor glitches, but don't all games have glitches?

I see a lot of people who upgraded from version 17, and they are not impressed.  Well, I upgraded from version 15, and it was well worth it.  So, I am comparing it to version 15.

It is a bit harder to play than version 15, as you can't just go around mowing every ditch row on the map and make silage out of it, you have to own the land before you can mow it.  You also have to work the soil more, fertilizing twice and needing to control the weeds.  I like that because it adds realism.  I also like being able to lease equipment.  It also has a sleep mode, where you can go to your house and get some sleep.  I like this because I don't have to wait four or five minutes for night to pass (at 120 x time mode), it passes in about 10 seconds.  Being able to work for other farmers is cool, too.  (my grandpa used to have an 80 acre farm with more equipment than he needed, so he used to either hire out to other farmers or rent land from other people)  And being able to start from scratch (no land or equipment, just money) is very cool.  I wish someone would get around to adding the Farming Classics expansion pack, it would go well with starting from scratch.

So if you like FS 15, you will like FS 19 even better.

If you like the previous Farming Simulator games, or this type of low paced peaceful games in general, then you'll probably like Farming Simulator 19 as well - just be aware that the game remains very buggy and has significant performance and stability problems, much more so than previous games.

New stuff in FS19 is that the "normal" (aka Farm Manager) and "hard" difficulties now start you off without a pre-made farm; you merely get a bit of money and have to buy all the necessary machinery and place all the farm buildings yourself. This means you no longer have a stable/pen for each animal type that you can't get rid of, but instead have to place them wherever you want them. New is also that you can keep and breed horses (max 16 at a time though), and to feed the horses you can grow oats (or you can just sell the oats as any other crop). Also new is the ability to grow and harvest cotton, but it works just like every other crop in the game.

The actual game has however not changed much or at all since the previous releases and the majortiy of the new features (like dynamic hoses, the train driving around the map on its own, or chopped straw from harvesters being visible on the ground) are simply taken from mods for FS17. The additions do make the game more "real" and add to the atmosphere, but they are all minor visuals and have no actual effect on the gameplay.

The most noticeable changes gameplay wise in this version is that there's now 2 fertilization stages instead of 3, weeds will grow in all crops (this can be disabled) and have to be sprayed with herbicide to improve the yield. You also have to apply lime occasionally (this can also be disabled), and whether or not you need to plough the fields depends on what crops you grow on them. Should be noted that the AI helpers refuse to spread lime on a field that is fully fertilized, despite the game telling you that the field needs lime. The overview map is a little better at telling you what needs done to improve yields, but despite the visual changes to the menu with better sorting of the shop, it remains clunky and requires a lot of clicks to get to  the information you want.

The 3D preview of what machines in the shop look like before you buy them is a long overdue improvement. It lets you spin the machines around and updates as you change colours and configuration. Just be warned that this feature does however has its own performance problems and in certain cases the game will crash when changing the configuration on certain vehicles - like changing tires on a tractor. The way you buy stuff in the shop has however not improved at all and requires a minimum of 3 clicks/button presses to buy anything, AFTER you've decide what to buy. Since you can only buy big bags and pallets one at a time and have to approve the purchase of every single one, this terrible design very quickly becomes frustrating and it is mind blowing that anyone at Giants thought it acceptable.

The most grevious problem with FS19 remains the way it handles maintenance of the equipment. Although slightly more realistic than the terrible system in FS17 - machines now wear down and have to be repaired at a workshop rather than having a recurring incremental cost for upkeep - everything simply wears down way too fast to the point where the machines are worn completely out and become practically unusable after just a few (in-game) hours of use. 
Even on small fields this means you have to either use equipment that is much bigger than realistic, or use multiple machines at a time doing the same job (which the game doesn't handle very well), or you have to stop work multiple times to repair the machines. Considering how small fields in this game actually are it is ridiculous that things wear out so quickly and I highly doubt the manufacturers appreciate their machinery being depicted as not being able to handle working even a single small field before it has to go through major repair or replacement, but just as it was with FS17, Giants refuse to acknowledge that it is an issue and won't do anything to change it. Should be underlined that the idea is fine, but the implementation is awful and everything wears out about 100 times faster than they should.

It is obvious that, just like FS15 and 17, FS19 was rushed out  and didn't receive adequate testing or bugfixing, or any testing at all. Not only is the game much more unstable than the previous versions and will happily crash or lock up at the slightest error, especially in multiplayer, but the new engine has atrociously bad performance. It only uses a single CPU core and even on maximum graphics settings barely uses the GPU at all. The result is that the framerate is all over the place and often dips heavily for no apparent reason, while changing the graphics settings have no noticeable effect on framerate at all. Rather weirdly the framerate dips the less complex the image is and go up the more complicated it is for the GPU to draw. Meaning, standing still looking at a bunch of buildings with no animations will typically cause the game to drop to 25-30 fps, while driving through a dense forest with trees that cast individual shadows usually can be done at 60 fps with the GPU practically idling. Even stranger, the hardware load usually goes down along with the framerate, which is the complete opposite of what you'd expect. It does however mean that running the game with more powerful hardware has no effect on the performance because the engine simply doesn't work properly. My GTX1660 Ti is practically idling while running FS19 and the CPU barely does any work either, and yet the game very rarely comes anywhere near 60 fps and more often than not sits at 30-45 fps, which is only playable because the machines move so slow anyway, though the low framerate makes it difficult to steer properly when driving on the road.

On the visual side of things, the machines look amazing and nearly all the new equipment added to FS19 has dynamic hoses and more animated parts than the previous games. Everything else, like ground and building textures, are however of very low quality and looks ridiculously bad for a 2018 game, and only underlines that they have not improved whatsoever since FS13. Animations remain glitchy for many of the machines and when objects have to interact with each other, like picking up logs or pallets, it can get really bad with logs flying across the map and pallets that are glued to the forklift.

Despite improving the lighting of the game, many of the machines now have lights that don't work properly. As example, turning on the worklights on certain machines (like the NH forager, the Agco Ideal combine, just to mention some) will make the light cones disappear completely, which in turn makes these machines unusable at night because you cannot see a thing. Like with nearly every other problem with the game, Giants say this is merely visual and refuses to fix it, despite of how severely it affects gameplay.

Edit: We're now looking at 7 months since release and I just want to say that although Giants effectively refuse to fix any of the issues with the game, it is very much playable despite of how poor the overall quality is and how terribly designed some of the features are. This game truly is years from being ready for release, but just as has been the case with the previous games, Giants won't take the time they need to do it properly and will instead release a new game in 2 years, that will have minor fixes and even more problems.

I have played every Farming Simulator game since fs11 and I enjoyed all of them and put in many hours. I'm also not sure as to why there is hate for this game as some other reviewers have stated.... But the game will improve over time as Giants will work to improve the game more with updates/patches and there will be a lot of mods coming out for fs19 like in fs17.

Here are some of my pros and cons from my own experience of playing fs19 so far:

Pros:
- Updated graphics 
- New brands and some updated tractors.
- New animals (Dogs and horses).
- New crop types such as oats and cotton.
- Better engine sounds for machines.
-Weeds and birds "hanging out" in your crops.
-Building your own farm.
- Ability to change most equipment color to a color brand of your choice.

Cons:
- Night and day cycle seems to take a while to appear and transition.
- Not many options for placeables. (although many mods will be coming to take care of this as well as in Giants own modhub).
-No option like in FS17 to open and close doors and other things with the click of your mouse like in for example, in the Estancia Lapacho fs17 platinum DLC map where you could open and close the doors of the house/garage etc. (in the fs19 version of Estancia Lapacho the doors of the house and garage are all open).
-Buying pallets of seed and fertilizer. Giants should have included standard in the game a seed/fertilizer tank like in fs15 and below. (But this has been fixed with mods that recently came out on various fs19 mod hosting sites).
- Placeables are sometimes buggy in not wanting to be put down in a specific part of an area and even next to each other.
-Not having roads to get to various placeables that are placed down.

All in all, fs19 is a good game. It still has some bugs to be ironed out. But Giants will continue to improve the game with patches and modders will be making/importing their mods to make the game better.

Ah, Farming Simulator. It all started that one night, browsing the Steam store for games on sale, and I stumbled upon FS19, 20% off. And I chuckled a bit, thinking 'hah, that would have been funny. Sitting here, pretending to be farming!'
I searched up some streams on Twitch, wanting to see how people actually played the game, and I watched a guy filling a silage clamp for 45 minutes, talking about his day.
How I went from that, to purchasing the game - I don't know. But here we are, over 300 in-game hours later and not feeling a natural stopping point. I've purchased a complete setup - steering wheel, pedals, two joysticks and to top it off - a newly revived YouTube channel where I post my gameplay. TL;DR at the bottom.

FS19 is the follow-up to the smash hit FS17. This time around, there are some new crops, a couple new maps, and, what feels like, less equipment. Would I recommend this game? it depends on what kind of player you are. Let me explain.

I think if you're new to the FS franchise or skipped 17, you should pick this up. The starting maps will give you tons of playtime.

But if you are a returning FS17 player (like me, over 300 hours) then it isn't that simple. It mainly depends on how you played 17. If you spent tons of hours on the stock maps and using stock equipment, then this game will most likely be fine for you. 

Now if you played less than 20 hours on each stock and modded map on 17, I can't recommend this for you. Currently, as of May 2019, there are only a handful of really good modded maps for the game and not very much equipment. Though you can find more of each on other websites besides GiANT's own mod hoster, the good mods are few and far between.

TL;DR: If you're new to FS or loved playing the stock FS17 maps, get it. If you only played mod maps from 17, hold off until a sale or more mods are released. Overall, it's a solid game.

Have you ever participated a state of the art farm simulator? I know I have and simulators are meant to be realistic as possible. With this up to date technology not only have I been able to farm in a simulation but I have been able to simulate the very clothes that farmers wear on a day to day basis. John Deere cap, red flannel, and a pair of Jeans. It ain't designer but working men like myself put function over form. With this simulation, perfection comes at a price however, this simulator is not free but I assure you it is well worth it if you intend to pursue a career or are thinking of pursuing a career in agriculture. Get a taste of what being Farmer Joe is like before you're locked in for good. Farming Simulator 2019. State of the art. Be a farmer.

I feel I have played enough to get a good feel for the game, and have come to a few conclusions.

1.  It is a fun and challenging game that requires financial planning and crop rotation based on the current market demand.
2.  Contracts are a must in the early stages of your business
3.  The "helpers" you hire are dumber than the dirt they plow.
4.  It would be nice to see more tree crops and processing of farmed goods (i.e. apples, tree nuts, alcohols, etc).

While I hate that the helpers are so stupid, it does add a bit of realism to the game.  How many farms are manned by completely competent employees?  I just wish there was a way to train an employee that stayed with the farm for the long run.  That way you could have them drive the chaser trucks and sell stuff at the selling points.  Maybe a DLC or mod with such a feature?  Please????

The only decent things so far are Cotton & Sugar Cane being in the base game. Also graphics have a had an overhaul since FS17, the game is gorgeous but that's pretty much it for the pros.

Physics seem to have changed slightly from my point of view, bales and logs haven't launched me into space yet

I came from FS17 with high expectations, but it rapidly became blatantly obvious that Farming Simulator relies upon the good will and efforts of the modding community. Even with the few mods currently available for FS19, I'm essentially playing a vanilla version of the game. No real physics, no real weather, no seasons. Only a small handful of maps available, to bolster the 2 maps that come with the game. For me, with FS17, it was a way to pass the time, thinking about life as I nurtured my crops, but there was a diverse stockpile of mods to make things slightly more realistic. 

FS19 suffers because the modding community hasn't been able to transfer their FS17 mods to this latest version. And for me, that demonstrates how little Giant/Focus actually do to create a fantastic game. Farming Simulator definitely relies upon the unsung heroes, the people who don't get paid, to create content for a very basic game. It's as though the devs had a meeting and said, "Real mud? Real physics? Real seasons and weather? Nah, we don't have to do that. That's too much like hard work. Let the modders do it for us."

In truth, FS19 has the potential to become a great game (the graphics are slightly improved over FS17, and there's the option to start from scratch and buy tracts of land as you increase the size of your farm), but without the modders, it's not worth getting if you already have FS17. I stopped playing FS17 because I was hoping FS19 would be a vast improvement. It's not.

Farming Simulator 2019 is broken. Most mods are not updated from 17 to 19 and the game has been released for over 6 months (this apparently is due to differences in code blah blah blah (I'm not a coder), and I've been told that Giants is "working on it" for months). Animals disappear, other bugs are prevalent throughout the game. I purchased this game because I loved Farm Sim 2017 and thought, they’re really going to add some fantastic features to 19 (given the increasing success with 15 and 17), but the reality is the only difference is slightly better graphics, some more realistic bumpiness in the fields, and horses. Everything else is the same. Simple concepts that were modded in 17 could have very easily been built into this new release, and they just weren’t. The only thing that has kept me in the game thus far is the included John Deere assets. But after animals just disappearing and lack of mods, I’m going back to 17. I wish I could get my money back for this game. Somehow Giants messed this up, and considering how close it is to 17, it really baffles me as to why?

Updating as of March '19 - Pre-ordered this game and posted an initial review at release.  Lots of positive changes since then.  When the game first came out mods were few and far between. 
 But all that has changed.  Here's my breakdown - 

Pros:

- Detail.  The level of detail put into the equipment in this game is remarkable.  I really like the effort Giants puts into these games on that front.
- Mods.  Lots of mods
- Tons of different types of maps you can either install from game or get from the internets.  
  Large fields, small fields, combo of both - whatever you like.
- Tons of different equipment
- Passive income mods are now available too (greenhouses, windmills, beehouse, etc)
- Multiplayer - this game is a lot of fun to play when you have other people to play it with.  
  Don't get me wrong... single player career mode is perfectly fine in its own right.  But it is fun 
  to play this game with others.
- They have John Deere in this game (although somewhat limited)
- Fendt Ideal - if you've ever had the privilege of seeing one of these beasts in person, you'd  appreciate the level of detail in the game on these combines.  Easily my favorite.  
  The Massey Ferguson Activa being a close 2nd.
- Music - you can listen to different genres of music in the game.  I like that option.

Cons:

- I am a big fan of Agco, and particularly Fendt brand.  They don't (at least not yet) have any 
  Fendt   balers, sprayers, windrower, forge harvester and a few other things.  It's entirely 
  possible maybe someone made one or some of those available on a mods download site 
  somewhere.  Haven't looked there.  Would like to see them available in the game mods 
  menu eventually.
- Hired Workers - If you've played past FS games, you know you can hire workers.  And 
  maybe it's just me, but they just seem pretty dumb unless you're on a perfect square field.  I 
  wished they were more intelligent with working fields because there's a lot fields that are not 
  going to be perfect squares or rectangles.
- Traffic.  Cosmetic of course, but the traffic in the game is completely oblivious to you.  I find 
   that annoying and often times end up turning traffic off.  Wished there was a little more logic 
   to the traffic given how many maps have streets nearby fields.

If you've never played a farm sim game before but the idea perks you're interest, you're not going to go wrong with FS19.  This is a good game - if - it's something you are interested in.  I have quite a bid of mods installed, mostly directly from the mods menu in the game (some downloaded from websites) and I've never had any crashes or bugs or any crazy crap interrupt my gaming time.  Its been pretty stable for me.  I should point out that I don't use a wheel or other peripherals... I'm totally keyboard/mouse and perfectly content with that for now.  

I would like to see Giants build upon the career mode side of this game in the future.  Take sports games for example... there's an actual story your character follows as they build their skills and progress.  I'd like to see Giants incorporate something like that (optionally) for career mode.  Maybe you inherit a farm from a relative that passed and it's a bit run down, has old equipment, some of it broken or in need of repair.  And you start out rebuilding what once was; and eventually work your way up.  But part of that would include interaction with other NPCs - perhaps with reps at a farm machinery show or something.  They do have different career modes you can start in but from an immersive perspective they are all lacking.  Doesn't make it bad per se, but I think it would be a neat addition if Giants were build on those in the future.  

Overall 10/10.

The jury's still out on this one. 

It's Farming Simulator sure enough, but it feels rinse-repeated (no change there) and has launched with a lot of technical issues that are rapidly making Giants look like they aren't even testing their new releases before dumping them on Steam.

First off, this is NOT a simulator. It's a game trying (poorly) to simulate. There's an important difference!

It looks nicer, with a new shader running on their ageing game engine, but still falls short of the mark when it comes to graphical technical know-how. It has all the hallmarks of a Giant's designed game. Back in the early days there was a rumor that the dev's were originally engineers that decided to make a game. It shows. Every item is technically oozing with detail, from implements unfolding, to fine details in the vehicle models. But the overall graphical artistic talent is lacking, leaving the landscapes feeling dated and lackluster. 

Their use of modern rendering techniques feels messy too, with some details looking excellent, while other distance rendering techiques look like a game from the late 90's. When combined, it delivers a mish-mash that doesn't quite come together properly. For example: Blurry distance textures on boundary areas (to give the impression of Depth of Field), with regular in-game trees that are clearly in sharp focus, with no shadows. It looks cut'n'pasted and honestly, very ugly! Why can't they just use Bokeh like most other games that attempt similar visuals? Only Giants know the answer to that one.

I can't help but think Giants need to employ some proper graphic artists and developers to bring this game into the modern day, before it becomes a laughing stock.

Having played this game for many hours with my wife on a dedicated server, I can confidently report that some of the equipment needed doesn't work as you'd expect either. A simple example is a long trailer that is designed to collapse down to cater for vehicles and implements, so the player can transport several items over long distances. This sounds excellent in theory, but in practice it's a disaster waiting to happen. Often the trailer bottoms-out on invisible bumps in the road along your journey and catapults anything it was carrying into the direction it was travelling. Even inspecting the road that it's stuck on reveals nothing restricting it, leading to the thought that it's a collision box on the terrain that's been left unoptimized. This is a classic example of Giants not even testing the [i]only[/i] trailer of this kind available (at the moment), on the roads they themselves designed. Simply raising the trailer height would solve the problem.Very shoddy!

Another example of broken implements are the KUHN items that have been added from what I assume was FS17's DLC pack. It's nice that they added them, but again they are more problematic than anything. The 4 part seed box, plow, harrow, seeder set that all connects together, only adds to complication when using an AI driver to work the field. Sometimes it's hard to even change the seed setup, but the most common problem is the AI randomly changing direction at the end of the field if you've had to refill it part way.

Terrible AI programming! Honestly, if this is the kind of AI our future holds, there's no way Elon Musk need worry about AI taking over the world, because it would probably try to download itself into a kettle and boil itself..

Finally, the physics. There's no change from all previous farming simulator releases, no matter what the fan-boys try to tell you. I picked up a pallet of seed, only to have it glue itself to the tip of the front loader forks, refusing to budge. When I decided to try and lift it, the pallet raised slightly, then catapulted about 20 feet into the air, as my wife and I laughed, awkwardly, trying to hold back our frustration at the stupidity of the physics system.

It's a game with a truly love/hate connection. Which is a shame, because for me at least, it used to be a labor of love to work a farm. Now it's becoming tedious as I work around all the old gripes, 10 years on.

I'd usually recommend this franchise, but not this time, as I feel Giants need to take notice of the unhappy customer base.

I have a mixed review for this game. So I'm going to list the pros and cons of this game compared to the 17 version. 
Pros-
- 19 has slightly better graphics than 17
- 19 allows you to edit the terrain and reform your land without a mod
- 19 added horses, which is pretty cool
Cons-
- I only have 1 real con, 19 has a different platform making it more difficult for users to create and edit mods, because of this there are far less mods available (only so far hopefully), also because of this, some of the available mods have bugs or just flat out do not work. It's been 4 months so far and no seasons mod yet. All of the great mods from 17 like, seasons, real tire dirt, real ground response, courseplay, follow me, farming tablet, gearbox, more realistic gameplay, proseed, gps, and other great mods, are not available for the 19 version. If these mods start coming out I will upgrade my review to a positive review no doubt, but until then, I say 17 is the best sim so far. I'll still recommend this game though because, hey, farming simulator flat out rocks to begin with.

(in my opinion) this is turning into the Call of Duty franchise. It started out great... But slowly declined in quality, effort, and finally the game play itself. I hope Giants does a better job on FS21 (or whatever farming game they do next). Don't waste your money on this game  (but like i previously said this is in the early life cycle of this game, things could change).... I have played many of the previous versions of the game and I must say, the most playable is still FS 15.  FS17 was released way before it was a polished product and to this day still has unresolved issues with crashing and hired workers not doing what they are supposed to do.  Now FS 19 is out and the state this game is in is almost unplayable.  

You will get the farmboi's claiming the game is fun, but there are so many issues that just break the game, it isn't much fun.  

First off lets discuss their shipped maps.  These are just stupid.  Almost all farms have huge piles of garbage on them that cannot be removed other than editing the map and removing them totally from the game.  Who wants a farmyard with huge piles of scrap iron in them?  These maps also have the ability to put many "placeable" items in them, (which is required if you are starting from scratch), but WHERE you can place them is severely limited.  If you cut down a tree, there is a 90% chance it will block you from placing anything where that tree was.  Furthermore, the distance with which you can place these items seems to have an excessively large "no build zone" around each placeable object.  This will, under many situations make building placement very awkward and restricted.

The shipped US map in now way shape or form emulates North American farms.  This farm looks more like something at the foothills of the rockies, NOT the grain belt of the US or Canada.  If you're going to emulate the primary grain production of the US, get it right!  When is the last time you have seen mountains in Oklahoma or Texas?  Seen any mountains in Kansas or Iowa?  The way that US farmland is depicted is almost insulting.  They seem to think that the US is still living in the dark ages.  I have seen farms in the US that would dwarf anything in this game. 

These maps are also pooly designed when it comes to placement of items.  For some reason, power poles are placed every 30 feet which makes getting around the map, awful.  So many of the poles are placed so close together that you cannot enter the field with the larger combines with an attached header since it doesn't fit between the power poles.  Where I live, there are ZERO power poles any more.  There are the huge 3 phase lines and the major production lines that connect the substations to the production facilities.  The lines that go from the substations to the various farms are all buried and have been that way for over 30 years.  The telephones lines have been buried for more like 40 years.  Is Europe that assbackwards that they are 40 years behind?  I find that hard to believe!  

They still have not fixed the woodchippers, since they seem like their ability to grip and pull tree's is very lacking.  The least amount of drag causes the tree to stall and not enter the chipper.  This has been an issue all the way back to FS 15 and it's still not addressed in ANY of the previous releases.  The physics that effect trees is just awful.  When pulling a tree with the Ponsse Scorpion, the tip that touches the ground swings around and slides sideways with such ease, it looks very stupid.

Ahh, but the machines themselves are correct right?  laughable, they are not even close.  Most of the combines have a turning radius less that half that of their real world counterparts.  The steering on these vehicles is just horrid.  Using the mouse and keyboards with factory settings makes the game unplayable.  There are settings in game to lessen these delays somewhat, but they fall horridly short.  

Best way, edit the game files (yes the ones they tell you not to), because their settings in the game are nowhere near real life.  I have had to edit every vehicle that I use on my farm to bring them into their real world counterpart specifications.  I think maybe their game testers are pet monkeys!  No quality control managers I know would ever publish anything that is this far away from what they actually are.  It's not inventing the items, these items already exist, have known parameters and controls.  But Giants seems to think that they can just splat on a bunch of stupid parameters and settings and no one will notice.  Uhm, there's a "new" thing out here in the real world called "Google", maybe have the devs check it out?

Hired helpers, oh lord, these guys are so broken!  They are constantly stopping their harvest with  "Unknown reason" and the only way to get them going again, is to hop in, and driver the combine again for a fair chunk of the field until the "Hire Worker" function will actually work again.  Furthermore, they very often will leave strips at the end of every field, and sometimes refuse to harvest the last 6 foot strip along the side of a field.  "Helper X has completed their task".  Uh, there's still half a mile long 6 feet wide!  

Now it is very obvious that these devs have never visited a US or Canadian based farm.  Land in Canada at least as well as the US is laid out using latitude and longitude.  As such over 90% of the land is laid out in "quarters" .  This means that most fields in North America are laid out in half-mile by half-mile fields.  Perfect squares.  Hence the basic land descriptions  "SW XX XX XX WX" (Where XX is the numbers that designate the land location). This is what North America was founded on.  The fields may be different shaped due to various hills, valleys or water (Sloughs, lakes or rivers), but the base field is square, always square.

European fields may be helter-skelter and unusual shapes, but North American fields are based on squares.  Canada uses the metric system, which is bloody stupid.  The country was drawn up and divided up by miles and even takes into account the curve of the earth with "Correction Lines".  

Farmland in the US and Canada, for the most part has very few fields with only 40 acres or less,  They may have crops at that size by subdividing a quarter section into several fields, but the fact remains, your base "Field" in the US and Canada is 160 acres (quarter section or a half a mile by a half a mile).  The US map never reflects this at all, as all fields are hap hazard and chaotic.   

On a side note, the game is constantly suffering from micro freezes, crashes, and freeze ups.  Hopping between many vehicles using the map eventually starts to disable map commands, such as "escape", "enter vehicle" and "hire worker" which will shortly thereafter cause the game to freeze totally disabling everything and causing the player to be stuck in place unable to move, open the map, or open the purchase interface.  These issues seem to get even worse if you install mods such as coursePlay.  CoursePlay has it's own issues, but at least it's devs are attempting to fix it and are constantly releasing updates via GitHub.  Giants?  Not so much.  

I have since quit playing FS 19, since it's just frustrating having to constantly hop for one field to the next starting hired workers that have quit working for "unknown reason".  Some of the larger maps out there, (mod Maps since the ones that ship with the game are just lousy), have over 60 fields, so as your farm grows, the amount of microfreezes approaches that of totally game breaking.  Having  vast amounts of machinery working in the field with hirelings means microfreezes about every 5 seconds or so.  The game starts to stutter so much, you have to turn it off.  

Also having even 30 fields and trying to maintain all the machinery with spraying, cultivating, fertilizing and harvesting, just causes so much hassle with hired workers stopping constantly just causes frustration.  Sometimes the hired workers do strange things like driving their machine way off the field in a straight line, veer way off course.  These instances are usually followed very shortly by a complete game crash, lockup or parts of the GUI locking solid

There are more issues, but sadly, I have reached the character count limit/post.

And FS 19?, well graphics were supposed to be the big improvement of this installment, but it falls truly flat. There are mods out for FS15 and 17 that make those games look better than this one. And what's with the empty towns? The previous two installments had people wandering the streets. Now? Nothing. It's like an apocalypse happened. Seriously. It's creepy. If you have the DLC for FS17, then there's really not much here for you. Except maybe the bouncier suspensions, and horses...yay. Now you can bouncily drive or jerkily ride around the dead landscape desperately searching for another living being that's not a zombie in a car. Yay. In short, if you have FS 17, then forget about this one.

OK.. let me start by saying I've been playing FS since the 2011 Platinum Version.
And I've always loved the game and this one is no exception, Graphics have been improved well over what all the others have been but that is about all. It has more glitches in it then almost any game I have ever bought out of the gate, and if they would give me a "REFUND" I would take it...
I've played a number of maps in it besides the 4 default maps and they all have the same problems.
#1. Even if you own the whole map I time and again end up with the message "YOU DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO THIS LAND" not allowing me to harvest trees that I own, or even mow grass...
#2. Even on a logging map "Black Mountain Montana" for one I again ran into the above message. And even after harvesting over 200+ trees i trued to plant a new stand of trees after clearing the stumps it came up. "TO MANY TREES TO PLANT HARVEST SOME MORE"??? On a Logging Map and this has happened on all of them as well.
#3. Again on all maps once you place your animal pens and put in your animals you can not feed or water them for at least 8 days..
#4. Even though your chickens will generate eggs where the cartons of eggs are put there is supposed to be a pallet for the eggs to be put on as they are produced, "BUT" No pallets are put into place making you have to load them onto the trailer or into your truck manually, Unless you place a pallet there yourself first.
  I will give them one thing they do continue to put out mods but mods are useless unless the base game works properly.
  They need to quit putting out content and just fix the game,,,
  I've tried contacting Giant's and they said send us your log file and we will get back with a solution "BUT" Big Surprise I've heard nothing back from them.
  I am going back to FS 17 while it may not be as polished at least it works and is more then playable.
  On a final note I really wish I could say buy this FS and you won't be sorry, But sadly I can not... 
  If this is your first one get FS 17 you'll be much happier...

This game was born on PC and now the inevitable shift has happened. That shift is when a PC game gets big, supported by community mods that make it what it is, the dev's switch focus to console where the money is at. This has unfortunately happened to FS. I am bored beyond belief. The new graphics are lackluster and cater to console performance. The draw distance is pathetic. Many objects do not render until you're about 50m away and there's no option to change this even with a high end PC. On release the economy was broken along with the outrageous cost to buy land. Some fixes have come but still finding it very uninteresting. I can't explain the graphics but they just look washed out. The equipment is bright with clean lines and no real definition looking out of place on the bland backdrop. Like everything is toy and made of plastic. All I can say is that to me it certainly looks different than 17, but not better at all. 

The default maps are catered to the Euro farmers. Small, clustered, bendy, obstructed curvy layouts with tiny fields. There is an uninspiring amount of equipment for purchase. Nothing new and exciting as far as I can tell. Was excited to see Mahindra but the only vehicle there is, is a stupid UTV. Mahindra makes tractors but there aren't any in the DLC.....

While there have been gameplay improvements from FS17 to FS19 (inclusion of John Deere, land ownership, terraforming), and a graphical overhaul, I cannot recommend this game.

The game was released with bugs, some of which were quite annoying, and while they have made efforts to fix their broken release, there are still issues. Several well-known and respected modders within the community have left (their reasons being their own), and the handful of quality modders remaining refuse to work with Giants (their reasons being their own).

The maps are...a very real representation of Giants' opinion of those they deem to be lesser beings. Ravenport (the US map) and Estancia Lapacho (the South American map) are both covered in trash and generally look like run-down ghettos, while Felsbrunn (the SUPREME German map), is well-kept and beautiful - a model of neatness and good housekeeping.

This is insulting on a level that I cannot simply overlook. Coupled with the lack of attention to the community, I cannot recommend this game, nor any other Giants title at this time. I do hope that they will learn from their mistakes, but my business with Giants is done.

This was my first Farming Simulator game, so I can't say how it holds up compared to the rest of the Farming Simulator games.  What I can say is that this is an okay game.  It's very overpriced.  If it wasn't $35, I might have recommended this as a fun time waster for people like me, causal players.  I don't know how hardcore players who stress about having giant fields and tons of money can do it.  I nearly throw my laptop across the room trying to harvest a small field because at least one vehicle gets stuck on the smallest incline. 

There are a lot of problems with this game.  First, the physics are terrible.  I went into this knowing they weren't good, but didn't expect it to be that big of a deal.  It is.  It makes driving a pain in the butt, because there is a decent chance you'll end up getting one or more vehicles stuck somewhere.  Although I've got to admit, driving my tractor off a cliff to get to my farm was the highlight of that save file.  I took like no damage.  And did this several times.

Another big problem is driving the vehicles.  Without attachments its all fine and dandy.  But the moment I added attachments, certain necessary maneuvers were a pain.  Is it realistic?  Yes.  It is still annoying?  Yes.  For example, I had to back up against a barn to sell the hay bales I had.  Took me like 30+ minutes.  I would've left, but I'd already spent waaaaay too long getting the bales all packaged up.

There are also some annoying bugs.  Or maybe the helper AI is just complete garbage.  I've had them plow like half a field and say they're done.  And yes, I had the money to pay them and there was nothing in their way.  But when the helper AI does work, it's really useful.  

Also, small note, the weeds are crap.  I liked the idea, but in reality it was poorly implemented.  I'd have fields at 0% weeds, turn around to go do something, and within minutes it was at 100%.  I swear it goes from 0% to 100% randomly.  The only time I saw it less than 100% and more than 0% was after spraying weed killer.  A few spots were at like 1% or something.  A little warning would be nice.  Weeds grow fast, yes, but they still take time to grow, and you can see them growing before they're the size of your crops.

I wanted to like this game, I really did, but it has so many problems that ruin the experience (for me at least), and left me utterly disappointed so it's just not possible. It has some nice features as well, i can't say it's all bad, but there's definitely more negative than positive here. Okay.

First of all, the graphics. Even with all the settings maxed out this game still looks like a work-in-progress. Some of the machines have nice details though, but the environments, buildings, cars, and pretty much everything else looks just plain unfinished. Not cool. I know that graphics don't make a game, but in this case making the game look even "ok" by 2018 standards, would be nice, especially in a game that's supposed to be very immersive and realistic. 


Physics in the game, i have a big problem with. You see, in real life, heavy machines like tractors, logging equipment, harvesters, trucks, and so on... are big and heavy. In the game, some of them handle like a three-wheeled go-kart. Try loading a logging truck full and drive it to the sawmill, you'll see what im talking about, the whole thing wobbles left and right like it's drunk. Controls feel wobbly and too fast, like you're driving something totally different than you actually are.

Another issue is with the logging parts of the game. Like big equipment, also huge logs are heavy, but in the game you can toss them around like tiny sticks, yet despite that, the crane in the forwarder is unable to pick up more than one log at a time, this is highly unrealistic (maybe not if you'd have a smaller forwarder, but with big ones like the Ponsse Buffalo or the Komatsu in the game, you're not supposed to have issues like that) and makes for a seriously annoying gameplay. 

I know you're supposed to mod the s*** out of this game, and so I did. Better maps, better equipment, more stuff, this and that. The best mods would be the maps, since the original two maps are just plain boring and uninteresting. I liked the "Grizzly Mountain" logging map, and the "Michigan 2.0" farming map much much more than the originals. I also downloaded a mod to make logging more realistic, and while it definitely took it in the right directions, it wasn't right enough and the physics issues mentioned before were still there. It made some things nicer, sure, but not enough. Bummer. 

Surely, there must be something positive as well? Yes. The amount of equipment available and the number of functions they can do, is pretty nice. I like the detail of mud/dirt on your equipment the more you use it on the field, it's pretty much the only nice visual thing in the game. The gameplay can be "ok" at best, it's not bad, but my expectations were so much higher, and no I don't thing they were too high.

I operate forestry/logging machines in real life and I was really looking forward to seeing how it was all created in the game. I was left very disappointed. The farming bits of the game are slightly better done, if that's all you want to do then the game can ALMOST be recommended, with heavy modding of course. Wait for a sale. 

All that being said i must add that I really hope Giants improves this game in the future, there sure is potential for a great game. Please put more focus on logging, not just adding more machines, but the physics of the logs and the features of the machines themselves. 

My overall score would be a 5/10 (the game in it's current state and without mods), not recommended.

I have stuck by the side of Giants since FS13. I have made multiple maps for each since then as well, and while I feel that the series has always taken big steps forward, FS19 has taken some steps backwards. 

The placeable system has completely ruined map making and game immersion. Who the hell wants to have 300 cattle in a .25 acre plot of flat (big emphasis on flat) ground. It just doesn't work near as well as the old way. Why change it if it's not broken? Oh right, console players....

Aside from the modders perspective, this game just feels rushed. Released with bugs and literal errors on Giants end that they seem to refuse to take seriously. There has been an audio bug since day 1 in server play. (Very annoying). They have done nothing but push out old content from 17 into the mod hub. However, I will commend them on the terraforming update, that was a very welcome addition to the game. 

It seems that they have began catering towards the console side of things, forgetting the platform that made them HUGE in the first place. Pushing this "e-sports" nonsense like it's some kind of sporting event. FFS Giants.... it's farming. 

In conclusion, I do not recommend this game at this time. Wait on them to fix it, wait on them to give us content that should be in the game from the beginning. Don't support this growing trend of money hungry devs who do not care about you. Especially since this game has taken a turn towards more console friendly, dumbed down, "e-sports ready" gameplay. 

TLDR- Giants is focusing more on pushing out content rather than fixing the glaring issues that have been there since day one. PC players are the last of their worries now as console oriented gameplay has ruined the series, IMO. (I'll argue this point to the death.)

Unless it's animal breeding, this farming simulator can be quite boring when it comes to crop cultivation. Forestry is possibly the most fun out of all the things you can do, additionally it's the best quick profit. It's fun turning the whole country side into a complete forest. These pine trees can grow nearly anywhere, even grass will do. 

Negatives that i noticed is random stuttering every second. I can play this game in highest settings at reasonable FPS, however from time to time the game goes into a complete unplayable lag hell. I don't know what's causing it, i did many things to fix it but none helped, it's a bug for sure. It's really hard to tell what is causing it, usually it starts to happen when using any lifting machine... since i do mostly forestry i get this quite a lot. Secondly the game pad should receive a lot more attention in this game, In "Euro truck simulator 2 " it is fully adjustable and easily you could control the turning speed sensitivity and all other things. It's a small feature which could improve the game beyond words. I keep crashing into things i should've never crashed into, because i have barely any control over a game about basically drivable machinery!
Graphics are good but for those trying to finish off a massive field quickly and straightly, i would like to give an advice... don't strain your eyes with blurred together textures, and so turn down the texture antialiasing. 

Verdict, well, It's a game still, but I'll give a 7.5 out of 10. why not 8.5? If they fix the issues above it would be quite a lot more fun.
The pricing for this game seems a little over the top at the minute, it has the looks and feel to it that's good, but it needs work on improving the interface and some serious look into bugs, that have potential to stop the player from playing all together, it's very annoying at it's best as it happens randomly.
I recommend to any creative and crafty gamer. But i won't recommend to any fan of Euro truck simulator as there's barely any cool radio features or song to chill with, nor any decent controls management.
it won't open for me

I really enjoy this game as a way to wind down, it is low stress (once you learn what to do)

I must warn you that this is heavily mod reliant, you will have much more fun when you load the game with user content.

The downside to this game is much like many other simulators, they have very little driving you.
Once the initial startup is done there is no challenge, nothing is going to come ruin your crops so that the bank loan causes parts of your farm to be repo-ed  there are 3 maps that the game provides you with, and each has a few points that you might sell crops at. However the games economic difficulty never truly challenges you. if 1 location sells too cheap the other is normally fair. at the hardest setting the prices leave a small margin for profit but i never find myself selling anything at a loss. Certain crops are always more profitable than others the market has no real demand built in to stop you from over producing the same crop over and over. Do not get too excited for horses they have many problems. first being that you buy full grown horses at 5k$ then raise them by caring for them (very simple) and riding them 5 minutes, doesnt matter how fast or where or if you jump or not,  nothing you do matters just 5 minutes on them.  then after about 8 days of care they sell for 50k$ 10Xs the money with minor costs and a painful time sink.

repair systems are also lacking go ahead and repair stuff from time to time but its just clicking a button there is no tires flat or blowing an engine simply your repair bar is low pay money.

I still recommend it for a bit of fun if you have some friends willing to try the multiplayer can be enjoyable share a farm or split into teams trying to buy up more of the map race to 100 million dollars or something of the sort.

It's always fun to play one of these [i]Farming Simulator[/i] games. I've had them since [i]Farming Simulator 2013,[/i] and enjoyed each of them for what they offered. The graphics are stunning, and make for some nice landscape scenes for us picture taking people, and the music is fitting for the game.

There's really not too much stress here once you figure out what to do, and what's needed to do it. Plenty of help in the [i]Game Forum Guides,[/i] and the in-game help menus offer assistance as well. I love to experiment, and learn what your equipment can, and can not do.

There's Bailing, Cultivating, Fertilizing, Harvesting, Logging, Planting, Plowing, Watering, and Weeding. You can Buy & Sell your Equipment, Harvest, and Supplies. Tending to Livestock is also available. Now for the first time, you can go horseback riding, and transform your land or fields to suit your fancy using the [i]Terrain Editor.[/i] It's all here.

I like moving at my own pace, and for me, this is the right game to do it in. Give it a try.

I'm new to Farming Simulator, so keep that in mind.

I picked this game up on a whim, and was quite quickly taken by how much I enjoyed it. I've played farming games before, but not *simulators* - usually I'm playing something like Stardew Valley.

Watch a few LPs, and if it looks like something you would enjoy, give it a try.

The modding community is hard at work putting out new content for this game - noticeably faster than the developers, in fact - and they've been bringing back lots of content that was in previous titles as well (including maps). If you want the maximum amount of mod content, play Farming Simulator 15 or 17 - but the graphics update for this game is pretty noticeable to my eyes, so if you'd like it to be prettier to play, get this one and just be patient with modders.
this is a fantastic game

Confusing for beginners - 1 Hour in of staring at the screen, trying to buy a farm, cannot for the life of me figure it out. There's basically no tutorial and no simple ui - go here buy this. It's like flight simulator - it's confusing.

FOR NOW I would not recommend this game. Sure, better graphics and all that, but the playability is rather 'limited' before it gets tedious and boring. I have played previous versions for more than a 1000hrs, but what really made those versions interesting for me and many (maybe most) players were some mods like Courseplay (and Seasons) for example to take over the tedious chores and give me more room to organize and enjoy farming. I would have thought that Giants would have understood the importance of these few mods to many FS-fans, and would have given those modders more support for creating new versions of their mods BEFORE the release of FS19. For now I keep on playing FS17 with - amongst others - a good working Courseplay and keep FS19 on the shelf until the modders have upgraded their fantastic mods. Unbelievable Giants does not realize the impact of some mods on the value and playability of their product, rather disappointing... These modders deserve more recognition. A lesson for me before I ever buy a next FS edition: wait a year or so after a new release until modders have written their new scripts.

ADDED 3 Feb 2019: a beta of Courseplay has been released (apparently with - too late -support from Giants), but it is an utter disgrace that Giants managed to mess up the setup of the only controller made specifically for FS, the Logitech/Saitek G Farm Simulator bundle, and in-game command shortcuts appear for some Playstation controller instead. So I stick happily with FS17 for now.

Going on about 110 hours total now, this game is amazing! This is the first Farming Simulator game that I've played and absolutely love it! There are a bunch of negative reviews that are for specific things, yes the game could use a lot of updates and added content that feels like it's just flat out missing. However I suggest using ModHub, it quickly replaces things that are missing from the base game. (I have 16+ mods running regularly) I never saw myself as someone who would ever sit down and play "a stupid farming game" however, my cousin let me play it for a couple hours on his PS4 and I was instantly hooked. I bought it on sale for $31.99 and it is by far the best and most thrilling game I have. Thrilling? Yeah, it is slow paced but the dopamine comes flowing into your brain after selling that large harvest you've been working towards. I only have 2 worlds, the first one was learning the controls and basics of the game, then messing up cause I decided to lease things and went broke. The second was on Farm-Manager and I am doing better than ever. I have also learned things I never knew in real life. I never knew anything thing about farming, let alone even planting a plant. I now understand the different steps in taking care and improving your yield and what the animals eat and how a farmer were to go about their days.

Pro's
- Great time passer
- Super fun
- Multiplayer is actually decent
- Overall solid fun game, also it's new so expect updates and addins

Con's
- Feels incomplete
- Bugs and lag spikes tend to happen even on the most beastly gaming rigs
- Helpers are amazing but dumbassess at the same time. Gotta love them

TL:DR - While I say I recommend the game, wait to purchase it. Wait for Giants to fix some basic quality of issues, and/or for mod support to be in full swing. Bugs are minimal, gameplay is always smooth and satisfying.

UPDATES: They have updated the game some, AI is still horrid but atleast now we can paint terrain and terraform. Which definitly helps bring immersion into the game, you can make your farm actually look like a farm. Still some minor irritations from me though, it's almost like Giants is just relying on the modders at this point to really make the game, espesially with placeables. Like come on, give me a proper default hay loft or some variety in tractor storage sheds.

The game looks amazing, a definite step up from previous titles. The lighting is probably my favorite added feature to the game, and the random wildlife, more random outdoors sounds. It really makes the game feel alive to me, which FS17 lacked.

It plays very well, bugs are few and far between, while the number of brands is down this time around, the vanilla equipment availble is much better than FS17 in terms of usability for my play style. The incoming mods are very promising looking, Giants really stepped up their game for supporting modders. Which in my opinon is a gift and a curse, sometimes it feels that Giants kicked their feet up for some features and said "eh, the modders will fix it, leave it broken for now". But in my honest opinion, I think it's time for Giants to move to another Game Engine, on that is more 2018. They are doing great things wtih this older engine, but it's time something new.

The games AI somehow took a giant step back. Which is wildly frustrating, because by default maps now have odd shapped fields, and the AI has ZERO idea how to handle it. They just, in many cases... fall off a cliff. It is my number one gripe in the game at the moment, it makes it very difficult to multi-task. Also still has the issue from FS17 when the worker only uses 3/4 of the actual workign width of the implement it is using, which means wages are higher than they need to be, diesel usage is higher also.

Physics are less than... perfect. Sometimes it feels like they didn't even play test the game. Tractors get floaty steering and will drift pulling empty trailers, skid steer falls on it's face lifting more than 100 pounds, which makes loading flat beds with pallets and such a fight.

Default maps feel slapped together, liek they are a tech demo with a couple good photo spots and LOTS of empty land, which makes it feel barren. Which is another bad point, the game still has the "bubble" for view distance. It's a solid option for people that have low-mid PC's, but for us with high end PC's, it would be nice to increase it even more.. without having to alter an .ini file. Also the whole "build your own farm" thing, what a disgusting mess and waste, it's a hap-hazardly thrown together feature. It's useless in my opinion. The 3 default maps, all only have ONE, yes ONE starting area realistically, unless you want to start your farm in a field. Also note, there is no vanilla way to pave or change the ground to cement or dirt, rocks ect.

Still no dynamic ground... this is 2018... oh well. The painted flat textures look pretty 3D, but having real soil simulation would be such a treat, and open so many more gameplay doors. Especially if seasons was a thing *cough* *cough*

Other than those gripes, I think this is a solid step forward in the series. I enjoy it when I just want to relax and stop chasing Diamond in R6:Siege or wanting to throw my PC out the window playing Escape From Tarkov.

I had previously played FS13 and FS17, and enjoyed them mildly, but never felt the hook.  They were too gamey, too repetitive, not really simulators at all, and lack many aspects that would make them enjoyable immersive games.  FS17 was a baby step in the right direction, but not enough to garner more than a passing bit of play.

Farming Simulator 19 is a giant leap forward in playability and immersiveness. Is it perfect? Not yet. But the addition of placeable buildings, terraforming (still rough), and the beautiful graphics make it so much easier to suspend disbelief and immerse oneself in the game's universe.  The out of the box maps are beautiful and while still smallish and with limited "environmental interactions" (no access to most buildings, NPC people and vehicles run in continuous mindless loops, and no real NPC interactions), they take you into the setting and get you feeling like a farmer much more than any other game in the franchise.

I have only played a limited amount of time (42.4 hours at this writing) and I still have many many more things to do in the game before I have exhausted my interests.  The learning curve is a little steep out of the box, and the help is really limited, but thankfully there is a huge community to support fellow players and most answers are just a quick search away and a video or two on your favorite video service.  

I do believe that GIANT and the modding community will add even more content in the next year that make this farming sim one of the best and most playable sims of this decade.

If you like driving/simulation games (not racing games, these are mostly slow tractors) with a bit of management/economics thrown in, this is the game for you.
A little tricky to get into at first (many icons which don't have a hover over pop up description :( , so a novice user like me spent lots of time looking things up online when a hover over description would have been far better) but persevere and you will find it's worth it.
Not a quick game where you will play for a few hours and then move on, this one will keep you busy and entertained for hours.  Can get a little monotonous with the same tasks over and over but you can always hire helper workers to do these and concentrate on the tasks you enjoy (or sit back completely and let workers do the driving while you do the planning and managing).  Game can be tuned to remove some of the harder elements but playing with all options on makes for a better game.
With plenty of mods available and likely future DLCs, pretty sure the game will only get better.
Still learning aspects of the game (plenty to keep me going) but would recommend.
