I've given positive reviews for all Farming Sim games up until now. As soon as I loaded the game the first issue I encountered was the mouse sensitivity, I can't remember this being an issue for me in the older versions of the game. But on this one even upping the sensitivity on my mouse was still nowhere near enough, as I still needed 5 swipes of the mouse just to look 360 degrees. You'd think that a game would have a simple mouse sensitivity slider, but no. I had to google it and found out I had to go into the game files and change it manually. Something which really isn't fun to do when you've just bought a game you want to play.

The game is still very 'Clunky' the Vehicles still drive and manoeuvre like some old game made in the 2000's. Something I noticed straight away when driving, is that wheels no longer auto straighten. Making things like reversing trailers way more complicated than it needs to be. I feel that was a move for people who use steering wheels when playing. On mouse and keyboard though it doesn't feel right, as every other game I play with Vehicles the wheels straighten up when letting go of 'A' or 'D'.

Although the game does have a handy help section explaining how most things work. It is very vague, and I tend to find myself resorting to YouTube and Google in search for answers on how to do some of the basic things. I was hoping for a search feature in the shop, as with 102 brands and hundreds of different types of vehicles and equipment. When you see a trailer that requires an 'SB100' to use, I'm expected to go through those 102 brands or the 20 odd vehicles tabs to find it. Something again that isn't fun to do for everything you buy.

It does play and feel like I'm playing the exact same game as FS17. It does have some cool new features. I'm a big fan of the smaller details, like having your character use peddles when driving to break and accelerate and bounce on their seat when driving over rough terrain. Birds on your fields. You can enter your house. These are just small cosmetic things in the game, but I can always appreicate the small details. I do like that now you buy land rather than just fields, having the map cut up in to tons of sections you can buy is a big plus.

I have experienced a few bugs, for example if a field needs sowing or something. I'll sometimes hire a worker to do it then go afk. Then when I come back the worker has for some reason decided to just keep driving and ends up on the other side of the map, all whilst still charging me the workers fee. When I return to my field only half of it is usually done, so the worker just decided to go for a drive. This has happened quite a few times for me.

Contracts have changed. In FS17 you would start a contract, teleport to the field you chose, and have all the equipment there ready to use. Now, you have the option of using your own equipment to save money, or you have to pay to lease the vehicles to do the contract. I paid to lease as I didn't want to drive my harvester all the way to the other side of the map. I expected the Vehicles to spawn at the field like in FS17, instead everything spawned in the shop. So I had to drive a Harvester, header, tractor and trailer across the map. Once the trailer was full I had to empty it at a selling point, again on the other side of the map. I had to do this twice. Point is, I spent about 45 minutes doing a single contract worth just £3,500. Minus the £400 lease fees. So the contracts become a waste of time, unless you pick a field next to the ones you own or next to a shop.

I must be the most unlucky person in the game aswell. Considering I'm on my 24th ingame day. With Wheat, Barley, Oats, Canola, Soybeans and Sunflowers all at, or just under the 100,000l capacity of my Silo. Out of those 24 ingame days not a single one has had a high demand at any of the sell points. I've had to survive on Eggs and Bailing alone for all those days. I don't think I can fault the game on this, I assume I'm just really unlucky with the high demand spawns. Pretty frustrating though sitting on hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of crops which I'm waiting to sell.

Overall the game is still worth a buy if you liked FS17, as it's pretty much just a reskin of FS17 but with some slightly better graphics and a couple of new farming methods (Sugar cane, Oats, Cotton etc). I'll most likely still put hundreds of hours in to it like the older versions. However, my reason for not recommending it is the complicated cluttered menus, the odd bug and having to leave the game to search up things. I just felt disappointed on how little the games changed from FS17. And that basic things in the game that have annoyed many of the players in the previous versions weren't addressed or improved. And the lack of common sense when designing certain features like the pre-mentioned Contracts.

Do you enjoy the idea of 3 grueling hours of adjusting the height, position, and angle of a forklift just to properly move a pallet?  How about doing that 1000x more?  Because that is exactly what this game is.  An unrelenting, hellish, frustrating act of futility.

I've played all kinds of simulation games in the past, but this is the worst kind.  I knew from reading about the game that it was not going to be your typical "big picture" sort of simulation.  I actually looked forward to the likely monotony, thinking it would be calming and zen-like to plow fields and tend to my animals.  But NOTHING is streamlined or automated and you are required to do every frustrating minutia.  I'd even be okay with the forklifting (as I mentioned above) if the game automated it's placement on the back of a trailer.  BUT NO.  You have to place everything EXACTLY right or it all falls apart.  In fact, I've actually driven a forklift in real life.  That was easier than trying to control it in this game.

There is a thousand different tools that attach to only specific machines and no clear indication of what fits what and how to utilized anything properly.  No guidance, no clarity, no help (the help files are useless).  I did the tutorial level, and it basically just stops helping after a few simple tasks and you are left to fumble around and try and make something happen.

If you are some kind of masochist who likes being put through sessions of agonizing pain and torment, you might like this game.  But I'd still recommend you find someone who would be willing to just kick you repeated in the crotch and save yourself the $$$ from buying this awful game.

This game also requires very specific video cards to run.  I tried to run this on my laptop with a powerful, yet off-brand, GPU and the game just freezes during load.  Nvidia on my desktop worked fine.

This game is definitely not worth the $35.99 I paid.  I would get a refund if I hadn't already spent six hours trying to move things with a forklift.

This is probably the worst of the Farm Simulators I have played from Giants.  The whole game is buggy.  The physics’ are outrageously bad.  I have seen the Lizard Truck and tipper full of wheat go flying half the map for no apparent reason.  Pallets of goods do the same thing, I not been able to find where they land.  The forestry aspect is buggy. I had a portion of a log in the tractors claw, the tractor was tipping sideways, and shaving the ends corrected the problem. The AI tends to skip when planting, plowing, and harvesting.  The red implements to to skip when planting, even with seed. 

The brakes,  Giants has a thing against brakes.  99% of the trailers in the real world have breaks and will slow down in sync with the vehicle pulling them. 

The roads are pretty tight and winding, expect to get caught up on everything.

I have been a loyal Farming Simulator fan for years now, but as much as I want to recommend the latest iteration, I just cannot. This is basically Farming Simulator 17, with a few more features, and a lot more bugs. My workers seem to all be crackheads, because they refuse to farm an entire field, even though I specifically cleared out all trees. My trailers seem to be prone to tipping even with dual wheels.

The features that I want to see are things that make the game funner. I realize a trailer that can autoload logs isn't realistic, but this isn't real life. The tediousness and bugieness seem to be increasing with each release, and it has just become too much.

If patches come in to fix this game and actually improve it, then I will come back to update this review. Until then I really hope that Giants is working on fixing things.

Really well done. Putting the incredible graphics aside, the gameplay is fantastic. Lots of equipment options in the base game, with a very strong mod community. The ability to fully customize your farm, including building it on other plots of land, is a very welcome improvement. The ability to sell land is huge as well, as later in the game, the small fields are more of a headache than they're worth. Being able to see the modifications made to your equipment before you buy/lease it is huge. There are also some older tractors available for purchase, which adds a level of dynamics to the gameplay. It would be nice to have a rotating used equipment market added. It seems a little odd buying an old tractor or harvester with no hours on the clock.

review: Great game with a lot of new features, compared to FS17. There isn't much, but the Farming Simulator series have a massive modding support, so the modders are improving almost everything. I hope that the future updates will bring even more good things to the game, like the terraforming update.
Incredible!!

As far as the machinery side of things goes, it's a good game. The graphics have improved but I have seen much more realistic natural textures in other games so a little dissappointing there. As stated in other reviews, the fact that modders can come up with fully animated tractors inside and out and yet giants haven't is a real disappointment. It seems once again they've gone for quantity over quality. I personally would sooner have 1 tractor for small, med and large classes that is fully animated and interactive over many that are not. As far as the helpers go, they have improved slightly in the sense that most of the time when they encounter an obsticle on turn around at the end of a paddock they will back up and find another way around it. I personally haven't had any issues with odd shaped fields as I usually do the first couple of laps myself and then let the helper take over. But that's just me.

One thing I do like about FS19 is the fact that you can actually start off with nothing, although I do personally believe that it should be optional to start with all the fields planted. I'd prefer to start with everything grass and weedy and just start from scratch. As far as what others have complained about with having to start with nothing, Giants need to include all the relevant paperwork as far as field area, implement usage (seed, fert, etc...), hourly fuel usage per vehicle etc.... 
Fortunately some people have already done that in the forums so I managed to get a field area chart, seed and fert usage chart and a rough yield chart. Being a farmhand myself I just treat it as I would any other farm and do all the math before I start. Work out machinery hire costs, how much seed, fert and chemicals i need for each paddock and then go for gold. Before I started doing this though, I failed miserably every time so I can see why the city folk would complain about not being able to jump in a tractor an make heaps of money straight up.

My biggest complaint about FS19 would have to be the fact that it's called farming simulator. The game is mostly just another driving sim with a few added extras to keep people happy. If it's going to be called farming simulator it should take into account the animal side of things as well. Not just the super basic stuff that has been included.
I can't speak for europe but very few farms in Australia would have a fully automated dairy system where cows just walk in on their own to get milked. Most are either small scale swingovers or large rotary platforms for the bigger farms. 
With how customisable this game has been made for modders, why they haven't made animals and economy more accessable is beyond me. 

If any modders feel like implementing the following please feel free to :p
Things I would like to see:
More custom dairy options, nothing over the top. Just simple options rather then the usual lely robotic crap.
To milk cows and shear sheep it costs money to hire someone. Should be the same here. eg: notification comes up saying cows need milking or sheep need shearing, press a button to trigger a simple animation of cows and sheep lining up to enter the building and a worker gets paid to do it.

Which leads me to the next item on the list, there should be an option to set a realistic pay rate. I managed to find some code to set my workers to $30/hr but have to insert it into every hirable machine. On a 1:1 time ratio the speed per acre works out damn close so $30/hr works well.

Roads should be hardwired into helpers like the paddock area to allow helpers to pick up a harvester from the store and drive it to paddick 12 for example or go unload at the mill etc...

As stated in other reviews, GPS needs to be implemented. Have it as an added option when purchasing certain machinery.
Bale counters on the balers would also be a nice touch.

The option of animal husbandry. Put a bull in with a cow and it pops out a calf, ram in with a ewe and out pops a lamb etc... Can't remember, but disregard this if it's already in there for FS19.

The option to fence off paddocks (separate fencing options per paddock that cost money) and allow paddock rotation for livestock. Rather then have to hard feed them all the time, have the option for fenced paddocks. 1.5acres of grass per cow per year, not sure on sheep, and placable water troughs with some sort of auto fill plumbing option. have to maintain paddocks as usual, cows actually eat the grass in the paddock and paddock gets fertilised at the same time.
walk up to the cow paddock, option comes up and select move X amount of cows from this paddock to that paddock etc... allow splitable herds. same with all animals.

The option to input realistic weather data and produce prices for a players' local area. Input the players local weather site and it just updates the weekly forecast every time the player is online.

Irrigation options. plants don't grow without water. Here it rains for half the year, paddocks get closed up to grow and then harvested once the weather warms up. If there's little rain through those 6mths then it's a bad harvest and feed needs to be purchased from elsewhere to get through at full production capacity etc... 

I haven't looked into it yet but as grain prices go up and down with demand, so should purchase prices. I think they already do but I'm not yet certain.


All in all it's a good game and quite enjoyable when played right however, if you're someone who simply wants to "play farmer" for a couple of hours and make lots of money I'd suggest go back to an earlier version.

So at the time of writing, I have about 200hrs in the game. The game has been coming along nicely since release, especially from the modding community. I would like to say beginnig that this game relies heavily on mods to make it enjoyable (especially in replayability). 

Animals: I love the changes they have made to animals, it really does make the decision making whether to be a completely arable farmer or a completely livestock farmer a harder one to make. It is arguably harder to get into, but that is part of the game experience in my opinion. 

Land: I love that the plots of land are not just the fields anymore (like they were in FS17). It makes it more of an accurate look into farming. You don't just buy the land that you harvest from, you buy the surrounding fences/pieces of grass as well. Something that could be improved here is adding in a way to lease land, as I constantly hear farmers mentioning that they have a mixture of owned land and leased land it may be a bit more realistic... (the farmers I mention here are YouTube based so take that for what you will). 

Machines: Now there isn't anything really ground breaking here, but as I said, this will be filled in by the modders as they continue to move forward over the next couple of years. Already a lot out there considering it has only been out for a short time and over the holiday period I would suggest that the modding community will continue to impress moving forward. (COME ON FOLLOW ME!!!!)

Overall, I love the game and I look forward to what GIANTS and the community holds looking further into 2019. At the $50  price tag, I would still recommend it to friends who find this sort of game entertaining.

First, let me clarify the Steam 1.2 hours on record.  I play in offline mode so obviously they do not pull time from game files.  Also this does not include the numerous hours in Giants Editor and scripting as I would not review FS without looking researching game as well as tools.

I have played FS for many years and am welll aware that Giants has poor Quality Assurance in their software releases.  FS19 has exceeded even my expectations for their lack of proper testing.   The list of bugs is quite extensive, the lack of logic in gameplay programming and basic decision making (i.e. changes to tractor sounds) show the product was rushed to market with little testing.

Tractor sounds are unrealistic and mimic that of a 2 cylinder 4 cycle.  The change from FS17 sounds to FS19 is dramatic and quite unimpressive.  

AI workers have never been a strong point in FS, however, after years in the development cycle it would seem they could get this point right.  Now they have implemented illogical gameplay design of trying to have traffic stop as tractor, harvester, etc approaches.  The traffic however will stop in path of equipment causing an abrupt course change.  Again, poor testing combined this time with illiogical design.

The implementation of landscaping was tossed into game in recent update again with not much design thought and testing.  More of an appeasement to the console crowd to allow for their ill-designed placeables system.   A subset of GE tools were thrown in-game with no proper instruction to those unfamiliar with GE to allow for very simplistic terraforming.
The biggest problem is no testing or design for the back end of this system such as how to defeat obstacles such as you can't perform that function in this location.

The grand new additions to FS19, dogs and horses are about as simplistic as a mid-level MS-DOS game.   The dog does nothing.  You can pet or throw a ball, the latter of which disappears into ground and dog remains fixed.  No testing.   Horses can be ridden when they stop glitching and sliding around long enough so you can press key to get on them.  Oh what an experience it is to ride these gems.  Not.  If you implement new gameplay then at least test and make these experiences your focus.  

Oh and cleaning your horses, you press a button and hear a "hairspray" sound.   No curry comb, no brush, no apply blanket, no wash just a wonderful whoosh.  Cleaning over.  The total experience.  Awesome.

Giants Editor is still in Beta 8.1 as 8.0 was beyond usable.  The 8.1 version is workable but any great new features.....nope.

I understand this review may sound harse, but the fact remains that Giants chose a money grab over quality.  I enjoy FS gameplay as well as modding for FS however if something is substandard I would be as critical of myself as this product.

This is a great game, can't wait till it's out of Beta. At least, that's what it feels like. Unfinished and unpolished, requiring a second screen so the player can navigate bugs and glitches.
There is a lot of great things to celebrate in FS19, The machines exhibit an attention to detail that is very pleasing. The ability to have your favourite internet radio feeds or mp3s play through the vehicle radios, and the well crafted maps are just a few. However, this is interrupted jarringly by pallets getting stuck on forks, horses that do a little bunny hop before the jump animation, Horses that climb sheer cliff faces (horses in general really).
The economy feels haphazard and random (tautology?). Graphing the changes in the prices of comodities in 12 hour increments heralded no discernable pattern. This feels like a missed opportunity as there is no real gauge on what to plant and when based on the market values, which is especially true because there are no seasons. That's right, no seasons. I was especially suprised to find this glaring omission from something with the word simulator in it's title. True, I'm not a real farmer, but arn't seasons a major part of farming? Here, plant what you want when you want with no consideration to anything. I often find myself inventing reasons to plant one crop instead of another. Once, I accidently planted oat instead of Barley and it is of absolutely no consequence.
There are three main flaws with this title;
The bugs and glitches. Some of these have been fixed and hopefully this process will continue.
Missed opportunities. There are many times in this game when I was left shocked and thinking "why is that not in this game". 
Nothing to react to. Except weeds. Vehicles don't break down, animals never need a vet. Everything is linear and predictable. So much so that I was excited when I found out that a horse's final day of training gives less value gain than any other days (oddly, this is due to the linear nature of value gain) Yay, something I can optimise by not following the script.

All that being said, FS19 is a nice experience. The progression is slow so each new purchase feels meaningful. The machinery is detailed and wonderful. The new landscaping feature allows for some beautiful farms to be created. Harvesting a big field listening to music or an audio book is relaxing and satisfying. The biggest upside of all is the modding community, those wonderful people working hard to fill in the missing bits, complimented by the ease of adding mods to the game.

The game has many hiccups, things that are weirdly missed, and has a 'do stuff and you'll progress' feel. But it boldly strides beyond this and presents as a really good experience. Its strengths outweigh its anchors and, as the developers and modding community work to make it more than what it is now, it can only get better.

Disappointed.  Buy FS15, mod it and you have at least the same result.  Landscaping tool is a joke.  Physics still don't work.  Vanilla maps are mediocre.  Animals are programmed so poorly (Watch a horse climb a tree or lamp pole.  The dog is a joke.) Another money grab

Obviously I'm a pretty big fan of the FS series, with 550+ hours combined in FS17 and FS19. I really like FS19, and I think it's a great buy if you're into the series. It's essentially FS17+ (There really isn't that much new) but there are some great quality of life things.

As always, the modding scene will really hold this game up for the next two years. If you're looking to go from FS17 to FS19, you might want to wait while courseplay and follow me and the GPS mod are updated.

Overall, great game.

A few things I've found after a few hundred hours -
Classic farming sim

Cons however,
Not that many new machines (however mods make up for this on PC)
Land is VERY expensive. On Ravenport a 10HA field + the land around it is 800,000, making starting from scratch a real grind.
Land deformation needs patching, when i first started without knowing it costs you money, a placeable worth only 100,000 cost me 380,000 to place on a surface which was relatively flat.

Overall, good game, nice peaceful way to kill lazy hours on a sunday morning, but without mods the game only really has one leg to stand on.

FS19 offers a small graphical improvement, the addition of john Deere, but the removal of several other useful implements, trailers, etc. from the game.   The workers are bugged, and the number of placeables to "make your own farm" is worringly low.

Give the game some time to be patched, and for the mod community to fill in the holes that exist in equipment on release.   Until then just buy FS17 as it will be more enjoyable for at least the near future.

I have played past FS versions and have been kinda annoyed by certain things but this game brings them to a whole new level. I have played about 8 hours and am fed up. I do like the introduction to weeds however if the hired help is planting and suddenly the rows they just planted form weeds then the help will suddendly stop planting new rows and will start to replant the rows with weeds... waisting time and money. The new feature of landscaping makes the ground ugly. Even the placeables dont work well with landscaping. And you cant level out the ground around it once the placeable is placed. My biggest problem with the game is the pointless, useless buildings on the land you can buy. For example, Field 20 includes 4 buildings (restuant which is a sell point, what looks like a stable, a house under construction, and what looks like a sawmill??) You can not do anything with these buildings except the sell point. Why include them at all? I mean seriously, the house under construction is completely pointless and waist of space... I was hoping to be able to delete the structure and put usable placeables down... but nope.

Graphics are great. The build your own farm, weeds, cotton, lime, horses and dogs etc. are some nice added featured. Sadly achievements aren't challanging and physics don't change much (The steering is different than previous versions though).

Sadly the game is quite buggy. This takes all my enjoyment away.

>this game is depressing

Farming Simulator 19: The same old.

I have played farming simulator since forever. It's never been a game that feels complete, its raw and direct on what you do and what you get, still is pretty addictive and well aimed, until you eventually get tired of doing the same on its slow gameplay.

With the pass of the years you would expect plenty of changes and upgrades, but honestly, Farming Simulator seems stuck in time, basicly being the same game, release after release, with some minor changes that have been or could have been done with older versions and using mods. This latest version is no exeption, with the added problem that is really broken.

What people thinks: was rushed for christmas release, what i think: definetly. Not many changes in vehicles and placeables, in fact, feels it has much less options than it should. 3D Models arent close to the detail shown on promos and arts. You can take models from 5 years ago and will fit just right beside the "new" ones. Yea there are horses and there is cotton, but, thats about it with the new. I am guessing the plan for this release was adding a fair ammount of new features, but it has not really been done.

Key upgrades seems  have been completely left out for this release and seems to get added over time, such as terrain modification, maps and vehicles, still, pretty slow at the moment. The ability to modify the terrain is basicly the only thing i can say is woth saying is new and clearly different from previous.

Game mechanics are exactly the same as forever. No upgrades, no new additions there. Graphics wise i dont see much change neither. A lot of low detail alphas, animations and meshes. Nothing outstanding with sounds, probably same as forever as well.

Bugs are all over the place. AI on the helpers is simply garbage and totally worst than older versions. They cannot operate machinery correctly on the easiest fields using the easiest equipment, random errors constantly that stops them from working, and sometimes they wont even understand the task unless you start doing it. They will leave random patches wherever they can. AI on traffic and pedestrians is dissapointing with clear use of simple loops everywhere.

There are also many other random bugs like world lighting issues, multiplayer lag and crashes, missing key information, random things that stops working.. its a mess.

In clonclution, this release is pretty much a dissapointment. Giants needs to realize that its already due to make a large overlaul on the series. The mechanics are simply too old in comparison to up to date games. The quality on visuals and sounds is no longer marginal with current displays and sound equipments. Much more can be done in favor of gameplay, but is being held back by recicling old versions.

If you havent played FS before, or atleast not for years, you will enjoy it, but its starting to be a dissapointment for those that knows how little this game has progressed over the years.

This is a hit or miss. If you ever done actual farming there is a few differences. The following should be noted.

* Unlike real farming, there is no real contracts with companies. Like in many cases a company will contract a x amount of a given crop. If you produce more than that, then you don't harvest it since you're wasting money. While in this you will always be able to sale your stuff.
* It should be noted that there is no requirement to eat,sleep, etc. You don't get sick and you can't get hurt. In fact, you can run your truck in the side of a tree with no problems. (this is good and bad in itself since the physics is pretty bad)
* Unlike real farming there is no wildlife other than birds. This means you don't have to deal with a bear trying to eat your livestock. And you don't have to deal with EPA over stupid things (If a deer craps in the middle of your field in RL, and EPA finds out about it. They can pretty much make it where you can't use the crop in the general area of that)
* There is no bees in this. 
* There is no greenhouses


Now if that doesn't bug you and the fact that no one is walking around, no one is doing anything, you don't see any farmers, and the nearest you get to seeing another NPC your help or traffic. Then I would say this might be worth it.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend buying this game in its current state for a few reasons;
1. The game has many bugs/issues; such as the combine harvesters getting stuck...
2. Limited mods at this current time - I know, it just realeased, but it honestly feels like playing FS17 with only John Deere mods.
3. The maps are poorly made.

I do like the game, and what it has to offer, but it doesn't have anything great in it yet.
I will update this review when these problems are fixed, as for now, I will continue to play FS17.

EDIT:
Recommended, Good game, most of the issues are now fixed.

Dont let me playtime turn you off my review.

I was hyped for the release of FS19 as it was to improve on the basis of its older versions. I was sincerely let down. It let me down in some major aspects: Layout of the store/controls and menus. Selection of equipment. Not user friendly when picking graphical settings. New features that are confusing to use and not user friendly (Landscaping).

The new interface has been improvement to make farming sim look more higher quality but it is harder to navigate and to understand. This is similar within the shop with more sub catergories but with a minimal amount of machinary in each. Within the combine section there is only 5 combines from my memory which is a severe decreases from fs17. I have a sneaky feeling more will be introduced in DLC at a cost. 

When i first loaded up fs19 i needed to change my graphical settings as it looked poorly pixelated on the main menu. I spent 20 minutes changing settings with little change and with no understandng on most of the options.

New features such as landscaping are very hard to understand, hard to control and can create more problems than solutions.

Workers havent had any improvements from what i can tell.

I would wait until next year to see if the game changes at all but in its current state i find it not fun, unusable and frustrating. I have over 1000+ hours on my pc and ps4 for FS17 alone. I wanted to love this game but its went down a path that hasnt got enough detail within it and also isnt understandable. Untill then i will refrain from purchasing it again.

If you are considering buying it, watch some walthroughs on Youtube to get a feel of the game before hand,

Now that a patch came out that made it so I can run the game now, I thought I'd edit my review. Just to be clear, this it the first edition of farming simulator that I have played, so I can't compare it to anything.

After playing the game for a good 15+ hours so far, I am really enjoying it. It's almost to the point where it is the only thing I feel like playing right now. The graphics and attention to detail are very well done. I will say that the controls do take a bit to get used to but they are pretty simple after that. The machine selection from the store is awesome and is getting even better with added mods. I do enjoy the fact that you can adjust certain aspects of the gameplay to change the dificulty. The farming itself is pretty realistic and overall very fun. I would rate the game an 8/10

This game has a fantastic community that is very helpful with questions on the forums, and the maps are beautiful. The machinery choices are great in some areas, but lacking in others. The UI is less chunky than the one in FS17, with the windows being mostly transparent, but it can be difficult to see it in bright areas. The price isn't bad either ($35 at the time of typing this)

I'm at odds with this game and at the moment I find it difficult whether or not I can recommend it.

See, the Farming Simulator franchise has meant a lot to me in the past. I met a lot of amazing people indirectly because of this game (through FS-UK) and had many great years playing FS13, 15, and 17. Once again GIANTS has released their latest game, two years later as normal, and once again it contains new features - some of these have been inspired by popular mods for the prequels, and others are new concepts altogether.

But my problem with this game is that, you quickly realize that underneath its new gameplay elements, and new brands and prettier visuals, at it's core it's still the same old game as it's been for over ten years now. Unrealistic, artifical-feeling default maps and clunky arcade-like controls that in no way represent farm equipment operation and bring to question the "simulator" portion of the title. Games shouldn't have to rely on mod creators to make their game what it is - mods should add to the game, not be required to get the full effect.

GIANTS should take a page out of SCS Software's book. Since the release of Euro Truck Simulator 2 and American Truck Simulator, they've continuously updated their flagship titles and released the occasional DLC for revenue, instead of an entirely "new" game every couple years. This means that mod creators only have to tweak their creations with the new updates instead of completely overhauling them to make them compatible with the new title, and loyal fans don't have to re-buy the same game continuously. It's getting annoying re-purchasing what seems more like a moderately updated version of the same game I bought two years ago.

Personally I've grown tired of the franchise and the game that I used to love only bores me now, but maybe that's just me. If it was a brand new game entirely maybe I could see myself getting some enjoyment out of it, but like I say it feels like the same game it's always been after playing it for just a few moments. So I guess my recommendation would have to be that if you're new to the series, go for it. If you've played other FS games and don't find them fun anymore, don't bother getting this one because it's unlikely to reignite your interest. And remember that in two years time, this same game is going to be re-released, and you'll once again find yourself starting over.

As big of a fan as I've become of the Farming Simulator series, I have to say I'm somewhat disappointed with this latest iteration. Giants has made some significant inprovements in the appearance of the game, which I have to say are, at times spectacular (new clouds!).

However, I find it interesting that Giants has, for several installments, ignored the community's most requested features, and added less inspired features that, for me, largely fall flat. It is my opinion that they have become too dependent on the game's extremetly dedicated modders to add what their customers want most.

For years, the likes of GPS, Follow Me, Seasons, CoursePlay, and mouse steering (God, how I miss mouse steering on my laptop) have been left to the modders to supply to the community. If this is the intent, wrong though I believe it to be, then get the tools to the modders prior to release so customers don't have to wait for features that they became reliant upon in the previous release.

The new features that are included are mostly misses for me:
- Horses - Don't really care. They're well-animated, but I'd rather tool around in a pickup. Training is a time sink.
- Dog - A neat touch, but the effort would have been better spend making  GPS or mouse steering a standard feature.
- Purchasing "lots" - Now instead a buying a field, you buy a field and a little bit of surrounding area. Not sure what the point was.
- The new difficulty modes - Many problems with this, in my opinion. Everything is overpriced. Placing already expensive structures becomes ridiculous if there's even minor leveleing required. Most of the new lots don't easily allow for setting up a farmhouse/structures, so you're still likely to be in the default starting location. I will say that the recently added (expensive) terraforming tools will help with this. I still think most are going to cheat their funds to get past many of these issues.

I hope that Giants will take more of thier customers' requests to heart (as they did bringing John Deere to the game) for long-awaited standard features. The practice of charging dedicated customers for three quarters of a game and letting modders spend their time finishing it at their expense is exploitative and kind of sleezy.

The core game is still strong and will, of course, only be made better by the modding community. The number of manufacturers and volume of equipment are impressive and model quality is extremely detailed (animated PTO's, etc.).  I still, with some reservations, would recommend the game, but maybe wait six months and get it at a discount.

Well my initial review of this game was negative, but after a couple of updates and a small number of mods, I can safely say that there is hope on the horizon.

The main issues were the building placement system being just straight up broken and the economy being disastrously unbalanced.

The update that introduces terrain editing makes placing buildings in an aesthetically pleasing fashion much more doable now, and a mod that allows buildings to be placed anywhere makes positioning items much less of a headache and less cost to construct.

The economy still needs a tweaking in my opinion, as its far too much of a grind to be able to afford high-end equipment. Also that awful dog is just crazy buggy, and I'm not sure I like the idea of making all the animals a placeable-only thing. (Makes for a really ugly farmyard.) Hopefully the introduction of some mod maps will solve this as GIANTS are notoriously bad at map design.

Overall its a major graphical overhaul from FS17, and with the mods slowly trickling in, this game will probably reach the heights that previous titles did before. It just may be a couple months before that happens.

I'd recommend checking this out after you've finished squeezing the last bit of play out of FS17 as that game still represents better value with the mods available.

Update: 2018-12-18 Lots of bugfixes are out.  It has been a rough transition as some of the updates have caused configuration files to break (such as inputbinding.xml) but overall can recommend with more confidence now.  Still not perfect--the placeable system is still tempermental and has some bugs, but with the landscaping update it's easy enough to clean up most messes that you might make.

As of 2018-12-09, this game is not finished.  Giants is working hard to patch it, and as it stands, it's playable, and mostly better than FS17, save for a few buggy feature updates such as the new sky/night system, vehicle lights don't work on the South American map, and they're still trying to fix the placeable system.  If you havent played a farming game before, there are many choices, but not really.  Farming Simulator is the only really competent one.  Many games try to innovate on the concept, and do very well at some things but fall short in some crucial area.  Farming Simulator 19 is as close to the full package as it gets right now.  In 2 more years, they'll probably release another one that corrects many "deficiencies" that weren't important enough and were too difficult to patch this time around.

So far it's clearly a nice improvement in some very important ways. You really feel how dynamic vehicles are and you can feel yourself bouncing and riding accross terrain. Every field feels like a different field. A field on a slope feels like it. Gone is the feeling of just driving on a dirt square. I feel like I am actually working it. So far I'm very happy.

Track IR works great and it's extremely immersive. You can look back to hook up to equipment, look around to see what you are doing. it's fun to look down the side of your hood. Track IR was just plug and play. I also use a XBOX Pro controller, it works really well. i am a PC guy and really only use controllers for driving type games.

This review is edited from my original posted on 11/22/18.  Today is 12/17/18, and this review is meant to be current.  First, some improvements have been made since my last post.  I will list pros and cons, but first I have to say this:  When released, this game was tatered and torn, and for many (including myself) largely, if not totally unplayable unless you want to steer with a mouse/keyboard.  IMO totally a polar opposite of what I have come to expect fro Giants.  Then, it took them WAY to long to get a patch out, and that patch didn't address many of my concerns.  The Steam forum was full of people very upset with the status quo of the game at tha time.  And when we voiced those concerns (complaints) in the forum, many others shunned us/shamed us labeling us as whiners, or worse.  I realize that the forum - good or bad isn't part of this review, but I want you to get the full picture before investing your money.  As it stands now:
Pros - 1)  This is an improvement over 17 0 lots of new toys!  The "mission" system has been completely overhauled and way better.  Many new jobs, the option to use your own equipment to do the job - or lease from the shop for a SMALL price.  Much better!
2)  The maintenance fee for owning equipment that was previously collected at midnight has also been made much better.  Now over time, your equipments needs repair.  There is an option (I took it) to buy a maintenance shop and put it on my land.  Then to repair equipment, you just drive up and press a button and boom!  It's repaired.  If you own this shop the repair is cheaper than at the shop, and you can alter vehicles (for example changint ries from single to wide or whatever) - often for no cost - over and over.  really nice.
3)  There is now a sleep option when it gets dark.  Just set the clock and presto, it's morning again - VERY nice for anyone (like me) who never enjoyed working in the dark.
4) The included maps - there are many varyin gopinions on the maps which are included.  Some like em, some love em, some hate em, and some like one but not the other.  My opinion - I don't particularly like the maps - too hilly for my taste, and the fields are also mostly very hilly.  But this is personal taste - nothing wrong with them.  You also get the Sugar cane map from 17 as a mod.  I didn't like it (the red soil) in 17, and haven't tried it in 19.
5)  New options to start your game in terms of what you start with.  I like the options, but many others have indicated the need for more sub-options.  For example, if you choose to start with a little cash, but 2 fields and equipment, you don't get to choose easy - med - hard modes - they say that this mode is easy - better prices, etc.  Overall, I give the options exisitng now a thumbs up.


CONS 1)  Even today, nearly one month after release, the whole "controller/wheels" bugs are not fixed.  They have made some bugs gone, but not all.  THings that are buggy here include wheel settings vor snsitivity conastantly resetting.
2)  The default controller settings interfere with "my settings".  For example, I use the Saitek Farm Sim wheel and side panel.  So I map - say just for example "V" to my side panel 1 button.  So if it is "defalut assigned" by Giants, then there is a conflic and it will not work unitl the conflict is resolved.  Why did they assign it for me in the first place?  It has caused me more problems and time than I care to admit.  I finally just deleted ALL default asignments - and it seemed to work as I have very little problem now.  But figuring this out was a nighmare.  UNFORGIVABLE.  And the worst "bug" for me still exists - a month later - and that is the choice to display assigned functions on the screen while I farm is STILL Bugged.  They say they are working on it - but - I've given up on them.  

The game is playable, and much improved over its release state.  But I think Giants released it way too early, and IMO their Quality Control people either don't exist, were not allowed to do their jobs - or were on vacation.  Others say in today's age, no one should expect a totally bug-free release - They MAY be right - but I offer two things to that:  1)  These bugs were way too big, and 2) it seems to me that games like ETS 2, and ATS have no bugs when they release - just saying.  So I have learned one thing from this - I vow to not buy the next FS (likely 21) until it's been out for at least 2 - maybe 3 or 4 months.  Giants let me (and a whole lot of peolpe) down on this one, and I quite frankly cannot forgive them..  I am playing it - because I did pay for it and am thus stuck with it.  But can I recommend it - No I cannot - still bugs, way too long to fix, and really no apology from Gaints.  They do acknowledge there are issues, but no apology - no offer for refunds - etc.

After 20 hours of play I will say that there is something truly special about playing. It is mundane but it creates a sense of accomplishment. An overwhelming feeling of good and time well spent. Now, the game has some support issues. The tutorial isn't comprhensive enough. Like how to buy seeds or chosing the right equipment. And if you take a contract read it well because you could sell to the wrong market and bankrupt everything. That was a hard 6 real world hours spent ruining a good start. But over all I really enjoy this. I paused to look at the DLC before starting a new farm. Let me know what you think of it.

Is this a joke? Is this a beta or something?

Spent 3 hours of the game freezing every time I tried to X into or tab into a vehicle. Found a bug thread on the dev's forum. Turns out it was my gamepad. Well, not actually my gamepad. It was my USB hub. Apparently this game can't sort out other devices on a hub, so if you want to use a gamepad (or wheel) it has to be plugged directly into a USB port. So, yeah, I guess all my other peripherals can sit on my desk while I farm. I kid, I kid! I won't be farming, at least not on this sim.

On an i7-7700@2.8ghz (up to 3.8ghz), 16gb DDR4 RAM, GTX 1050 with 4gb, with graphics on high and a few on ultra, this game looks like absolute garbage. Worse than FS17 with ReShade. Draw distances are like a cruel prank. It also runs my card hotter than any other sim I've ever played. Fans maxed out the whole time I was in-game.

No Seasons Mod or Seasons Mod functionality, as was strongly hinted at. Sporadic dynamic hose functionality. Lots of recycled equipment from FS17 (and FS15!). Physics is still, uh...amusing. They did get rid of the Formula One tractor performance, and now they all drive like a 2 door Honda Civic. Which I guess is an improvement. No Gearbox functionality, as was strongly hinted at. No extended AI as was strongly hinted at. You can buy areas of the map, and you can buy structures to fill an entire area and make a farm of sorts. That tends to deform terrain for the transitions around the buildings and it ends up looking like generic structures plopped down via an interface, rather than placed structures. Essentially your 'farm' looks fake and has no immersion.

It's got lime now. Hooray! And horses. Lots of birds fly around. And you get a dog that doesn't do anything.

Seriously, if you want to be this disappointed go stream a Channing Tatum movie. At least it won't cost you 35 bucks and roast your graphics card.

And pre-emptively, no, I'm not a C&C fanboi. I got snookered by those fools and sent them a hundred bucks via Kickstarter for a sim that's never going to be finished. My disappointment with FS is just about FS19 and nothing else.

>100 hour edit: Yep, it sucks. Lifeless and uninteresting. Endless grinding missions, just to buy bigger equipment. This game was made for casual console players. FS17 with mods is the direction to go if you want (sort of, kind of) realistic farm sim.

I'm a very long time player of the FS games. I now have over 100 hours played on FS19, so I have waited to write a review. First I want to say that I have not played a FS game that was this buggy! Giants really dropped the ball on this one! Why they released this game is just mind bobbling. If they used the youtubers as testers, they should really get their free game back. The bugs are from everything from the AI being real stupid to keybindings not saving to game crashes. And Giants fix is a beta patch! I can see many, many patches down the road for this game. In many ways they had a very good ideal with the build your own farm thing, but the way they did it is kinda dumb. They should have left the buy individual fields in the game instead of this stupid buy plots of land crap. What they were drinking I would like to know. They still could have used all the placeables with that option. Graphics are pretty, but only in 4k. In 1080 it looks really not that much different than FS17 (probroly why they told the YT streamers not to compare them). Yes there are some real nice features like the way the plants bend and John Deere in the game. The horse and dog are time wasted! Should have invested that time into releasing a less buggy game.

Final thoughts here are this. Don't buy the game unless you can get it for like $10 dollars! Expect bugs! Is it playable? Yes but you get frustrated with it. Beside the pre orders, I don't see Giants having a very Merry xmass this year. To even break even It wouldn't suprise me to see some kind of DLC added to the game as a promotion to buy it.

When you've attached one jetpack to a cow you've attached a jetpack to every cow.

When you've single handledly overthrown a corrupt government using only equipment picked up 
from you conquered foes you've overthrown every corrupt government.

When you've seen attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion and watched C-beams glitter in the dark near the Tannhäuser Gate then you've seen all the attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion and all the C-beams, whatever gate they might be near.

But when you harvest a field you experience a different kind of joy, one known by our distant ancestors who toiled tirelessly for generations to afford even the simplest of combine harvesters with the narrowest header and would find spending hard earned money on such things as jetpacks and C-beams completely foolish.

Ich kann die, kürzlich häufig aufkommende, schlechte Kritik nicht ganz nachvollziehen.
Wir haben uns zu zweit das Game gekauft, direkt einen dedicated Server gehostet (Nitrado *Hier Spenden-Link eingeben*) und das hat einwandfrei geklappt. Mit etwas Grundwissen, gar kein Problem. Performance technisch laufen wir auf stabilen 60 fps(1080TI), bzw. 50-60(1070).

Der Server ist, gameseitig, nie abgestürzt. Es gab höchstens während der Speicherung einen kurzen Lag.

Vom Feeling ist das Game klasse. Das ingame-Radio ist sehr gut umgesetzt, der Multiplayer-Aspekt ist einfach und simpel. Kein kompliziertes Berechtigen oder, oder... .

Die 3 Schwierigkeitsgrade sind sehr ausgewogen. Da ist sicherlich für jeden was dabei.
Die Mod-Unterstützung ist grandios und sehr einfach. Es lässt sich sehr einfach an den XML-Dat. zusätzlich einige Verbesserungen vornehmen (View-Distance bspw.).

Die Farmarbeit an sich macht ein stimmiges Gefühl. Es ist keine haklige Steuerung. Die Lenkung ist gut umgesetzt, meiner Meinung nach.

Zu Bugs: Ich habe circa eine Handvoll erst mitbekommen. Und davon war keiner sehr spielschädigend.
Ja, manchmal kann man sich leicht verhaken, aber bis jetzt bin ich selbst aus den aberwitzigsten Positionen wieder heraus gekommen. Nicht ein Reset ist nötig gewesen.

Kauft euch das Game und testet es aus. Es ist wirklich grandios und ein guter Landwirtschafts Simulator.

#################################################################

I don't quite understand the bad criticism that has come up recently.
We bought the game together, directly hosted a dedicated server (Nitrado *Enter donation link here*) and that worked perfectly. With some basic knowledge, no problem at all. Performance technically we run on stable 60 fps(1080TI), respectively 50-60(1070).

The server never crashed on the game side. There was at most a short lag during storage.

From the feeling the game is great. The ingame radio is very well implemented, the multiplayer aspect is simple and simple. No complicated authorizing or, or... .

The 3 levels of difficulty are very balanced. There is certainly something for everyone.
The mod support is great and very simple. It is very easy to make some additional improvements to the XML data (e.g. view distance).

The farm work itself makes a harmonious feeling. It is not a hooky control. The steering is well implemented, in my opinion.

To bugs: I got about a handful at first. And none of that was very damaging to the game.
Yes, sometimes it's easy to get caught up, but so far I've come out of even the craziest positions. No reset was necessary.

Buy the game and test it out. It's really great and a good agricultural simulator.

So...
I dove into my new purchase, the highly anticipated next installment of Giant's Farming Simulator series, FS19!

I'm so freakin excited and stoked to play 1000s of hours, yet again, on another release by the King of FS Games 'Giants Software'.  My love of the FS series goes back to FS2011, FS2013, FS15, FS17 and now FS19...well no actually, not FS19..not even 5mins into playing FS19 and I'm floored, disgusted, on the verge of tears for christ's sake.

Why is wheel support relegated to just the basics of steering and gas/brakes?
Why is there a god dam xbox controller setup appearing where I would be costumizing my game with all the neat wheel functions I've used in all previous FS installments?
Why do I even have to point out to Giants that it IS IMPERATIVE that the farming simulator game has to cater to and fully support steering wheels, gas/brake pedals, and control decks when it's released?
What about your own expensive customized Saitek dream wheel setup?  No need for it now? You making an Xbox controller one instead?
I have to stop raging and go for a walk, and it's freakin -25C and snowing here in Ottawa, Canada right now, but I don't care.  It's going to be a long dam winter without FS19 looks like.

This isn't a review, it's a gaming steering wheel support APB report. All players need to be on the lookout for any sign of it's whereabouts and need to inform Giants ASAP.  The first 24hrs are always crucial in any missing investigation.

Ok, so now that I've finally calmed down after my walk in a snowstorm, ended up near the Arctic Circle and then turned around, I can see Giants has sort of fixed the steering issue, but I still need to tweak things on my Logitech GT FFB for it to be the way I want.  I'm not getting any tension in the steering, sort of like FS15 was for me.

As for the game itself, I sort of like it, but I don't really get that feeling of excitement of playing a new rendition of FS.  Cosmetic buildings that do nothing (sold all mine except the house), and placeable animal pens that leave the area look like shit pardon my french.  They've added some terrian sculping and paintbrush function, which I totally suck at.  Not posting my screenshots of my attempt to 'fix' the area around my cow pen,  for fear of being ridiculed.

One big thing that annoys me is my darn dog.  Can't place his dog house too close to buildings leaving it placed out in the open.  Unlike the nice cinematic trailer, he can't actually come along with you in your truck.  That nice ball he gets at the dog house?  He/she can't chase it, just sits there looking at you saying 'I'm not getting that, you threw it, you get it'.

Overall, the game passes for a worthwhile purchase, but it's not what I thought the next FS would be like.

This is the first Farming sim that I have played and it will be the last one. Unfortunately I have 6 hours in the game so I was denied a refund. But know that I did try to get one. It alone takes about 45 minutes just to complete the tutorial, which barely shows you any of the mechanics of the game. Then you must spend an hour or two trying to figure out how to even start your farm. It was built to get you past the refund threshold before you figure out the game is garbage. You are left guessing when you start, how do I purchase land/equipment? How do I manage animals? What is the purpose of buildings?

On top of all the remaining questions you have, farms are buggy and won't allow complete planting of crops. I don't know if was due to terrain changes or what, but my farm was very patchy. Corn would only plant on 50% of each row. It would sow for 10 feet then it magically wouldn't for 10 feet, then it would start sowing again and then stop again. Very frustrating trying to research online why this would happen when it turns out its just buggy.

The map is missing quite a few labels, So if you start a contract requires you to do something, which was also not explained anywhere, you are left guessing where to go and what to do. Not Recommended.

The whole game was a frustrating guessing game of steering into things until it bugs out. Uninstall!

First off, if you're look for 4K Ultra HD, go out side and be a real farmer. Second, if you not happy about the fact you have to work to earn money. Then while you slurping your drink, and spilling that sandwich down the front of yourself. Remember, some farmer, done the repeatitive and grinding tasks that people have complained about. Just so you can complain about having to do what the poor farmer did. While eating that sandwich.

Now, lets get down to the good stuff.

Graphics - Marked improvement over previous versions. Again, not 4K Ultra HD, so don't be expecting the heavens to open up and the angles to sing when you power up you GTX what ever Ti. 

Game Play - Again, better then previous versions. Ok, the dusting you fields with lime every now and then (can be turned off in the in game menu), takes a bit to get use to. But, and I say this is a good way. When you fill your seeders/planter/fertilizers. You'll get the option to unload. When you choose that, make sure you have room. As it will dump it back in bags/pallets on the ground. Even if you fill up from a lime station. I think that is pretty awesome. You don't have to shovel the stuff back in. Crops, grass , bushes will respond to the player, tractor, harvester, tools etc.. when driving over them. No more do they stay stiff and go through the tractor etc... Adds to the fun. Um, yeah there are also nice little quirks in the cabs of the vehicals. The pedals and/or stick will respond to your back and forth commands. Again realy cool little features. And riding the horses around is fun, and required to help keep their value up. If you looking for riding like Red Dead Redemption 2, then you're going to be disapointed. But that being said, it's still cool. And the detail on the horses is fantastic. The building, unless my IQ is in the top 2%, which I am sure my school teachers will disagree with. It's fine, and is better then previous versions. Instead of just be stuck in the on screen postion and only rotating the object you are placing. You can now rotate the screen as well as object (Q E and left and right arrow). You now also have the option to raise and lower the object to help it level with the ground. I am still at a loss as to why some people have had trouble. Chickens, Horses, Cows and pigs. You will need to purchase the actual Pen/Stable etc... And then fill it with animals. Also, you dont buy fields anymore. You by sections of land, which will have a field or two. Or empty space with trees. So for all the people that complained about the animals being stuck on map, Giants now lets you choose where you want to place them. When you purchase them of course.

There is a lot I could go on about. No, I didn't get the game at discount nor for free. I paid full price (AU). And after about 15 minutes was really happy I did. 

If you are sitting on the fence, and really enjoyed the previous versions of the game. Then, grab this, you will not be dispointed. If your looking for high stakes action, with 4K Battle Royal Mode, then keep  scrolling. And don't complain.

Just remember, (1) It's not going to go at 144Hz at 4K Ultra HD with GTX Ti's. I have been playing at 1080p 60Hz with no worries what so ever. (2) Yes, its a farming game. Yes, it's fun if you're into farming. (3) NO! That's right, NO! Battle Royal Mode, it's a farming simulator, you know, where your food starts out from. (4) If you don't like working in real life, then I'm guessing you will not want to work in a simulator. (5) If you have enjoyed the previous versions then this great.

A lot of things need to be fixed.  It also doesnt seem like that much changed from FS17.  I like the three different "difficulty" settings they have this time.  It adds a bit of a better way to get started farming and the prices for equipment seems a bit better than FS17.  But outside of a few new crops and pieces of equipment (mostly for the new crops) there really isnt much here.  The mod community will once again be relied upon for added depth to the game and for adding much needed pieces of equipment and placeables that there really isnt ANY excuse why Giants couldnt have figured out were needed and inserted into the game prior to release.  The game looks a bit better and has a few more pieces of equipment but my honest opinion is wait till its on sale for no more than 20 bucks and hope they have fixed the bugs and the modders have come out with content because it doesnt look like Giants is going to do it.  Oh, and if your relying on contracts to fill in the void and give you good money for real time spent, think again!  Unlike on FS17 when you took an hour of real time to harvest a big field of potatoes or corn and you got 20k+ for it, now your lucky if you get 6-8k for it AND you have to trailer it, and sell it for the field owner!?  So you have to spend almost TWICE the amount of real time to get less than half the money.  Contracting is a complete waste of time!  I like that they added the ability to use your own equipment to get a bit more money, but I have yet to do that, as the price of leasing the (usually better) equipment to get the job done, in no way makes it worth me using my own fuel/maintenace/usually smaller equipment.  So you get to use leased equpiment (that you have to drag from the store to the field...) which is nice to see new stuff, but you get docked money for it and you already get next to nothing for the work.  So yeah, contracting sucks!

Farming Sim Genre:
I grew up in the city and never thought I would be playing a farming simulator in my lifetime. I gave FS15 a go back then and the rest is history. I dare say FS19 is currently my favourite game. 

Farming Simulator 19:
I played FS15, FS17 and hyped and pre-ordered FS19. I can honestly say that if you ever considered a Farm-Sim then this would be the best title to pick up ever up to date. I tried other Farm-Sims Brands/Titles and played previous FS titles and this one is by far the best one out there (Keeping in mind that the Mod Community still needs to produce content this early on after release. Knowing the best is still to come.).

Conclusion:
FS19 has bugs with release and is not perfect but as I type this review, we are expecting a patch early next week with the long-awaited landscaping feature among other things. The multiplayer is ample fun and there is lots of models/content with this release that was buyable DLC's with previous titles.

Final Conclusion:
Best Farming Simulator ever and great value with lots of content and hours of fun if you are into this kind of game. Giants Software does produce I have found. Community Mods is superb quality overall and the community in general is mature and great. I would urge you to buy this if you like farming simulators and highly recommend you try this game if you never tried a farm sim before and is considering a try in this genre.

I got on board the Farming Simulator series at 17, so I'm not really an old hat at this game series (yet). But for me, thus far, it's  an excellent way to relax and just do something that takes no effort to do. That said, I recognize that there are some shortcomings here, none of which affect the gameplay enough to shift me from a "yes" to a "no" but should be acknowledged:

*FS17 had a map where a player could roll their machines up to dispensers on the farm and have them automatically filled and charged money for the transaction, likely more than it would cost to buy pallets and manually fill the tool. FS19 lacking this option for slightly less involved play, and modders having to add the functionality afterwards, is a slight black mark in my eyes. Obviously most people in this game will want the full experience--get a loader, load the seed/fertilizer/whatever on a pallet fork, dump it into the machine--but if the previous title offers a gameplay option to the player, I feel that the sequel ought not take it away.

*FS17 also had a system by which repeatedly doing jobs for the same farmer visibly accumulated "friendship points" for lack of a better term which translated to better pay and a better price for buying land from that farmer. If FS19 retained this, there's no indication of it. I believe an incentive to build a reputation with the NPCs is another instance of a gameplay feature that a prior had that its direct sequel ought not to have removed.

*Until the player become wealthy enough to be managing many fields at once, there is very little to do other than fill contracts for money. When your field is plowed, cultivated, seeded, fertilized, and limed, all there is to do is stare at it, until the next growing stage, and then until its finished growing. A minor complaint to be sure, but there's a fine line between idle relaxation and boring and early game flirts with it.

*This game oozes real-world machinery out of every pore. There are an enormous number of options for what to drive, what to use to seed, cultivate, plow, spray, fertilize, and so on. The sheer content volume and variety is impressive and appreciated. And most of it, there's no reason to touch except for the fun of it. You have a fast tractor with a front-loader attachment that you can get immediately at the start which can be upgraded to have more horsepower for tools than anything short of the most expensive light tractor. The Khun subsoil cultivator/plow is more cost-effective than buying the two tools separately, and is quite cheap. Buying the most inexpensive fertilizer spreader and a weeder beats everything until you're rich. In essence, especially if you're challenging yourself most of the content may as well not even exist. I list this as a downside, but I fully acknowledge that even if there is a solution, it'd be a headache to figure out so this, like the others, is a very minor complaint.

As of 26 hours in, these are the only things I see that could be downsides to this game. Wtih how small they are, it seems fair to say that this is a truly excellent experience that I heartily recommend. I'm now looking forward to Farming Simulator 21.

It's a funny little game.

It's not for everyone. Definitely isn't for me. I gave it a chance because of a good gamer friend wanted me to try it.

But despite my best attempts to continue playing it, I just couldn't play it anymore. It was just a painful experience by the end, and I wasn't having any more fun and was actually dreading playing it. Which is definitely not something you want from a game.

Not to say I didn't have some fun. But most of that came because of multiplayer and us messing around with things and just funny querky parts of the game, that are hilarious when you consider this is supposed to be a simulator, but a lot of it is a bit of a joke.

The game looks really nice, has really nice atmosphere. But at the core, it is a grinding experience and just too boring to be a gamers game. After as many hours as I managed to put in, you will likely be like me if you are a gamers gamer, and need some quality gaming sessions that truly stimulate your mind in a way that suits you best.

This game is more of a place to hang out with people and work on your farms while keeping each other company. Or if you just love farming which some people just do.

But if you are not from this genre like me, then my review is more for you. I would not recommend if for you. Unless you know some people that play the game and are happy to have you in their game and will help you out when you need it and vice versa and you can have some fun together messing around.

On a technical level, the game has its faults and you have to give it a pass. But sadly Steam only gives you 2 hours to determine if the game is worth it, and frankly that isn't enough time. This is one of those games I wish I could refund, because I will likely never play again and it's just not a really good game for me. 

Usually I would never get a game like this, because I know I won't be into it. But sometimes it's amazing what impact friends can have on you and what you will try for them. Love you guys.

I won't change the recommended thumbs up, even though deep down I wish they would stick that where the sun don't shine, especially Steam and the devs who refused my refund requests and were completely ruthless about it. Don't get this game unless you definitely know it's something you really want to keep and have. Because 2 hours is not enough time to determine those things. So wait until long after release so you can watch video and get more of an idea on the game. Typically I do that, but with this game, I got caught out. Lesson learned.

---------------------------------------------

End of Review and beginning of my Rant about Steams Refund Policy:

They state 2 hours playtime within a 2 week period.

However I think this needs to change. I rather it was based more on game activity.

For example, how can you tell if you are going to enjoy a game or not in 2 hours in a farming game when in 2 hours you haven't even grown and harvested your first crop yet. I only truely realized this wasn't a game for me, after doing my 3rd Harvest. And I realized it then. Now that is not something that can be accomplished in 2 hours. So it is a ridiculous policy that needs to be flexible with the game it pertains to.

I'm changing this review to a thumbs down just because of that. Had they been more understanding and reasonable, I would have been happy to give them a thumbs up, but stick it up your Acehole, this is the price of refusing me a reasonable refund. Guess that is the final end value of my purchase.

End of rant.

This is a big step up from FS17 in many ways. The physics are a lot better, vehicles feel "heavy", the steering is improved greatly, the wheels no longer move around independantly of the axle, the seat suspension looks great and the graphics are improved. As always they have addded heaps of new vehicles and even more customisation to play with as well. 
Can't wait until the mods start coming out for FS19 to make it even better.

Edit 3 weeks in:
Yes this game had some bugs but most things other reviews have mentioned have been fixed in the 1.2.0 update. Nice work Getting it sorted out Giants Software.
Also there are lots of the classic mod maps being converted over now so I am back playing some old favourites like Westbridge Hills.

There is a good game hidden in there, but it just feels like a rushed release with too many bugs and crashes.
So in it's current state I cannot recommend it.

Now lets start of by saying that Giants did many things right, with the new installment of FS19. The expansion in animals and the dynamic land is something that was definetly needed in previous version.
It is a game that is nice to look at and promises almost the same experience as FS17 so if you liked that one and had a few bugs that frustrated you for example in timber and pallet movement, these are solved. A nice overhaul to the field floor texture as well as graphically overall improvements can be seen. 

Now to the wonky bits, the building system......
While the thought of building your farm modullarly is absolutly amazing in practise it is something that will frustrate the player from the get go. In normal mode no farm buildings are given to the player and if you play for example the american map (not very flat), you may soon realise that the buildings will level out the ground.
While this is realistic as no buildings are build angled, Giants did not implement an option to level out ground or even change ground textures with a tool, the essence leads to huge hills that lead up to your buildings.
Also the idea was that you could buy land and create your own farm, well since we can not create roads you have random buildings standing in the middle of a grass patch.

In all honesty I belive that the modding community will help all players but this brings me to the next point. 
With FS19 it seems as if giants got lazy and thought, the things that we dont do perfect the community will adjust, this is a mindset that will destroy a franchise. And this would be a shame!

There is many good things about FS19 but also still many bad things, i hope that Giants will solve this via patches and their own mods on the website if not it will be Farming Simulator 2017.5

Grampa Bob sat on his porch lazily smoking his pipe.  His grandson, Jim, came out and sat down next to him.
"Pa says you've retired from farming Grampa.  Is that true?"
Grampa Bob took another big puff and slowly blew it out.
"Yup."
"But why Grampa?  Is something wrong with the world?" Jim asked.
Bob leaned back in his chair.
"No, nothing wrong with the world."
"Is something wrong with the equipment?" Jim asked.
"Well, a few things.  One of the combines thinks that corn makes a mighty good brick wall, and the steering has changed for most of the vehicles.  But that's all pretty minor."
"Then what's wrong Grampa?  Why'd you quit farming?"
"Well my boy, it's like this.  Yer pa and I tried farming in Felsbrunn, but all the fields were built on hills.  So we tried farming in Ravenport.  All the fields were built on mountains."
"But what's wrong with that, Grampa?"
"I farm because it's relaxing.  And trying to farm in Felsbrunn or Ravenport is alot like trying to have a threesome with a wolverine and a rabid porcupine with leprosy.  You may succeed in your goal, but you're going to grok a whole new meaning of the word pain on the way there."
-----
