With 2000+ hours in FS15 and FS17, I feel comfortable leaving a review on FS19 with 23 hours in.  Like all FS games before it, this version is better in all ways than previous versions.  Most things you'd like to see improved or added have been.  Graphics are better across the board.   Not a big change, but better, smoother, and more detailed.  General physics are better, especially ground response and crop response (crops move when driven over).  In cab especially feels more real.  Also now, whether in cab or out, you can see pedals and levers move depending on what your doing.  It's not noticable right away, especially if your not a seasoned FS player, but you'll see it.  It's not a huge thing, but these little details are what make the FS series great.  The new property buying sytem is nice, along with the placaeable aspect, although out of the box, there aren't alot of placeables.  The side jobs now seem more like jobs, and not just free money.  The nice thing especially is you can use your own equipment or lease it just for the job.   You can even put a worker on it if you've got better things to do and have extra equipment to spare.  Also, like all Giants games, very well optimized.

As it is now, 8/10 in general.  If you're a seasoned FS fan, you probably wished for more, and it ends up 7/10 .

What this game is missing at launch, will be completed with mods through the in game mod manager.  A great feature introduced in FS17.   With that being said, it's surprising that a few things are not included in this version without mods:

-Animated map triggers/operable doors and gates.  Especially surprising they took out the operable garage door from Estancia Lapacho. It was in FS17, and gone in FS19???????
-Seasons (I don't want to play that way all the time, but every now and then it's nice. Mods will take care of this)
-Better physics with ground, ie getting stuck/driving through mud.  Both available in early mods in FS17
-Better base maps from launch.  The USA map is garbage.  As an American from the mid-west (AKA farm country) it's 
 disapointing the base US map was so bland, and kind of trashy looking.  Don't get me wrong, alot of the rural farm 
 county looks like that, but most large farm communities don't.  It just felt like it was laid out very poorly as well.  And it's all over the place in general, large fields seperated by cliffs, and ocean, and I'm pretty sure I saw palm trees somewhere.  I guess it's California?  Maybe the Carolina's?  I heard the Pacific Northwest, but unless I was really hammered and imagined those palm trees that can't be right.  It's just weird non the less.  Can't wait for good map mods or the Platinum edition a year from now.  Really, both maps feel almost kind of rushed. 
-More placeables from start.  Yes, there are already mods for buildings.  But with such an emphasis buying land and being able to start your farm from scratch, I expected more available buildings to purchase. Again, mods and official DLC will fill the early void.

All in all, it's better than FS17.  I preordered, and am happy I did.  It's what I expected and more. The few short comings I know will be addressed in mods and official DLC.  Solid game once again.  The next two years of mods and DLC will make this game great.

The latest from GIANTS Software, Farming Simulator 19 is here!

I will admit, I was skeptical about purchasing this before I did. But, I'm actually glad I did. 

There's a lot of improvements both subtle, and eye catching. Standing out the most for me is the dynamic clouds that have been introduced for FS19. It was something I longed for in previous FS games and it's been worth the wait. No more sudden hail storms, allowing you to prepare for incoming weather in a way you see fit.
There's also the improved handling, much improved physics, better lighting, better sound, and in my eyes - well...better everything. It's hard to get this much improvement out of the same engine used in previous series' games, and I say good job! The AI traffic is even (somewhat) better (something that really toyed with my emotions in FS17)!

FS19 so far has been a joy to play, and I have no plans of discontinuing my gameplay.

There are sadly some things that I'm hopeful will be remedied, and or tools for us to overcome. Namely - terraforming. Placing down objects on property you own will generally raise the terrain to meet the highest point on which your object is placed on, which can create some very unsightly placements if you're like me and purchase a small field for extra sheds to store your fleet of vehicles and implements. Removing that object leaves a foundation and raised terrain with lips that are at times impossible to climb, and also prohibits you from placing another object down on that foundation as it is itself an object. What I hope to see out of this - terrain tools to raise/lower terrain at a cost to the player of course (think of it as landscaping).

I have also experienced a few CTD's early on with no error messages which can be frustrating, but auto save is key.

The pros outweigh the cons for this title and it was a well worth it purchase. I look forward to the future of Farming Simulator from GIANTS!

I can't help feeling that GIANTS should have just released DLC's for FS17 while developing FS in the background. They would probably make just as much revenue in micro transactions and work towards giving us a full upgrade of the series.

My recommendations to the devs are as follows:
1. Create proper ground deformation aka 'Spintires Mudrunner' - folk will be in awe with this kind of realism.
2. Create maps with proper infrastructure, i.e. bigger roads, more intelligible traffic and people perhaps.
3. When creating fields from scratch we all like a nice neat square, rectangle etc. Howabout having the ability to create a sizeable perimeter on the map that allows us to plow the field and if we go outside of this box the plow does not create a field past this point.
4. Organise the garage menu so that it does not take a year to scroll across to your last item.
5. Lets have proper 3D fields and produce rather than the current optical illusion.

Be brave GIANTS, don't just stick with your previous formulation, push the boat out a bit.

I am recommending FS19 on the basis that the mod community will pull this through and the devs will fix the bugs and listen to the users, but if we get to FS20 and there are no significant advances then I will no longer buy any further releases.

I'm sure future FS buyers would have done their homework as to whether this is a good purchase or not.

Better graphics

More crops

The only downsides are:

There was no improvement in physics from other FS games

Background:  450 hours in FS15, 1250 hours in FS17
20 hours in FS 19 at the time of the review

Comparing a game to one that has been out for 2 years with a ton of mods is not fair.  Compare FS19 to unmodded FS17 and then write that review.  Also, give it a few months to work out the bugs.

Great
[list]
[*] Better graphics
[*] Build a farm
[*] New Mechanics (Lime, weeds)
[*] Chickens are better
[/list]

Good
[list]
[*] John Deere, frankly I don't care
[*] Better Mission System (can use your own equipment)
[/list]

Meh
[*] I am not a fan of the maps.  Ravensport roads are horrible.  I can't wait for custom maps

Bad
[*] I get that Giants have allowed mods and grown a huge modding community.  Not everything can be in the base game.  However, changing the API so drastically and not given documentation out early means that we have to wait for the good mods (Follow Me, CoursePlay, GPS)
[*] Some bugs, but that is par for the course with smaller dev shops.  They had to get money coming in and hit a November release date for the holidays

Not much into writing reviewes, so here is a list of why I would recomend staying away from this title.

- XBox controller bug that fails to auto map controls. (Resolvedwith workaround)
- PS4 controller bug that fails to auto map controls. (Resolvedwith workaround)
- Helpers are bugged, and require a lot of hand holding. Not much of a helper...
- Multiplayer game play syncing issues. 
- poorly designed sell points without proper markings.
- Maps not designed for multiple farms.
- Ploppable building system is terrible.
   ~ Lack of terraforming.
   ~ Uneven, undrivable surfaces are created after placing.
   ~ No way to tell how some assets will affect the terrain.
- It still rains inside.
- Bugs, so many bugs....

In short, enter at your own risk.

The seeder kept missing areas on the field so has to go over it all again. Bales of straw fell through concrete. The wood chipper grab arm would not work when picking up logs. Not being able to get into more of the farmhouse is just poor design, if you are supposed to use it to sleep then at least have access to a bedroom. Train crossing barriers don't go down early enough, been hit by a train 3 times while going across crossings. Steering vehicles with a keyboard is almost impossible and loads more problems not listed here. Good Points: Great graphics. Great game to play. Plenty of variety and things to do / acheive to keep it interesting. I would recommend giving this a miss for 6 months while the bugs are fixed. Or buy Farming Simulator 17 which actually works.
The game overall is great.

Like most people have said- If you are new to the farm sim series then by all means pick it up and give it a go. For those of us coming from 17-there's nothing impressive about this game.  Now I don’t hate it. I’ll be playing it all the time. The graphics are great. The ability to buy land and start farming how YOU want to is a great idea and hopefully they expand on it and refine it. They added lime and weeds which are both cool additions to say the least. JD is in the game but then it really has been all the while if you’ve been playing on PC (thanks to all the hard working modders that make farm sim great). So, really not a huge addition. The menu for buying and customizing equipment is cool if you just want to take a look at the machines. Farm Sim is a solid title but they need more.

Now to what bothers me.
Farm sim is great because of mods. How do they go from the library of mods in 17 to nothing or pretty much nothing? I get the game just came out but once again we are at this idea of incomplete games launching and that’s just bothersome. Maybe they expect the community to do all the work while they sit back and collect…….
Helpers are useless in fields that are not square! I don’t think there has been a single improvement since they were first introduced. 
How are things like courseplay and gps not STANDARD in this game.
Where are my seasons? Yeah, sure I get they; be coming down the line but why are they not here now.
Can we get some new terrain physics, please?
So, it hails and my crops are completely fine still?
Once its done raining I can just hop right back in the field and keep at it?
--Expand on these things and give us morrrreee--
Some of these American maps they dream up are silly. Ravenport is a farm that’s inside the Grand Canyon (being a little over the top but I mean it) that’s inside the town. So, you want me to either drive up this cliff to get to all the nice big fields or roll through the middle of town. 
There’s more but I’m starting to get a little annoyed at it all and I am late for dinner so ta ta…

I’d like to say thanks again to all the modders that make this game great and keep it alive.

Having played since FS11, it is really interesting to see all the changes in the game over the years.

In my opinion some of the new features in FS19 makes it a very good new generation of the game:

- The machinery detail and additional suspension and ground response makes the driving feel much more realistic 
- The way animal pens are placeable and can be put down in multiples, really opens up the game for focussing and scaling livestock farms in a whole new way. 
- The wear and repair system for machinery was previously only available through mods - and seeing this in the base game is great
- Obviously there's been a huge graphics uplift as well
- Finances are more challenging now - things are expensive - but you can blaance it, and there's better access to loans
- Introduction of weeds and herbicides is really great. Sprayers were previously only for fertilising, which frankly was not very realistic. 
- New animals opens up the game to a wider style of players - focus on building a successful horse livery where the farming is done to feed and keep the horses - the options are there now!
- Houses that allow players to skip the nights, or some of the darkest hours at least.
- A massive range of vehicles compared to any previous version of the game!
- Additional crop types that adds lots of new options and tools (sugarcane if you didn't play FS17 with DLC expansion, Cotton, and oats)


Having said that - there are of course also things that seems a little unbalanced. There seems to be many people suggesting a huge amount of bugs, but after 38 hours, I am still to come across one. I knw this can depend on systems, and know there has been issuses with steering wheels, but overall, this game runs very, very well on the same system that ran the previous version of the game - you do not need a absolutel beast of a computer to play this.

The things that mainly are drawbacks - which i suspect might get fixed/balanced in patches are:

- Lighting cuts off quite hard at night/in the morning.
- The prices of some of the animal placeables are quite steep - but what really wrecks this part is the terraforming costs, which easily pushes the costs up by several multiples of the base cost. If you don't pay attention while placing a building, it could empty your bank account!

And as with previous versions of Farming simulator - mods will take this game to even better and exciting experiences in time - across all platforms now. 

All in all - a very warm recommendation for anyone who wants to play a versatile farming game with a tons of features!

I've ennjoyed all the farming simulator games.  I enjoy this farming simulator game.  I am disappointed in the continued lack of interaction with the environment.  why have buildings and structure with doors you cant open?  Eye candy is fine, but this isnt a visually stunning game.  Its a farming game.  if there is a barn, dammit, i should be able to open the door and park / store stuff in it.

this is more indepth and while not harder, it does require more thought and planning than previous iterations of the franchise.  Overall I like it, but cant give it 5 stars.  A five star game has doors you can open.  this is at best a 2 to 3 star game.  The maps suck.  Really.  We have these modes where we start with nothing, but really, the only decent place to build aanything is the now empty starting plot from the easy mode.  the plots of land should allow enough room around them to do your building without impacting the field itself, or there should be small plots adjacent to the fields that you can buy that are flat enough to have some fun building your "dream" farm that you cant interact with.

overall very meh....  its ok.  Not really recommended.  It's not any better than the previous versions when it comes to interaction with the environment, and in a farming game, that was something i was hoping would be in this edition.

I love how much more realism they've added since FS17, including crop destruction from large wheels, the need to spread lime, weed control, and the start-from-nothing options.  I also like how the AI is a little smarter than before in avoiding trees and such when turning.  Love the new crops they added as well.  Good job Giants!

Despite what other people say about this game, I think this game great. 

The "Farm Manager" mode is something that I have been waiting for for years; it's awesome. I was at the point in FS17 where I would just sell off all the stock vehicles and start my farm for my choice as much as possible. The fact that the construction was very limited always bugged me.

The new maps are awesome too. They look so much better than the previous ones. 

The only thing that still really bugs me (as a person who is all about the little things) with the features aspect of this game is that there is no American-styled equipment in this game. Why go through all the effort to try and make an American styled map without American equipment??

Speaking of bugs, the only issue that I have come across so far is a little graphical glitch with the John Deere 6M where if you turn left, the JD logo on the front left fender veers off the fender.

Oh, and spreaking of graphics, the graphics in this game are awesome. A larger jump in improvement compared to the jump from FS15 to FS17.

If there would be anything to me that would make this game better to me it would be to lengthen out the 2 year deadline for another game to 2 and a half, or four years. That would get rid of the rush and people would be more happy with a less buggy game (according to others).

Also the ability to have sperate farms is a great new feature for multiplayer. Overall love this game even if it has some bugs now giant is work to fix them.

Seeing a lot of reviews about people complaining about a number of things from physics to placeables etc.

I have 100 hours as of this review, and have been playing since FS2013, and I honestly don't have 99% of the problems people are complaining about, or the problems I AM having in common with them are going to be patched soon or are so minor that it's not even worth worrying about, like the dog being buggy, as if that's a deal breaker. This is Farming Simulator, not Dog Simulator.

Has this been a bit of a rough release? Yes. Is it a bad game? Absolutely not, it's a fantastic game, by far the best farming simulator release so far, and considering I've already put in 100 hours over 10 days on a $35 game puts this in the "best value" category for me.

People talk about the lack of vehicles / tools / implements, most of those are being added as official "mods" by Giants which can be downloaded ingame or through their website. This was likely to cut down on the initial file size.

Player created mods are coming, it takes time. A lot of people were complaining that there were no mods practically the day of release. These people are dumb, don't listen to them. For example, OxygenDavid who is well known for his maps said that his new upcoming map for FS19 is going to take a couple months. Meanwhile you can find plenty of recolors, refill points, and beta maps on 3rd party mod sites.

-Edited to include 1.1.3 update fixes:

Broken key bindings. I can't -really- play until my joystick (Saitek ST290 PRO with 2400+ hrs of FS17 on it) works. PS: After 11 hours of tinkering, don't bother editing the .XML files. The problem is how the program applies the data from that file.

FS 17 was buggy as hell at launch too, but these folks had it all sorted out in a few months. I'm pretty bummed at the moment, but can confidently recommend this version knowing that it will all be okay soon. 

+ I did check out some of the new features before it crashed. The Horses, the new fertilizer, weed control, soil acidity and compaction simulation are even -more- revolutionary than the "tip anywhere" and ratchet straps where in FS17! And then there is the rendered sun and moon, *illuminated* instrument clusters, land purchase/SELL system, new missions, you can preview what you are purchasing in the shop now! ...

With only 9 hours of gameplay so far, I can say I had enough. I've played FS15 and FS17 and both of them are resonably better than this. The "overhauled graphics" and "Brand new graphics engine" really isn't what GIANT has lived it up to be, as the game only looks good if you max the settings with only 15-24fps. The background scenery is a sloppy mess which they didn't put any effort into and the trees look like they have knives for leaves. Moving on, the building in the game is an utter disappointment and rarely ever works in your favour. The buldings deform the land in hideous ways and give you a headache as you can barely place anything in them if they are on uneven terrain. It costs a fortune to place a bulding anywhere but flat land and ruins the area around it. Furthermore, there are so few buildings, that i dont even know why we have the option to bulid! You have an over priced farm house that does absolutely nothing, a couple ugly silos, a few sheds, and little to no useful buildings on top of the few i mentioned. And the dog! Don't even let me start! It's a clumsy, poorly put together animation and model which is a pointless mess. 

Now for the farming. The overall farming feels like any other farming simulator. It's choppy animations and ugly pop-in textures are all the same. The steering of the tractors is very slow but somewhat okay, and if you go anywhere over 40-50km/h, you end up doing a double backflip into a wall or fence somewhere. The first person view is slow and eats your frame rate, and the animations for operating the vehicles that GIANT praised is just simple. Nothing special about it. Now lets talk about the prices. The land that you purchase is way too over priced and makes the game a chore. You can barely make a living no matter what difficulty and the land that you think would work to put a shed on, is occupied by empty space that wont let you place any objects. Also, they got rid of the vehicle menu so that you cant find your vehicles or reset them. The only way to do it is to zoom in really far on the map and click on the icon. This way you cant find vehicles or equipment and check to see what you have if you're on a big farm. It is honestly disappointing

The game has major bugs and issues. If you tab out of the game at any point or even go to your toolbar, the game chooses a random aspect ration and basically streatches or shrinks your game to oblivion. Another great one is a sound bug that ear rapes you with one loud ass engine rev. There are so many that the list would go on forever. Honestly, its a piss-poor effort of a game and they should be ashamed to even call it a simulator. There are better FREE games out there than this $50 title. It feels as if they didnt even test it.

To wrap the whole thing up, its a huge disappointment. GIANT is just one big scam and puts no effort into making games at all. Oh and I forgot! It rains indoors still. They completely lied to us. Unless they update it or change how to whole game feels, stay to FS17.
Seems that Giant is listening to it's fanbase and is regularly updating their game. Graphic wise and vehicle wise it's a big step up from the last FS. Definitley a great farming game.

This pains me to say, but after loving FS17 to death, FS19 appears to be early access gone wrong (and it's not even early access)

Pros:
-Graphics Engine is vastly improved
-Tractor sounds are far better

Cons:
-Bugs Bugs Bugs Bugs
       -The first few bugs I encountered weren't game breaking, but the more I played, the worse it got.  I had to reset the career twice.
-Mission System is improved, but some tweaking needs to be done. (Missions not showing complete when you finish, not letting you work on a field that you have a contract to work on, etc.)
-Missing essential equipment like flatbed trailers and other implements to do work around the farm

TL:DR,
I was afraid Giants bit off more than they could chew, and I believe I was right.  Maybe with some updates and mods, the game will get better.  If that happens, I will update this review.  Nov. 20, 2018

Edit: Nov. 29
-It's obvious Giants has been working hard to resolve some of the most important issues.  It appears that most of the game breaking issues have been resolved and wheel support it slowly getting a lot better.  This game is now in a state where I can recommend it.

I've been a fan of this series since 2009. Each edition seems to get better and better, the only drawback being that, the newer the version, the longer it takes for all of those wonderful mods to become available. The graphics in FS19 are pretty awesome, and it runs almost flawlessly even on my old HP Pavilion. I snagged it the day it became available and I expected a few hickups, but I can't find them.
    The hired hands are still a little derpy and require a responsible adult to check in on them from time to time to make sure they don't get stuck waiting for a tree to move out of their way or something, but I like it. A word of caution about the Giants Editor for this one; at this time it's corrupt. Every download I've tried has an issue installing and my decompressor tells me it's the file's fault. If I'm wrong, please let me know, but this is a big disappointment. Thankfully it's the only one. I'd buy this game again if I had too, and I'm cheap!

Let me start by saying I really want to like this game. 
Additionally - I think this is like the 2nd review ive ever taken the time to write.
I have a few hundred hours on fs17, and was expecting at least that level of polishment.

The Con's List ( so far )
- So few buildings the " farm manager " option is a joke
- Vehicle model glitching after going like 40mph
-"Dead spots" in multiple fields where crops will not grow
-"Helpers" are still almost un-useable
- American map has more narrow streets than the euro map
- Everything is so expencive that you get to either have vehicles or buildings to start, not both
- The Dog .. lmao ... 
- Farm plots naturally divided by default on the map , arent actually divided, Helper plants both reguardless of grass barrier
- Additional little 4x4 offroad cart ( the preorder thing) is only available 50% of the time i look at the store.
- Missions arent worth doing for the crap payout
- When you start a mission, and lease the equipment for the mission - you must also drive all things individually to the mission farm plot , from the store ( which by ur self trying to drive a combine and a tractor from 1 side of the map to the other, wasted 45 min - just setting up to do a mission that took 2.5 ACTUAL REAL LIFE hours, for a payout of 18,968.

- Takes twice as long to "load" all menu options vs fs17


Pro's List ( its a short list )

- Graphical improvement .. 
- The plants actually bend and fall over when behind driven on
- The sky moves now, it isnt just a static picture
- Attention to detail of vehicles - fantastic!
- The moveing parts are nice, unfoldable things on tools, seats and wheel and character model in vehicles
- Can do missions on multiplayer................( not worth tho )


In summary ... like others here have said ... leave this disapointment alone until they fix everything ..
Feels like warmed over fs17 for a cash grab.

Hm... it`s like when you buy a chocolate with a fancy packaging and after taking a bite it dawns upon you that the looks are deceiving. So prior to buying the game i have played the FS17 for weeks...so after starting the game i could see the differences immediately.
Is it a re skin or it`s a new game? 
Well on the tech side i don`t know but on gaming side...well 90% of the game feels like FS17 tho the foliage graphics are beautiful, there is more grass everywhere and the new foliage bending when you drive on it looks amassing compared to the FS17 foliage. But sadly thats it. Everything else is more polished sharper but FS17 had some mods that replaced the ground textures with 4K ones and this feels like that. No more than a texture polish.

!Update! - this game suffers from the same limited Sphere LOD draw distances as the FS17 in which on max settings i saw as the foliage and crops pop in after a distance. This LOD draw distance seems to be sphere shaped emanating from your position. The sad thing is with the new game and new graphics i would expected this to get solved. But no :(.

!Update! - AI - now that i have spent a considerable time in the game and used 70% of the time the "Helper" i can confirm that die "Helper" AI got an overhaul. How much of an overhaul? Well i think a complete re-wright. In FS17 if there was a tree, lamppost or anything at the edge of the field the AI just rammed it and got stuck. Now i can plow my field to the edge of the road, forest because the AI will detect what is in front of him, go as near as possible, back up and turn on the field. I have a filed that is on one end 1m from the road with lampposts, and on the other end 5m from a forest. In the last 12 hours the AI managed to plow, cultivate,plant and fertilize the field without getting stuck or any intervention from my part. In FS 17 that was not possible. Traffic AI has been improved, they try to leave room for the tractors to turn on the road, but sometimes they tend to wait on tractors that are 30 m from the road and will never get on it, and some times they don't detect the tractors at all and ram them. So there are some things to polish but as far as the Helper AI goes...it`s definitely an improvement.

Is there an improved physics in this game compared to the previous games?
Well i have just the FS17 to compare it to and sadly the physics are the same. But i must mention that the off road vehicle that you can get in a DLC has an amassing suspension movement...most realistic that i seen in FS. But it can go up a 45-50% steep cliff whit eas...so much for physics. Tires bend under pressure...same as in FS17, indicators can be hit and they will fall...same as FS17...you can place buildings...same as FS17...but it was improved upon and now you can make your own farm instead of  getting one prebuilt farm...which you steel can if you choose so.

How hard is it on the PC? Performance
Sorry to see that it`s poorly optimized. Graphics on Very High gives me a whooping 60 FPS (thats the max for my monitor) but as i start to move and whit fields and foliage in my close vicinity it dips to 30 FPS but not lower. So you could think yeah try upgrading your graphics card men...well i have a 1080 with 8GB RAM so....that`s that. By the way the card is 100% utilized and the game uses 2-3Gb of Card memory. Well it could be a CPU related problem...do you have a i5 3600? Nope i7 7600 4 cores 8 threads... and it barely scrapes the 30% utilization during my play time. So it must be a HDD problem buy an SSD. Well i done one better i have an M.2 SSD :) so it`s 3x faster then a SATA SSD but with no benefit`s in this case as the game runs from my 16GB memory and the SSD barely reaches 1% utilization during game play. So....poorly optimized. And yeah i have the latest drivers... and i even used NVIDIA`s optimized settings for this game. So how can you solve this FPS dipping? Well i found 2 options which work just fine and i have constant 60FPS. One is looking in 3rd person view at the ground like GTA London style :). Or lowering foliage draw distance to 100% and all other LOD and Draw distance to 100 - 150% out of 200% at a 1080p resolution. ON A FUCKING 1080. 

The game looks gorgeous don't get me wrong an there are improvements like when buying a field you get an amount of surrounding terrain to not just the field it self, the 3D preview where you can see what are you buying (just to mention the camera moves with your mouse even if you ain't holding left mouse button down, it`s annoying to say the least), cabin and chair movement and now our surrogate turns the wheel with his hands and pushes the pedals with it`s feet which is awesome for immersion (i would mention that in combines and for Helpers this animation is laking). Hit boxes where updated and now you actually can go ower railway lines like in the real world without your vehicle hovering on an invisible box. Birds fly out of the foliage time to time which helps with immersion. Maintenance is added...don`t know how it works really but an indicator with a wrench is there. Interior screens and gauges work...but as i saw it it`s limited and more or less same as in good quality tractor mods. Horse play is included and a dog but i head no time to test that because of the performance issues. The sky is beautifull with the new moving clouds. And now for keyboard users there is an option to modofy how fast doas the wheel get to strait after turning...but the cars and tractors all turn sharp and unrealistic. I would say the driving with keyboard is whorst then in FS17...and i booted the FS17 just to see if it`s so...and yeah. Over all all tractors...implements...trailers are with improved graphics...expected from a 2018 release.
Update! I played a little bit with my settings and with Vertical Sinc on i have these problems that i mentioned with FPS dipping to 30 and with Vertical Sinc off it improves so much that i can set everithing to max and the minimum that i haw 30% of the time is 38FPS. 

But on the bad side the Isle map is full with design problems...just to mention one...every single railway crossing. The rail tracks stick out like a sour thumb and you just clip true the rails...it`s disappointing to see this...and if i go to FS17 there are proper railway crossings. Unloading seeds looks horrible with a seed shower not even getting to the ground...the seeds disappear in thin air 95%  of the way and by the first trailer that you can buy the seed when unloading at the default position you see the door opening and you would expect the seeds rushing out from the full trailer...but no there is an invisible wall holding the seeds and letting only a thin line to flow out. It`s eve worse then in FS17.
!Update! - now with more time in the game a had the chance to try more trailers out...i`m sorry to say that all unloading animations...like Kombines or trailers have either timing issues or they just go through the trailer (Auger Wagons for instance).

So buy or not to buy. Well now that i played this game i can`t go back to FS17 :). That shoud answer it.

I will of course update this review as the game continues it`s Early Access state in a full release format. I hope for the best.

====================

Edit: 2018-11-22:
Well, the issue with the ghost input was due to some xInput Device, which I turned off in the device manager. Okay, my bad. Still not playable, though.

The next issue is, that the game does not save my keybindings. I use a Thrustmaster T500RS which is labeled "B65E" for whatever reason in the game.

The "funny" thing, though, is that if I change deadzone/sensivity settings for my TM, I see the following:

Axis 0: Deadzone: 0.14 ; Sensivity: 1.00
Axis 11: Deadzone: 0.14 ; Sensivity: 1.00
Axis 12: Deadzone: 0.14 ; Sensivity: 1.00
Axis 13: Deadzone: 0.14 ; Sensivity: 1.00

It does absolutely not matter what changes I do, after saving the changes and restarting the game, the values I mentioned above are set again.

Well, there is an inputBinding.xml file in Documents/my Games/FarmingSimulator19 which contains those values. Well, sort of, only axis 0 is listed here.

If I add axis 11 to 13 and do whatever with the values, e.g. setting the deadzone to 0, the game only notices it for axis 12 and 13. After just closing the game, the lines for axis 11 to 13 are removed from the xml file.


Still a gamebreaker, BECAUSE I HAVE TO PLAY WITH DEFAULT BINDINGS ... Got about 90 minutes of play time. If the bug-tracker forum (buahahahah xD bullshit -_-) does not reply within the next two days, I'll order a refund.

This sucks as well, because this report will vanish from steam -_-

====================

Edit 2: The support answered within minutes, after mentioning plans to refund the game ... interesting. Anyway, there is a fix in development and will be released "soon".

====================

After playing for just a couple hours I already couldn't even imagine going back to FS17. 80 hours later, farming still feels better than it ever did before. Good job Giants :D

Almost every single aspect of the game has been improved from FS17 in some way. Most notably:

- item handling: Moving things by hand is no longer frustrating! Things no longer fly out of your hand whenever you touch anything, no Herculean strength to flip tractors with a piece of wood and able to rotate items in-hand. Looking forward to conventional balers at this point.

- vehicle handling: greatly improved, steering feels much more realistic (using keyboard), you can feel you're driving a several ton piece of machinery, suspension and ground response better than ever

- vehicle maintenance: vehicles no longer have daily maintenance fee, instead they have wear and tear that you have to fix for a small fee (similar to what Seasons mod did in FS17), resulting in massive decrease in passive running cost for the farm (idle vehicles don't cost you)

- land management: you no longer own entire map except the fields, land/field expansion feels more natural with having to buy the land. Buy a forest, cut down the trees and turn it into farmland!

- buildings: finally able to build up your own farm other than just adding a couple sheds, although placing stuff on anything but a very flat ground can cause issues. Upcoming terraforming feature will fix that, potentially. Also choice of buildings in base game is limited, but I'm sure modding community fill flood the game with dozens of new items soon.

- field management: new lime and weeds mechanics, greatly expanding on the "fertilize 3 times" approach from FS17, more stuff to do between sowing and harvesting phases

- new stuff: cotton, horses, sugarcane (for those without FS17 platinum). All with their own mechanics/machinery. More variety of stuff to do, even if cotton is pretty bad profit compared to other crops.

- contracts: complete overhaul of missions, much less clunky although somewhat buggy at the moment (weeds will overtake NPC fields permanently)

- animals: chickens are finally not useless, as eggs will spawn in boxes without having to collect them manually. Placeable animal pens require higher initial investment in livestock, similar to buying fields for arable farms. 

- shop: better separation of vehicles and implements into categories, full 3D preview of machinery and its configuration ("Does this tractor look silly with narrow tires and painted pink? Did that trailer have a hitch on the back or not? I'll just look and see!")

- graphics: not a massive leap forward but pretty good upgrade overall, game feels to be running smoother than FS17 too. Big improvements in lighting and atmospheric visuals, you can easily see the difference in the overall image and feel of the game. Beautiful sunsets and night lights :)

- audio: a lot of good enviromental sounds, engine sounds stand out much more than in FS17

- interface: new interface look, much cleaner, more readable and compact


Stuff that did not improve (or marginally):
- AI Workers: Almost as derpy as always :D, seem to miss less parts of a field on angled edges though
- Logging: while the new chainsaw animation is good, it seems 'aiming' the cuts is less intuitive, pieces of wood can still get glitched after cutting (weird collision box and mass) and still missing any sound when a massive tree falls down. Need that satisfying 'creeeeeak-THUD'

While the game sure has some issues currently, none are too serious or game-breaking (as far as I've encoutered).

I've logged more hours on farm simulator than any other game, so it was natural to move on to the latest version 2019.  But it's like this game is only half done!  Every time I want to do anything I have to download a mod just to get the job done.  I keep getting stuck because of the lack of proper implements to run my farm.   No autostacker for round bales, but they provide a round baler, so they expect you to hand load round bales onto a trailer which is about as much fun as gouging my eye out.   They provide an implement that processes your beets into "easy to sell pallets" then they forgot to put any triggers in the game that accept them.  I have yet to find a place to sell pallets.  You can start this new game from scratch and just a pile of money which is great, but they forget to let you know where on the map they provided a place to place your first buildings.  The list goes on.  Why release this new version when half of it is missing?  So frustrating I wish at this point I could get my money back and go back to 2017 version.

I don't have a lot of time logged on any of the Farming Sim games. That being said I was really looking forward to this one, mostly for the "build your own farm" feature. 
-Build your own farm is a joke. There are a few buildings, but placing them in a way that makes them look good and functional is almost impossible. 
-Once again the game releases with only 2 maps. Maybe I am missing something, but it seems like each version of this game keeps moving towards mountains every field is on a hill of some kind. Can I please have just one map of nice flat farming terrain.
-One of the biggest problems I have can be seen with this game, but many other games as well. There seems to be this collective attitude like the developers are gods and we owe them our money and god forbid we question them. reading the positive reviews for this game, I stopped counting at 23 times I saw someone say "Mods will take care of that". Mods are great but if we have to count on them to make the game playable then the developers are not doing their jobs. 
-The game is playable and it is fun, but it's a dissapointment from what I was expecting.
-If you already have '17 save your money and just keep playing that, at least until this goes on sale. The current price is not worth the graphics upgrade. Thats all that is different here, all of the other smalle changes are attainable via mods for '17 If you don't have '17 buy that instead or wait. Hopefully they will fix this one.

5 stars

Very engrossing so far. I've played nearly 20 hours slaving away at a controller.
I forgot to buy a farmhouse, so I'm technically homeless. Good thing I don't need to sleep. I just bought my second tractor, though!
My first purchase after starting the game was a dog. Even before a silo. Totally worth it, because I get to pet it, and it follows you around while you're on foot.
And you can't run it over, which is good because tractors are kinda hard to control when badly laden. (Sorry, dog.)

Unlike previous games, you start with a blank slate, at least in normal mode. You have a bit over a million, no land, no vehicles, no home. Buy what you want, where you want, then go farm it. But you have to buy your own silos and animal pens, and even access to the biogas plant's bunker silos and their land to dump silage on.
Trains move on their own, which is a little unnerving at first when you realise you need to watch out for them.

Definitely worth buying.

Would sugest waiting for some mods to come out and some bugs to be sorted.

I like how grass, weeds and bushes are animated and how they look. Don't really like that the interaction between them, seems a bit weird and unnatural.

Found really annoying the fact that shadows do a litle dance, like the light source moves left to right all the time.


Giants put a lot of work and try do nice things, but it just feels like in some places they have no clue.

Would still recommend the game as I can see some improvements which with the right mods could make for a nice farming game.

It's called farming simulator but it's actually "Tractor Driving Game". It's about driving machines to do tasks. If you play realistically then it's a realistic game, but if you don't care you can do wacky things and nothing will break.

The 19 edition adds small improvements over the 17 edition making 19 the better game.

If the experience clicks with you then "literally watching grass grow simulator" is very fun somehow. Maybe it's the challenge of beating the rat race starting from scratch, maybe it's the satisfaction from delay of gratification, seeing the planning and hard work pay off some time later. Maybe it's learning about farming machines and being creative in finding different ways to get the work done, or contemplating the design of these amazing labor-saving devices which make food easily affordable - you may not get to be a one man army but with the power of technology you can be a one-man farmer - buy yours today!

For fans of the FS series, I do not recommend this game.
Many of the new features are buggy, poorly thought out or very shallow.

The core of this game remains almost identical to the previous release, yet somehow they managed to introduce enough bugs or bad design decisions to make this game extremely frustrating to try to play. Read through the Giants forum to get an idea before you buy.
Issues include:
[list]
[*]Terrible support for controllers (doesn't support more than 4 input devices, resets controls constantly or totally disables them - the game removed the hire worker control for me so I was unable to hire a worker at all)
[*]Poorly balanced or broken mission system, cannot complete some missions
[*]Multiplayer control axes reversed from single player
[*]They have added a delay with throttle inputs, making any work with a forklift or telehandler difficult
[*]The placables system is basically unchanged from FS17 but is now compulsory for working with animals. This would be fine except that there are virtually no places on the maps where you can place the buildings without creating a ridiculous ugly ramp up to the edge of the building because there is no flat ground. And don't bother trying to delete existing buildings because nothing can be built in the space that they once occupied
[/list]

Graphics look nice up close, but most of the models in the game are the same as FS17 with slightly improved textures. Improved foliage effects only served to make the LOD pop-in more ugly by comparison. Lighting is definitely an improvement, the menus are better and I like the new lime/fertilisation system.

All new bugs.

Stick with FS17.

Great game, a few minor bugs but other than that, works fine.

I really enjoy this game so far. I think there are some features that are a bit wacky still, but maybe they'll do some hotfixes or something to get rid of them.  For example, they introduced their new ground leveling system for placeable objects, well on the server that I play on and the fields that I own, the $9,000 building costs me $130,000 to place because there isn't anywhere with a completely flat area without taking up my field space.  I really enjoy the new seat and pedal animations that they now include which really helps it be immersive, and the multiplayer contracts have really made the game more enjoyable for online players.  It would be nice to see their new flagship crop to actually be of use instead of being the least proftiable crop in the entire game.  It seems like prices and the main cash crop haven't changed from the last version, which isnt nessicarliy a bad thing, but it would be nice to be able to play with the new crop type and not lose money in the new "hard" mode.  I really enjoy that they now offer three different modes, one like the traditional fs17 games, one where you start out with plenty of money, but no equipment or land and must purchase it yourself, and one that you start out with very limited money and no equipment or land.  It has given me something to work for without reaching endgame in just a few days.  Overall its not a perfect game but it is a game that I have come to enjoy, and look forward to playing with buddies after getting home from work for a few hours when I don't feel like playing anything that requires a bunch of attention or just want something to do to relax.

Another solid reiteration of Farming Simulator, there's absolutely nothing inherently wrong with the game. 

Vehicle textures have improved along with field textures and richness of color.

There's several new features that add some welcomed depth to the series. I enjoy the option of being able to set up wherever I want as well as addtional field maintenance to acheive maximum efficiency.

( HINT : Yes, there are a handful obvious spots on the map where they are basically inviting you to build, BUT you can revert any plowed land back to grass and virtually homestead on any section of map, given it's owned land) 

The US map is a bit stark and a bit odd for a "farm feel", I think they were going for a Northern California farming community feel with the map.....it is growing on me, albeit slowly. I trust there wont be any shortage of available maps once people have time to complete map mods.

It seems like people were hoping for more, that's understandable. Given Giant's trackrecord, the new releases have always been a bit "updatey" but, as far as I'm concerned....I'm happy with the game.

Seasons anyway???...... What am I going to do? Chop all the wood on my map while my animals starve with the game clock is set to 120x because I can't plant anything?  eh, just my two cents. ( wait, maybe that would be cool lol )

~ I've not ecountered any bugs, glitches or crashes at this time. 11/24/18

A hint to them on this is the A.I. controls from Construction sim 2, where i can tell the  ding-a-ling in the dumptruck to follow the cold planner.

So in short the only issues are the farm building and the A.I. after 9 or so years is still dumber then a potato

Farming Simulator 19 is almost exactly what we've come to expect from the FS franchise. It's an enjoyably buggy game that gives users full creative expression to build the farm of their dreams. With new features like lime and cotton the game adds more options than it's prededcessor and the developers have obviously listened to the community when it comes to the features that FS17 players wanted to see implimented into the base game. 

Pros: 
-New Crops and livestock allow a more dynamic game, especially in multiplayer
-Multiplayer is VASTLY improved over FS17 with individual farms and bank accounts in the base game.
-"Building your own farm" gives you a feeling of being more connected to the game than in previous versions.
-Of course... John Deere
-Huuuuge modding community is already hard at work creating new and exciting mods for FS19
-Dev's seem to be receptive to criticism and are currently working to push a patch to fix the known issues.

Cons: 
-It's a Giants game, the initial release is always full of bugs and it takes a few weeks to work out.
-The engine, doesn't seem to be that much different than FS17 and the game mechanics are almost identical
-Controller support is still an issue
-Some features in Multiplayer obviously weren't tested (granting contractor status, doing contracts for AI)
-AI system is still unable to cope with basic obstacles.
-Lots of equipment has issues with mirrors, lights, interior lighting, etc. 
-Giants didn't include "Seasons" OR a working GPS in the game. I know I don't speak for the entire world, but of the dozen people I have spoken to about FS19 all of them were dissapointed about these features being absent. 

Overall I think GIANTS has a solid base for what could have been an AMAZING game, but in it's current state it's only "OK". If you're a fan of the FS/LS franchise you should buy the game, but if you're reading reviews to make your decision you probably are going to be dissapointed, at least until they patch some of the major bugs.

During E3 and gamescon I expected more out of game, build your own farm or buy exiting one is nothing to compare what we have now. No farm to buy, only build your own with nothing to choose from, one garage, one silo.....  I expected more. Only mods can save this FS17 DLC

A real shame. Big fan of FS, I was looking forward to a new sequel and pre-purchased it. But it is nothing but one huge disappointment:
1 - Forget the animals. The troughs will miraculously fill by themselves. You supply the feed only once. No point playing. It is beyond me how could they release the game with such a major and obvious flaw.
2 - Loading/unloading/refilling - unlike FS 17, you have to stand by and watch (in most cases). Plain silly.
3 - Hay/grass loading wagon can no longer hire driver. (using the smallest  windrower)
4 - Buying/selling animals - endless clicking, no way to enter a number. Same with borrowing money.
5 - No point to bother with tedders or windrowers. Just put a tiny bit of hay in the loading wagon and collect grass. It will become all hay.

And so on and on, glitches, mistakes and changes for the worse from 17, the game even briefly freezes occasionally, which never happened in 17. So for 35 dollars you get two maps and (worthless) horses. If the developer had a bit of decency, they would at least give owners of FS17 half or more off. 

But they basically cashed in and gave the fans and modders the finger. They are selling untested product showing negligence and absence of care. This release actually borders on false advertising. The promised "best graphics ever" is actually worse than in 17. There is NOT ONE single improvement. Pathetic.

If you have FS17, don't even think about buying.
2013, 2015, and 17 were less buggy than this pile of garbage. Rushed and unfinished game!

More bugs than you could possibly imagine. Did they even have anyone test this game before they released it?? There's no way this made it through any type of QA process. Game recognizes my Fanatec Clubsport pedals and my T-Rudder pedals but refuses to allow me to assign them to anything. As of right now, it's impossible to assign any axis to accelerate or brake. This is seriously a step backwards from FS2017. Sure the new graphics look pretty but everything else is a complete disappointment. This is not an upgrade from 2017....This is an over hyped, over marketed cash grab.

I will review positivily but I hope that folks take time to read this review. I've been a farm-sim player since 2011, the only version I never palyed was the 2009 version. I do farm in real life as well and I've always enjoyed the game as a way to try new farming ideas in the virtual world. I dont dicsourage from buying this game but to return buyers of the series I'd like to say that the only real differences to the game are better greaphics and a few small upgrades. The game at the time of me writing this still has many game issues and glitches to work out, however giants is a great company and will take care of its customers in time. As a long time player of this series I may say that I might have hit my end with the game. My favorite of the series was FS 15 ecause for its day it was the best improvement over the former versions and had the best graphics upgrades at the time. Now I feel that as a farmer in real life that I just dont know where to go with this game anymore, I've done all the game has to offer. That just my personal opinion though. I would say buy this game if you enjoy the series, and like a challenge. the bugs will get worked out in time and it will be a great game to play. Just remember however, the game will get repetitive in time. Farming in real life really doesnt get repetitive because conditions  change every year, however to model that in a game would be impossible lol. Enjoy the game, giants has really out done themselves on this one, its a beautiful game with lovely graphics. Also I end with a tip, make sure your pc is running at least 2gb VRAM on a discrete graphics card otherwise the game will run poorly or not run at all. Farmers feed the world, god bless. Happy Farming.

Ya know, there is something in common for some or many (I`m not sure about number), or all German games. Or its simulation games only. The main thing - simulation, or core part of game, call it what you want, is done very well, but all secondary things - animation, optimisation, visuals, secondary missions, objectives are horrible. For example - Omsi 2, farming sims... They all missing quite significant parts.

And separately about farming sims - to play this alone without courseplay is hard, boring. And I`ve got nearly all games - 13, 15, 17 and 19. The red line goes through all of them - mods. Only because of mods these games still coming out, and I fear only because of mods they come in shape like they are - unfinished. And always we pay full price. With hope, something will be better this time. And yes, something gets better everytime. But just something. It`s like the path to the ultimate farming simulator - gets better with every new version. How many of these versions gonna be more? I dunno. And i feel pity for poor modders, who has their lives, jobs and all, but everytime they have rebuild their mods to be compatible with new version of game. What will happen when loyal modding community get tired of this? The farming sim will die or we will see the ultimate farming sim? The one we all been waiting for all these years... Hard to say...

Every new game with old illnesses - the help section is nearly useless, it don`t say what you can use to fight weeds for example. Well it`s obvious, you`d say - a weeder! Right. And what are my other options? Having some knowledge in real farming, i understand that using sprayer and herbicide also helps. Other topic - icons. Every new game, everytime a new guide appears with meaning of these icons. Say, does it really hard to add a line of text under the icon??? Will it kill the immersion or what else?

Giants releases only a barebone of game, admit that. With bugs and all. Everytime. Well, I don`t afraid call it a beta version. Modders and players hunting bugs drags it to "release". Though money drops into pockets of Giants only. It`s like DYI game - add your mods and play as you like.

Nevertheless all aforementioned, I`d recommend this version. On sale. Or after 6 months. When we have all needed mods and bugs fixed.

Ok, ok, besides all criticism, some good things. I like new graphic additions - tools loosing the paint; more detalised machines, tractors. But again, every FS game I tried it`s like player is in some sort of buble, where nice and cool textures inside, but low poly outside. And the border between both good and bad is so good visible! It was ok for games 5 years back, but today... when I look what breathtaking views are made with Unity... and this. Giants, it`s time to change. And community, it`s time to say we demand the true and only the ultimate farming sim. Enough to feed us with this unfinished "release" every few years. Enough to earn money on some enthusiasts free work you gladly take into game.

I like farming sim, I really do. But with every new game I play less and less. I`m afraid i will not buy the next one, if current develpment will stay as it is now.

Thanks for reading.

Get your bug spray out...omg I don't know if you could have any more bugs than this game has. I have only played on a few pieces of equipment so far and most of them have bugs. Ideal 8t harvester - doesn't unload properly at times or at all, Sometimes when the counter says it is empty you can see physical crop still in the hopper and it doesnt fold, graphical glych on the shading on the backside. The Case 9240 combine it unloads properly but the counter says zero and you can see physical crop inside so it doesnt fold (and yes I am set on the combine). The small capella sunflower seed combine header is unplayable as it misses chunks of crops in the middle of the header...Can't use any of the small combines to do sunflowers!!!!!!!!!! Combine headers run while on the ground not attached to anything. The game looks nice and runs well in single plater but come on it was a copy of 17 to 19 with John Deere added on. Not much changes graphically or with much. The animals are still shaky and make you want to puke when you get close to them. FYI testing your game before release instead of copying the entire previous version and changing it for a month and putting it out would be a good idea. Also multiplayer is still horrible and pretty much unplayable in this game doesn't matter how good your PC or connections are. Buy it on sale unless they start fixing these bugs which I have yet to see any updates. Get on it Giants you can't tell me it took a whole lot of time to do the initial game. If I had paid any more than I did I would have refunded it already. The problem with this game is that it takes quite a bit of game play to get to be able to afford everything so you are may hours in before discovering these issues. Thumbs down until these bugs are fixed...Like I said I am sure I will find many more to come.

Well, This is a great game, but not built right. First off, the buildings, can really screw up the terrain with no way to reset it which makes it even harder if your starting from scratch. Not good with trying to store your farming fleet.  Second, The Trees, How can you Forestry if the log's physics stretch beyond the Texture/model. I flipped a tractor over by not hitting the texture/model but the messed up physic box. Third, Old model/trailers miss balanced, Now this one messes up a lot. How can you drive in a straight line when the trailer lifts up the back wheels, even though the fuel trailer should have no problem with the truck when filled, making the weight all in the back is not a real world weight. Over the FS 15, 17, and 19, FS19 has let me down. I never had these issues in FS17.
It's like Skyrim but with tractors and without the fantasy and monsters and roleplaying.
There are a handful of issues that should hopefully be worked out in patches pretty quickly, but so far FS19 has some solid improvements. If you enjoyed FS17 at all, you'll be a fan of 19.

I love the new game but I have found some issues, and I am confident Giants will sort it all out in time. Remember, it took time for FS17 to become what it is today and that is arguably the best farming simulator ever made. I think that FS19 will surpass the previous title in time. The mods, the maps, and all the scripting is what really opens these games up anyway.
The graphics are beautiful but need to be re shaded.. The colors are dry and should be more vibrant. Tractor physics are amazing! I love how the game plays, how they drive, and It really has met my expectations minus a few issues so far.

The issues I have had:

-Pallets just out of no where flying off the pallet forks into oblivion. 
-Pallets of fertilizer just falling through the pallet forks all together when I tried to move them to tidy the yard.
-On perfectly square base game fields the helpers don't complete the field in its entirety. (Could be my error)
-The prices are really steep in this game. While I do like the new challenge in FS19, I do think it makes it harder to get into animal work early game, which is what I liked in the previous title. 

Thank you Giants for another incredible game. I know you will iron out these issues with coming updates.

Ok, so this is my first ever review.

First off, let me say that I am a huge fan of FS series to date.  Particularly FS 17.

But on reflection I now realise that FS17 was great because it created a platform for modders to really up their game.
Now that I'm playing FS19 without mods, I've come to realise that the game is only good with mods. For me anyway.
For me, I like the dynamic of using Courseplay to effectively manage the farm as oppposed to just drive tractors etc.

Why doesnt Giants take ANY advice from its fans? We have been saying for years to add some kind of courseplay replica
to really enhance gameplay. We have also been asking for better ground working physics, more realism. One of the only games I have seen do this is Agriculture Simulator...yes it was an absolute shambolic mess from the get go, but they had the two things FS is missing. A management function AND better ground dynamics.


So heres a few pros and cons:

Pros
-The machinery looks really good. Particularly on High settings.
-There is a real "weight" to driving the bigger machines. This is helped by the new steering system too.
-Finally added John Deere. 
-Really interesting "contracting" model.

Cons
-The gameplay reminds me of the original FS. The monotony of drawing my own grain etc is creeping in.
-The maps are dogshit. Unimaginative. Badly planned. Again, reminds me of a bygone era of FS.
-There is NO useful infrastructure that you can buy. Couple of sheds and a vehicle workshop.
-4/10 times, my games crashes
-Ground dynamics are literally the exact same as FS17.
-Fuck all new machinery.
-WAAAYYY TOOOO DAAYYUMM EXPENSIVE YOOO

My verdict:

This game had real potential. The build up to release alone had me really pumped to get it. But its just a re-skinned version of FS17. I for one, will be going back to FS 17 until the very talented modders out there make this game great.
All around better than last version with some much needed Tweeks. I wish that the American Map was not populated with Garbage
Good graphics and animations, more realistic than fs 17. Price is okay but I would recommend wait steam sales. Pretty similar than previous FS but that's obvious.
A little confusing having never played the series before but, overall fun and relaxing.

FS19 in its current state simply isn't ready to be released. Yes, the graphics are stunning compared to the previous games, unfortunately that's the only good thing I can think of the game in its current state.

The physics are worse than ever, pallets either stick to the ground or flip in the air when you try to pick them up,
Logs are indredibly heavy for some reason, forcing you to use logging machines/forks to pick up the tiniest of logs,
The logs have the worst collision I've ever seen in the FS series ; they float when you put them on trailers, won't let you fully close the log fork when picking them up, they'll slide off the machinery at most random times,
The current mission system is so un-rewarding it's not worth doing 90% of the time,
AI is dumber than ever, won't finish half the jobs you start them up and give you "unkown reason" as an excuse to stop working,
Lots of reported bug/glitches with Controllers bindings,
The new placeable farm features is incredibly costly should you place something on the tiniest of slope, etc..

This game has a lot of potential and I'm sure will become one of the best Farming Sims out there, but in its current state (just released I know we should expect "some" bugs), there are way too many downsides for it to be enjoyable.

Farming Simulator 2019 is a great game with no limits! I'm currently playing in the "Farm Manager" mode and it's perfect for me! Starting with ~$125.000 and you don't own anything, of course you need to be a bit finical experienced here but I made it! I'm having fun with the game and play it every day! So many machines, equipment, etc to experience with hundreds of game time left! And if you get bored of the machines, FS19 have great support for mods and a huge modding community! So you will get able to download gamechangers, new machines for FREE by the time being! 
But thanks to the hundereds of machines, equipments etc, you have much to explore before getting bored!

Positives:
Fantastic graphics, physics and envoriment!
Hundreds of licensed machines, equipment and more from over hundered different real brands!
Open-world, you'll do whatever you want from agriculture, forestry, animal care, just driving around or yeah, whatever you want to do!
Fantastic community by the internet including tutorials, let's plays, posts and much more!
Fantastic support for mods and a HUUUUGEEE modding-community!
Many different crops.
The controls are not so different from even back to FS15, (Which was my latest version)
This is not even all, i could sit here the whole day writing positives :D

Negatives:
the driving physics is a bit weird. 
Wait, was that all? ... Hmm, Great game!

As you propably already have telled, i would higly recommend this game for those who are for the types of these games!

I totatally love FS and have spent more hours in it than I care to think about. 

If there was an "unsure" button to click when recommending games, this is the one I would use for FS2019. Seeing as there isn't, I am going to go with "Not Recommended".

I have played for a few hours now, and to be honest I am a little underwhelmed. The graphics may be slightly better, and the machinery more varied, but I am struggling to really find anything new that can really justify a whole new game with a fairly hefty price tag.

The game mechanics seem to have stayed fairly much the same as have the physics. The graphics and HUD may have had a slight improvement maybe but nothing earthshattering. Yeah, they added "Horses" and "Weeding" but nothing with the potential to blow my socks off.

I was hoping for a larger improvement on the previous titles. Mud? (thinking Spintires here). Greater weather dynamics (snow or ice?). Different terrain (marshland?). Different aspects to the agricultural industry (reclaiming boggy land, use of excavators to install drains, buying heavier lifting equipment to build sheds?) Some of these things do actually exist in the world of farming.

I know I expected too much - although I would have been happy with just a little bit more. Sorry Giants - I have loved your work up until now.

For newcomers, I recommend this game, and FS diehards will buy it anyway (I did!). But if you owned FS17 and aren't sure where to invest your hard-earned cash, maybe leave this one to the side for now.

I started playing this the moment it came out, and I have to say, it was not worth the wait.

Pros: Good detail, amazing scenery, better animations, crops lay down when you drive over them, this game FINALLY has John Deere, you get a dog, you can get bigger loans, you can get horses, more crops, more machines, you can sleep through the night, lights are a lot brighter, birds fly in and out of your field, workers don't get stuck on something as easily, and the workers do a better job with angles than the previous games.

Cons: Workers keep leaving small spots undone, workers won't stop backing up after they get done with a job, machinary resets to shop instead of your farm, too many posts to run into and get stuck, you run out of fuel way too quickly, land is extremely expensive, you get horses but I can't place them anywhere yet, I don't know if it's my computer or not but it started running almost perfectly but now it keeps glitching, It rains a little too much, It's hardly every sunny and clear, I'll run a cultivator that can plant as well but it looks like it just cultivates instead, steering and camera movement are slow, it's really easy to get hit by the train it comes by really fast and you don't get much warning, It's very bumpy, a lot of hills making it harder to turn around, birds flying in and out of your field gets annoying, cones are in the way at the gas station, workers take forever to turn around, and you can't just buy the fields you have to buy the land around the fields as well.

I'm still playing the game, and I haven't gone through everything, but this is what I've noticed so far.

Significant upgrade over FS17. Too many people are focusing on small bugs present at launch (admittedly annoying) and missing the large improvments made elsewhere.

The graphics may not look dramatically different on the surface but the change in the rendering process feel different in game. Add to that the dramatic level of detail on every object and the too-many-to count new animations and this really feels like a simulator.

The ability to place most of the useable objects around the farm really is a game changer. At launch there is admittedly a lack of variety in placeable objects, but just being able to determine where you store crops, park vehicles and most importantly raise animals allows for more freedom than any previous entry. You are no longer stuck with the map maker's idea of a layout!

Highly recommend to any Farming Simulator fan!

The bugs make this game so not enjoyable at all. I was a huge fan of FS17, and this is such a step back.

Good:

- Graphics are better at max settings, but still the shadow and plant draw distances suffer.
- The character animations are cool and he actually bounces, moves, presses pedals and steers.
- Some cool new machinery
- Horses are a nice addition and work pretty well.

Bad:

BUGS. At this stage of the game it is clear they did minimal QA testing of the game. Like there is no way they did much at all. Or just didn't care enough to fix it before launch. Either way it's unacceptable. People that haven't run into bugs yet have probably not done much because i have run into a TON of them. The Fliegl bale trailer attaches itself to whatever was loaded on it even after you unload it. so whatever you unload FOLLOWS IT AROUND AND DESTROYS EVERYTHING IN ITS PATH. Bales, pallets, bags it doesnt matter. The tractors get extremely dirty after you drive 20 feet after washing them. WHY EVEN WASH THEM? The terrain deforms so badly when you place a shelter that you cant even drive your equipment into the shelter sometimes. Both included map designs are AWFUL. A lot of fields dont have enough space due to terrain or objects around them to even turn around equipment when working the fields.  there are numerous other problems and this game needs A LOT of work and I don't see a lot of these things getting fixed any time soon or at all. This really sucks because i loved FS17 but this just is NOT FUN in its current rushed, buggy and unacceptable state. Ill come back in a few months and update my review if things have been fixed.

I have played every Farming Simulator game since 2009, normally bought on release date. This one is the most discouraging game out the gate.

This is a day 1 review, and I will update it as the game is updated:

Pro's
Lighting is vastly improved
New crops are always a great addition
Horses - Good to have another new animal to the game!

Cons
Bugs. Bugs. Bugs. 

Controller support - Before I started the game, I had my joystick hoytas plugged in from another game, plus my controller. I unplugged it, started the game, and the game still wanted to use my hoytas. I had to restart the computer to fix this. Others are reporting that they are having issues with X controller or wheel, but restarting the computer fixes it. I hate to have to restart my computer when I am switching games. Those days were gone when Windows 3.1 came out.

Horses - I guess this is the first attempt, but very derpy controls. Extremely wonky while you are riding. The hitbox is horribly huge, and if you are within what looks like 4 feet of an object, it will block you. You can climb trees with a horse. The idea is solid, but horrible execution.

In Summary:

If you own FS 17, and still play it, I do not recommend this game at this time. If you are new to the series, and just want to farm, then sure, jump on in. If you preordered the game, then you don't need my review to make your choice for you.

Edit 1:  Adding in list of bugs per request. These are not all the bugs I have seen, just the ones I can think of while at work.

Disappearing missions.
Parts of the field "disappearing" while harvesting, making it to where you cannot see what you have done, and what you have not done.
Parts of fields not able to be sowed.
Chicken egg boxes not filling because something is within 5 miles of it.
Placeables, everything about them, very buggy
Helper bots occasionally leaving the field they are on and going 3 fields away. (I LOL everytime.)
7.1 sound still doesn't work, even after yesterday's patch that supposedly fixed it.
Other people report crashes, but 25+ hours, I haven't had this.
However, occasionally, the sound get's extremely wonky requiring a restart.
3 times I have tried to connect to my server, but nothing shows on the list. The fix is a restart.
Rollers don't create grass that grows. (might be intentional, but they won't say. I can see reasons for and against this being intentional)
A lot of graphical bugs
